DOCUMENT TYPE: Board Meeting Minutes
DATE: January 6, 2025
PREPARED BY: Corporate Secretary Maria Fuentes
DISTRIBUTION: Board of Directors
CLASSIFICATION: Board Confidential
REFERENCE: NXS-BOD-2025-001

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
MINUTES OF THE REGULAR MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Q4 2024 REVIEW AND 2025 OPERATING PLAN APPROVAL

Meeting Location: Nextera Solutions Headquarters, 14th Floor Boardroom, 655 Montgomery Street, San Francisco, California 94111

Meeting Called to Order: 9:02 AM Pacific Standard Time

Members Present:
  Robert Kessler, Board Chair
  David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer
  Sarah Jiang, Independent Director
  Tom Whitfield, Independent Director
  Nina Patel, Independent Director

Also Present:
  Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer (presenting)
  Maria Fuentes, Corporate Secretary (recording)

Quorum: Confirmed. All five members of the Board of Directors were present in person. A quorum existed throughout the entirety of the meeting.

Meeting Duration: 2 hours 14 minutes

---

I. CALL TO ORDER AND APPROVAL OF PRIOR MINUTES

Board Chair Robert Kessler called the meeting to order at 9:02 AM. Mr. Kessler confirmed attendance and the presence of a quorum. The minutes from the October 14, 2024 regular meeting were presented for approval. Mr. Kessler noted that one minor correction had been submitted by Ms. Jiang regarding the phrasing of a resolution on the equity incentive plan amendment; the correction was noted and incorporated into the final version of the October minutes. Upon motion by Ms. Patel, seconded by Mr. Whitfield, the Board unanimously approved the prior meeting minutes as amended.

Mr. Kessler welcomed the Board to the first meeting of 2025 and noted the packed agenda covering Q4 performance review, financial position, the 2025 Operating Plan, governance matters, and the executive session. He proposed proceeding with Mr. Aldric's Q4 review, followed by Ms. Vasquez's financial report, before moving to the operating plan vote. The Board agreed to the proposed order of proceedings.

II. CEO REPORT — Q4 2024 PERFORMANCE REVIEW

Mr. Aldric presented the Q4 2024 performance review to the Board. The presentation consisted of 34 slides covering revenue performance, customer acquisition, competitive dynamics, product milestones, and operational highlights for the quarter ending December 31, 2024. A printed copy of the slide deck was distributed to each Board member.

Mr. Aldric reported that Q4 revenue came in at $31.2M against a target of $30.5M, representing a beat of approximately 2.3% over plan. He noted that the outperformance was driven by three large enterprise deals that closed in the final two weeks of December, each above $250K in annual contract value. Mr. Aldric walked the Board through the customer acquisition funnel, noting that the enterprise pipeline had been strong throughout Q4 with particular strength in the transportation and logistics vertical.

Mr. Aldric: "We closed 14 new enterprise logos in Q4, bringing our total customer count to 218. Net revenue retention is 119%."

He then discussed the composition of the customer base by segment. Of the 218 total customers, 82 were classified as enterprise (greater than $100K ACV), 94 as mid-market ($25K-$100K ACV), and 42 as emerging ($10K-$25K ACV). Mr. Aldric noted that the enterprise segment had grown from 68 customers at the start of Q4, representing a net addition of 14 new enterprise logos during the quarter.

Mr. Aldric reviewed the product roadmap milestones achieved in Q4. The recommendation engine v2.4 release shipped on schedule in October and had been adopted by 34% of the customer base by end of quarter. The supply chain analytics dashboard received a significant update in November with new predictive capabilities that had contributed to several competitive wins. The API gateway was upgraded in December to support higher throughput requirements from the largest customers.

Ms. Jiang asked about the company's competitive positioning in the mid-market segment, specifically against Palantir, which had been increasing its presence in deals under $500K ACV.

Ms. Jiang: "What is our win rate against Palantir in deals under $500K ACV?"

Mr. Aldric: "Approximately 62% in that segment, up from 54% in Q3."

Mr. Aldric elaborated that the win rate improvement was driven by the deployment of the recommendation engine v2 release in October, which had been well received by mid-market prospects during proof-of-concept evaluations. He provided examples of two competitive displacements in Q4 where the recommendation engine functionality was a deciding factor in the customer's vendor selection process. He noted that Palantir's pricing in the sub-$500K segment had become more aggressive in Q4, but that Nextera's product differentiation — specifically real-time supply chain visibility and the recommendation engine's ability to process multi-modal logistics data — continued to be the primary win driver.

Mr. Whitfield asked about gross margin trends and whether the competitive pricing pressure from Palantir had required any discounting that might affect margins. Ms. Vasquez responded that gross margin for Q4 was 78.3%, in line with the trailing four-quarter average of 78.1%. She noted that average selling price had remained stable and that the handful of deals where competitive discounting had been applied were offset by strong expansion pricing within the existing customer base. She noted that professional services revenue had been stable and that the gross margin reflected an increasing mix of subscription revenue relative to professional services.

Ms. Patel asked about customer churn in Q4. Mr. Aldric responded that gross revenue retention was 94% on a trailing twelve-month basis, with two small customer losses in Q4 totaling approximately $180K in ARR. Both losses were attributed to the customers' own business closures rather than competitive displacement or product dissatisfaction.

III. CFO REPORT — FINANCIAL POSITION

Ms. Vasquez presented the financial position of the company as of December 31, 2024. The presentation included audited balance sheet data, cash flow statements, and key financial metrics. The following highlights were reported:

Cash and Cash Equivalents: $28.4M
Short-term Investments: $0 (all cash held in operating and money market accounts)
Credit Facility: $15M revolving credit facility with Silicon Valley Bank, currently undrawn
Total Debt: None (the company has no term debt outstanding)
Accounts Receivable: $14.2M (Days Sales Outstanding: 42 days)
Accounts Payable: $4.8M
Deferred Revenue: $22.8M
Total Stockholders' Equity: $62.4M

Ms. Vasquez noted that the company's cash position remained strong and that the operating plan for FY2025 did not contemplate the need for additional equity or debt financing. She stated that at the current burn rate, the company had approximately 24 months of runway. She noted that the credit facility with Silicon Valley Bank was available as a backstop but that management did not anticipate drawing on it.

Q4 2024 ARR: $118.7M, up from $104.2M at Q4 2023, representing approximately 14% year-over-year growth. Ms. Vasquez walked through the quarterly cash flow statement, noting that Q4 free cash flow was approximately negative $1.0M, an improvement from negative $2.1M in Q3 and negative $3.4M in Q2. She attributed the improvement to operating leverage as revenue scaled while headcount growth was held to planned levels.

Ms. Vasquez presented a summary of working capital metrics. The company's current ratio was 2.8:1, reflecting a strong liquidity position. She noted that the deferred revenue balance of $22.8M was the highest in the company's history and reflected the shift toward annual and multi-year prepaid contracts in the enterprise segment.

Mr. Kessler asked about the interest rate on the revolving credit facility. Ms. Vasquez responded that the facility carried SOFR plus 175 basis points, with an annual commitment fee of 25 basis points on undrawn amounts. The facility was set to mature in June 2026 and management planned to renew on similar terms.

IV. 2025 OPERATING PLAN

Mr. Aldric presented the 2025 Operating Plan for Board approval. The presentation was 42 slides, covering financial targets, headcount plan, product roadmap, go-to-market strategy, infrastructure investments, and risk factors. A bound copy of the full operating plan document was distributed to each Board member.

Key elements of the 2025 Operating Plan:

Revenue Target: $142M ARR by December 31, 2025 (approximately 20% YoY growth)
Headcount: Increase from 402 to 465 FTEs
New Logo Target: 50+ enterprise customers
Gross Margin Target: 78-80%
EBITDA Target: Breakeven by Q4 2025
Total Operating Budget: $108.6M
Capital Expenditures: $12.6M

Mr. Aldric walked through the revenue build, starting from the $118.7M ARR base and adding planned new logo acquisition, expansion, and accounting for expected churn. He noted that the plan assumed a conservative churn rate of approximately 5% and that the $142M target required approximately $28M in net new ARR through a combination of new logos and expansion within the installed base.

The Board discussed the plan at length. Ms. Patel inquired about the assumptions underlying the headcount increase, specifically the split between revenue-generating roles and support functions. Mr. Aldric noted that approximately 40% of the net new hires would be in Engineering (approximately 25 positions), 30% in Sales (approximately 19 positions), and the remainder split across Customer Success, Product, and G&A functions.

Mr. Whitfield asked about the product roadmap's major bets for 2025. Mr. Aldric noted three key initiatives: the recommendation engine v3 general availability release (targeted for February 2025), the supply chain dashboard redesign (targeted for March), and a potential data partnership with Axion Labs that was in the evaluation phase. He emphasized that the roadmap was designed to strengthen the company's competitive position in the enterprise segment while expanding into adjacent use cases.

Mr. Kessler asked about the capital expenditure assumptions in the plan. Ms. Vasquez responded that the $12.6M capex budget was primarily allocated to infrastructure migration — the Kubernetes project — at approximately $5.8M, office expansion at $3.2M (15th floor buildout and furniture), and the remainder split across lab equipment, testing infrastructure, and miscellaneous IT capital.

Ms. Jiang asked about the competitive landscape assumptions in the plan. Mr. Aldric noted that the plan assumed continued pricing pressure from Palantir in the mid-market and potential new entrants in the supply chain intelligence space, but that Nextera's product differentiation and net revenue retention metrics provided a strong defensive moat.

Board unanimously approves 2025 operating plan with $142M revenue target.

RESOLVED: The Board approves the 2025 Operating Plan as presented, with authorized headcount increase from 402 to 465 FTEs.

Upon motion by Mr. Whitfield, seconded by Ms. Jiang, the resolution was adopted unanimously with all five Board members voting in favor. The Corporate Secretary recorded the vote.

V. GOVERNANCE MATTERS

Mr. Kessler motioned to ratify the appointment of two new independent auditors to supplement the existing Ernst & Young engagement for the FY2024 annual audit. The two additional auditors, Margaret Wu, CPA, and Samuel Greenbaum, CPA, were recommended by the Audit Committee following a review of their qualifications and independence. The Audit Committee had confirmed that neither Ms. Wu nor Mr. Greenbaum had any conflicts of interest or material relationships with the company.

Mr. Kessler noted that the additional auditors were brought on to support the expanded scope of the FY2024 audit, which included new revenue recognition procedures and the initial assessment of the company's internal controls in anticipation of potential future reporting requirements. He stated that the Audit Committee had thoroughly vetted both candidates and was satisfied with their qualifications.

Upon motion by Mr. Kessler, seconded by Ms. Patel, the Board unanimously ratified the appointments.

Ms. Fuentes presented the upcoming Board calendar for review:
  - February 10, 2025: Regular meeting (January financial review)
  - April 14, 2025: Regular meeting (Q1 2025 review)
  - June 9, 2025: Annual meeting of stockholders
  - July 14, 2025: Regular meeting (Q2 2025 review)
  - October 13, 2025: Regular meeting (Q3 2025 review)

The Board confirmed the calendar as presented. Mr. Kessler noted that the next Board meeting was scheduled for February 10, 2025, at which time the Board would receive the January financial update and a progress report on the 2025 Operating Plan.

VI. EXECUTIVE SESSION

At 10:45 AM, the Board entered executive session with only independent directors and the CEO present. The Corporate Secretary was excused from the executive session. The executive session lasted approximately 30 minutes. No formal actions were taken during the executive session.

VII. ADJOURNMENT

There being no further business, upon motion by Ms. Jiang, seconded by Mr. Whitfield, the meeting was adjourned at 11:16 AM Pacific Standard Time.

Respectfully submitted,

Maria Fuentes
Corporate Secretary
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

APPROVED: ___________________________
Robert Kessler, Board Chair
Date: _______________________________

Attachments:
  Exhibit A: Q4 2024 Performance Review Presentation (34 slides)
  Exhibit B: Financial Position Summary
  Exhibit C: 2025 Operating Plan (42 slides)
  Exhibit D: Auditor Independence Certifications

---

DOCUMENT TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: January 6, 2025
FROM: Priya Vasquez (CFO)
TO: Finance Team All
SUBJECT: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Finance

--- Original Message ---
From: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
To: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 11:32 AM PST
Subject: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Team,

Happy New Year. I hope everyone had a restful break.

With the board meeting behind us this morning, the 2025 Operating Plan is now officially approved. That means we need to move quickly on finalizing all departmental budgets and locking in our vendor renewal schedule for the year.

Here is where we are and what I need from each of you:

TOTAL FY2025 OPERATING BUDGET: $108.6M

Breakdown by department:
  R&D: $42.1M (38.8% of total operating budget)
  Sales & Marketing: $35.7M
  General & Administrative: $18.2M
  Capital Expenditures: $12.6M

Please ensure all department heads have signed off on their allocated budgets by January 15. No exceptions.

I've attached the departmental budget templates in the shared drive at Finance > FY2025 > Departmental Budgets. Each department head needs to review, approve, and sign the electronic form in DocuSign. Jordan has set up the routing — once a department head signs, it will automatically route to me for final approval.

Action Items:

1. Jordan — the vendor renewal schedule needs to reflect our standard 24-36 month commitment cycles. Let's lock that down before the board package goes out. I need the finalized vendor renewal schedule by January 17. We have 47 contracts up for renewal in FY2025, and I want to make sure we're capturing all early renewal discounts and avoiding any auto-renewal surprises. Please also flag any contracts where we have termination for convenience clauses that could give us leverage in renewal negotiations.

2. Angela — please verify the audit preparation timeline with Ernst & Young. I want to make sure we are aligned on their March window and that all Q4 revenue recognition is buttoned up. Also, please update the intercompany reconciliation for our UK subsidiary — it was flagged as an open item in the November close.

3. Derek — I need you to build the quarterly revenue waterfall model. This should show our path from $118.7M ARR to the $142M target, broken down by new logo, expansion, and churn. I'd like to review a first draft by January 13. Please pull the pipeline data from Salesforce and use last year's conversion rates as the starting assumption.

A few additional notes:

The R&D budget increase reflects the approved headcount plan. Marcus is planning to add 26 engineers in the first half, so we need to phase the hiring expense correctly in the waterfall. We should assume a 45-day ramp for new engineers before they're fully productive and billing to projects.

The S&M budget includes the expanded President's Club program that Kevin requested. I've allocated $200K for the trip plus an additional $150K in SPIFs for Q1 pipeline acceleration. Kevin's team is targeting 10 new enterprise logos in Q1 and the SPIFs are designed to accelerate proof-of-concept cycles.

G&A includes the additional office space we're leasing on the 15th floor. The lease terms are being finalized by Rachel's team. Expected occupancy is March 1. The buildout cost ($3.2M) is in the capex budget, and the annual lease expense ($680K) is in the G&A budget.

One more thing — I'd like to schedule our annual planning offsite for the Finance team. Last year we did Big Sur and it was great. Let's aim for the first week of February. Jordan, can you look into availability at Post Ranch Inn or Ventana? Budget is $3K per person for the two-night stay.

Let me know if you have questions. Let's have a quick sync tomorrow at 10 AM to walk through the open items.

Priya

--- Reply ---
From: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 12:14 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

Happy New Year to you too. Thanks for the recap.

I've already started pulling the vendor renewal data from the procurement system. I have 43 of the 47 contracts mapped to renewal dates — the remaining 4 are legacy agreements that don't have structured renewal terms in the system. I'll chase those down this week.

Quick question on the AWS renewal: we locked in the 3-year commitment last week at the 8% discount. Should I count that as done or do we need formal sign-off from the board given it exceeds the $4M threshold? The total commitment value is approximately $11.3M over 3 years.

On the offsite — Post Ranch has availability Feb 3-5. Ventana is fully booked that week but has Feb 10-12 open. Let me know your preference and I'll hold the rooms.

I'll have the full vendor renewal schedule ready by the 17th.

Jordan

--- Reply ---
From: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
To: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 12:28 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Jordan,

Good catch on the AWS threshold. The board pre-authorized all infrastructure commitments within the approved capex budget at this morning's meeting, so we're covered. Mark it as approved. Please file the board authorization reference (Resolution 2025-001) in the contract file.

For the 4 legacy contracts — if they're under $50K annual, let's just bring them into the standard renewal template at their next renewal date. If any are over $50K, flag them for me and I'll work with Rachel's team on structuring proper MSAs.

Let's go with Post Ranch Feb 3-5. Book it.

Priya

--- Reply ---
From: Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
To: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 1:45 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

I spoke with our E&Y partner, Samantha Reeves, this morning. They've confirmed the March 3-21 audit window. Their team will be on-site the first week (March 3-7) for walkthroughs and testing, then remote for the remainder.

I've verified that all Q4 revenue recognition is complete. We had two items that required judgment calls — a multi-year prepaid deal with TransGlobal Shipping and a usage-based component for FreshTrack Logistics. Both have been documented per ASC 606 and reviewed by Samantha's team in their pre-audit call last month. I have the memo files ready for the PBC list.

I'm preparing the PBC (Prepared by Client) list and will have it distributed to all department leads by January 20 with responses due February 14. The PBC includes 87 items this year, up from 72 last year due to the expanded scope Mr. Kessler mentioned.

The UK subsidiary intercompany recon is in progress — I expect to close it out by end of this week. The only open item is a $47K timing difference on a cross-border software license payment that straddled the quarter end. It's straightforward but needs documentation.

Angela

--- Reply ---
From: Derek Hollis <d.hollis@nextera.io>
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: finance-team-all@nextera.io
Date: Monday, January 6, 2025 at 2:30 PM PST
Subject: RE: FY2025 Budget Finalization — Action Items

Priya,

I'll have the revenue waterfall draft ready by the 13th. Quick initial cut: to get from $118.7M to $142M, we need roughly $28M in net new ARR, assuming approximately $5M in gross churn. That implies about $33M in gross new business (new logos plus expansion) offset by churn.

Based on Kevin's pipeline numbers and our historical conversion rates, I'm modeling:
  - New logo ARR: ~$19M (50+ logos at ~$380K blended ACV)
  - Expansion ARR: ~$14M (based on 119% NRR applied to expanding cohorts)
  - Gross churn: ~$5M (6% gross on the ~$80M expansion-eligible base)
  - Net new ARR: ~$28M

I'll layer in the quarterly phasing based on last year's seasonality patterns. Q1 is typically our softest quarter (approximately 18% of annual bookings), so I'll weight accordingly. Q4 is usually the strongest at about 32%, with Q2 and Q3 splitting the remainder roughly evenly.

I'm also building a sensitivity analysis showing the impact of plus or minus 5% on each variable. I'll include scenarios for faster-than-expected churn and slower-than-expected new logo acquisition so we have the board package ready for the February meeting.

One question: should I model the Axion Labs partnership impact separately? Hannah mentioned it in the product roadmap and it could drive incremental expansion revenue if it lands. I don't want to bake it into the base case but could show it as an upside scenario.

Derek

---

DOCUMENT TYPE: Slack Channel Excerpt
CHANNEL: #engineering-general
DATE: January 6, 2025
PARTICIPANTS: Multiple

[09:03 AM] marcus.webb
@channel Happy new year team! Sprint 1 kicks off today. We have 14 stories in the backlog, 340 story points. Let's ship :rocket:

[09:04 AM] marcus.webb
Quick housekeeping: please make sure all your PRs from the holiday freeze are rebased and CI is green before you start pulling new work. We had 23 open pull requests as of this morning — let's get that number down by EOD. Anything that's been open since before the holiday freeze needs to be either merged or closed today.

[09:06 AM] lisa.chen
Morning everyone! Sharing platform team OKRs for Q1:

OKR 1: Complete migration to Kubernetes 1.29 for all production workloads (KR: 100% of services running on K8s by March 31)
OKR 2: Reduce p99 latency to <300ms under peak load (KR: measured via Datadog synthetics)
OKR 3: Achieve 99.99% uptime for core API endpoints (KR: calculated excluding planned maintenance windows)

If your team depends on the platform team for anything in Q1, please reach out to me by EOW so I can plan capacity accordingly. I have 18 engineers on the platform team and capacity is tight given the migration timeline.

[09:08 AM] raj.patel
@lisa.chen quick q — does the K8s 1.29 migration affect the rec engine v3 deployment? We're tracking for Feb 14 GA and I want to make sure we're not stepping on each other.

[09:10 AM] lisa.chen
@raj.patel Good question. We're planning production migration for Feb 3-7. Your Feb 14 release should be fine — you'd be deploying onto the new K8s cluster. Let's sync this week to make sure your Helm charts are compatible with 1.29. Minor changes expected — mostly around resource limit syntax and the new pod disruption budget API.

[09:12 AM] raj.patel
rec engine v3 GA is tracking for Feb 14 release. We're at 94% test coverage, just need to close out the edge cases on sparse matrix handling — @raj.patel

Specifically, we have 6 remaining test scenarios for the sparse matrix decomposition path. Four of them are around handling matrices with >95% sparsity, and two are edge cases with non-standard dimension ratios. I've assigned them to the team for this sprint.

[09:14 AM] sami.okoro
New on-call rotation posted. Please swap directly with teammates if you have conflicts. No need to loop me in unless it's more than 2 days.

Link: [On-Call Rotation Q1 2025](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/oncall-q1-2025)

[09:15 AM] sami.okoro
Also — reminder that on-call handoff is now at 10 AM Pacific instead of 9 AM. We made this change based on the retro feedback last quarter where the London team was getting paged at 5 AM their time during the overlap period. Please update your PagerDuty schedules accordingly.

[09:17 AM] diana.xu
Is anyone else seeing flaky tests in the supply-chain-analytics module? I've had 3 tests fail intermittently this morning that were green on Friday. All three are in the test_logistics_aggregation suite.

[09:18 AM] raj.patel
@diana.xu Which tests? The ones that hit the external logistics API mock sometimes time out if the mock server hasn't warmed up. Try adding a 2s sleep before the assertion. I know it's ugly but it's a known issue — there's a ticket for it (ENG-4891).

[09:20 AM] diana.xu
@raj.patel Yep, that's exactly it. tests 47, 52, and 61 in the aggregation suite. Thanks Raj. I'll add the workaround and reference the ticket. Is anyone actively working on ENG-4891 or should I pick it up?

[09:21 AM] raj.patel
@diana.xu Nobody's assigned. If you have bandwidth this sprint, go for it. The fix is probably to use a readiness probe on the mock server instead of the sleep hack. Should be about 2 story points.

[09:22 AM] marcus.webb
Team metrics for reference:
- Engineering headcount: 142 (of 402 total company)
- Sprint 1 duration: Jan 6 - Jan 17 (2 weeks)
- Open pull requests: 23
- CI/CD pipeline pass rate last quarter: 97.2%
- Target CI pass rate this quarter: 98.5%
- Kubernetes migration target: complete by end of Q1

Remember: if CI is red for more than 30 minutes, the responsible engineer should revert or fix. No exceptions. Let's keep the pipeline green.

[09:25 AM] lisa.chen
One more thing — I'll be sending weekly migration status updates every Monday starting next week. If your service is on the migration list and you haven't reviewed the compatibility checklist, please do that this week. Link: [K8s 1.29 Compatibility Checklist](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/k8s-compat-129)

We have 47 microservices to migrate, and I've grouped them into three waves:
- Wave 1 (Jan 13-17): 12 stateless API services
- Wave 2 (Jan 27-31): 18 worker/queue services
- Wave 3 (Feb 3-7): 17 stateful services (databases, caches, rec engine)

Please check which wave your service falls into and make sure your team has reviewed the compatibility checklist before your wave starts.

[09:27 AM] tommy.nakamura
@marcus.webb quick process question — for sprint 1, are we doing daily standups at 9:15 or 9:30? The calendar invite says 9:15 but the wiki says 9:30.

[09:28 AM] marcus.webb
@tommy.nakamura Good catch, it's 9:15 AM. I'll fix the wiki. We moved it up last quarter so it doesn't conflict with the West Coast product sync at 10.

[09:30 AM] elena.kowalski
Morning all! Just a heads up from the QA side — we're rolling out a new automated regression suite for the analytics pipeline this sprint. It adds about 450 new test cases. Expect the CI run time to increase by about 8 minutes until we optimize the parallel execution. I'll send details to #engineering-ci later today.

[09:32 AM] sami.okoro
@elena.kowalski 8 minutes is a lot — is there a way to run those in a separate pipeline stage so they don't block the critical path? Our current CI takes about 12 minutes and adding 8 would put us at 20, which is way above our target.

[09:33 AM] elena.kowalski
@sami.okoro Working on it! The plan is to run them in a parallel pipeline by sprint 2. For this sprint we'll run them serial to validate coverage before we optimize. Once we have confidence in the test stability, we can shard them across 4 runners and get back under 15 minutes total.

[09:35 AM] marcus.webb
Sounds good, Elena. Let's prioritize that optimization in sprint 2. Our target is to keep CI under 15 minutes end to end. I don't want us regressing on developer experience.

[09:37 AM] raj.patel
FYI — I'm going to be running some load tests on the rec engine v3 staging instance this afternoon between 2-5 PM Pacific. If you see elevated traffic in Datadog for the staging cluster, that's me. No action needed. I'll be ramping up to about 10x normal traffic to stress test the new sparse matrix paths.

[09:38 AM] lisa.chen
@raj.patel Roger that. I'll set up a Datadog annotation so the on-call doesn't page on it. Can you also drop a note in #engineering-incidents when you start and stop? Just so there's a record.

[09:39 AM] raj.patel
@lisa.chen Will do :thumbsup:

[09:42 AM] chris.malone
PSA: the new code review guidelines are live in Confluence. Key changes from last quarter: (1) all PRs need at least 2 approvals for production services, (2) security-tagged PRs need a review from someone on Frank's security team, (3) we're now using conventional commit messages. See ENG-POLICY-2025-01 for details.

[09:44 AM] sami.okoro
@chris.malone Thanks for the reminder. Team — please read the new guidelines before you submit your first PR this sprint. The conventional commit message format is required starting today.

---

DOCUMENT TYPE: HR Policy Bulletin
DATE: January 6, 2025
FROM: Vanessa Kline, VP People
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: 2025 Benefits Open Enrollment Reminder
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: HR-2025-001

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — HUMAN RESOURCES
2025 BENEFITS OPEN ENROLLMENT — FINAL REMINDER

Dear Nextera Team,

This is your final reminder: open enrollment closes January 20. If you do not make a selection, you will be auto-enrolled in the same plan as 2024.

Please take a few minutes to review your benefits selections and make any changes by the January 20 deadline. Below is a comprehensive summary of our 2025 benefits offerings.

MEDICAL INSURANCE (Provider: Aetna)

Nextera offers three medical plan tiers for 2025:

  Bronze Plan: $180/month employee contribution
    - $3,500 individual deductible / $7,000 family deductible
    - 80/20 coinsurance after deductible
    - $8,000 individual out-of-pocket maximum
    - Includes preventive care at 100% with no copay
    - Network: Aetna Choice POS II
    - In-network urgent care copay: $75
    - Emergency room copay: $350 (waived if admitted)

  Silver Plan: $320/month employee contribution
    - $1,500 individual deductible / $3,000 family deductible
    - 90/10 coinsurance after deductible
    - $5,000 individual out-of-pocket maximum
    - $25 copay for primary care visits
    - $50 copay for specialist visits
    - Network: Aetna Choice POS II
    - In-network urgent care copay: $50
    - Emergency room copay: $250 (waived if admitted)

  Gold Plan: $510/month employee contribution
    - $500 individual deductible / $1,000 family deductible
    - 100% coverage after deductible
    - $2,500 individual out-of-pocket maximum
    - $15 copay for primary care visits
    - $30 copay for specialist visits
    - Network: Aetna Choice POS II
    - In-network urgent care copay: $25
    - Emergency room copay: $150 (waived if admitted)

DOCUMENT TYPE: All-Hands Meeting Transcript
DATE: January 9, 2025
PRESENTER: David Aldric (CEO)
ATTENDEES: All Employees
SUBJECT: January All-Hands Meeting
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: AH-2025-001

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — JANUARY ALL-HANDS MEETING
Transcript prepared by Office of the CEO

Location: Main Auditorium, 14th Floor, Nextera HQ, San Francisco
In-Person Attendees: 340
Remote Attendees: 62 (via Zoom)
Meeting Duration: 55 minutes
Recording: Available on Nextera Stream (internal) for 30 days

---

[DAVID ALDRIC, CEO — OPENING REMARKS]

Good morning, everyone. Happy New Year. I hope you all had a wonderful holiday break and are ready to hit the ground running in 2025.

I want to start by thanking every single person in this room — and on the Zoom — for an outstanding 2024. We finished the year strong, and I couldn't be more proud of what this team has accomplished.

Let me give you the highlight reel. Q4 was our best quarter in the company's history. Revenue came in at $31.2 million, beating our target by over two percent. For the full year, we exited at $118.7 million in annual recurring revenue. That is 14 percent year-over-year growth, and it puts us in a very strong position heading into 2025.

We are building this company for the long haul. Nextera is not a flash in the pan — we are building a generational company in supply chain intelligence.

That's not just a tagline. That's our north star. Every hire we make, every feature we ship, every customer we serve — it's all in service of building something that lasts. I think that's what separates us from the noise in this market. We have a clear vision, a strong balance sheet, and a team that knows how to execute. That's a rare combination in enterprise software, and I don't take it for granted.

Before I hand it over to the team, I want to share one more thing. The board met on Monday and unanimously approved our 2025 operating plan. The revenue target is $142 million in ARR by year-end. That's approximately 20 percent growth over our current run rate. It's ambitious, absolutely, but this team has shown me time and again that ambitious is exactly where we perform best.

Now let me walk you through the key highlights from each team, and then we'll have plenty of time for questions.

[PRIYA VASQUEZ, CFO — FINANCIAL HIGHLIGHTS]

Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone.

I'm going to keep this brief and high-level. The detailed numbers are in the slides that will be posted to #all-hands-slides after the meeting, but here are the headlines.

Full year 2024 revenue grew 14% year over year. We exited December at $118.7 million ARR, which means we added approximately $14.5 million in net new ARR during the year. Our gross margin held steady at 78.3%, which is in line with our target range of 78 to 80 percent. I want to call that out specifically because there has been some competitive pressure in the mid-market on pricing, and the fact that we maintained margin discipline while scaling at this rate is a testament to the value proposition of our product and the discipline of our sales organization.

Cash position is strong. We ended the year with $28.4 million in cash, and we have an undrawn $15 million credit facility with Silicon Valley Bank. At our current burn rate, we have roughly two years of runway. The 2025 plan does not require any additional financing. I want to be very clear about that — we do not need to raise money. We are well-capitalized and our path to profitability is visible in the operating plan.

The board approved our 2025 operating plan on Monday. The revenue target is $142 million — that's approximately 20% growth over our current run rate. It's ambitious but achievable based on our pipeline and the investments we're making in product and go-to-market.

We're also expanding headcount from 402 to 465 by year end. That's 63 net new positions across the company. More on that from Vanessa in a moment.

On the balance sheet, I'd note that our accounts receivable position is $14.2 million with DSO of 42 days, which is within our target of 45 days. Deferred revenue is $22.8 million, the highest in company history, reflecting our shift toward annual and multi-year prepaid contracts in the enterprise segment. That deferred revenue number is important — it represents contracted revenue that is already committed and will be recognized over the coming quarters. It gives us a solid foundation heading into 2025.

EBITDA for December came in at negative $1.0 million, which is a significant improvement from negative $1.8 million in September. The trajectory is clear and we expect to reach EBITDA breakeven by Q4 of this year.

Any questions on the financials before I hand it back?

[Pause — no questions from the floor]

[MARCUS WEBB, VP ENGINEERING — PRODUCT & ENGINEERING UPDATE]

Thanks, Priya. Hey everyone.

I've got two things to share with you today, and I'm going to demo one of them.

First, the Kubernetes 1.29 migration. Lisa Chen and the platform team completed Phase 1 — staging — over the holiday break. Staging is running clean, no issues. We're planning the production migration for the first week of February, with a scheduled maintenance window on February 5 from 2 AM to 6 AM Pacific. More details will come from Lisa's team, but I wanted to give you a heads up that there will be a brief maintenance period. The engineering team has rehearsed the migration three times in staging and we're confident in the rollback procedures should anything go sideways.

Second — and this is the fun part — I want to show you what the recommendation engine v3 looks like.

[Webb shares screen, demos recommendation engine v3 beta interface. The demo shows a supply chain scenario where the engine identifies optimal routing alternatives during a simulated port disruption. The audience reacts with applause at the speed of the recommendations — sub-200ms response times on a dataset of 2 million shipment records.]

Thank you. That's the beta. We're at 94% test coverage and tracking for GA release on February 14. Raj Patel and his team have done an incredible job on this. The performance improvements over v2 are substantial — we're seeing 3x faster inference times and the model handles sparse data matrices much more gracefully. The edge case handling that Raj's team has been focused on for the last two months is really paying off. The v3 engine processes 2 million records in under 200 milliseconds, and it handles the sparse matrix scenarios that tripped up v2 without any degradation.

I also want to give a shout-out to the entire engineering team for our CI/CD pipeline pass rate last quarter: 97.2%. That's the highest in the company's history. Our target for this quarter is 98.5%. I know that sounds like a small number, but when you're running thousands of builds per week, that fraction of a percent matters. It means fewer broken builds, less time wasted on investigations, and faster time to ship.

Our engineering headcount stands at 142 out of 402 total employees. We have plans to add approximately 25 engineering positions this year, and I'll be working with Vanessa's team on the hiring timeline. Our sprint cadence is two weeks, and we kicked off Q1 Sprint 1 on Monday with 14 stories totaling 340 story points.

[Applause]

[KEVIN OROSCO, VP SALES — GO-TO-MARKET UPDATE]

Thanks, Marcus. Good morning, team.

I am very excited about where we sit heading into 2025. We closed Q4 with 14 new enterprise logos, and I want to call out three wins that I think really demonstrate the momentum we have in the market.

We won Maersk, DB Schenker, and Kuehne+Nagel. Three of the largest logistics companies in the world. Each of these deals was competitive — we went head-to-head against the incumbents and won on product. That is a testament to the work this entire company does, from Engineering to Customer Success to Marketing.

These are not small deals. These are marquee logos that will open doors to other enterprises in the transportation and logistics vertical. Our win rate against Palantir in the mid-market is now 62%, up from 54% last quarter. The product is speaking for itself.

For 2025, we have a target of 50 new enterprise logos and a pipeline that gives me confidence we'll get there. Q1 pipeline is at $18.4 million across 34 active enterprise opportunities, and we're building fast. We've also got 10 new sales reps joining in Q1 to support the growth. Currently, our sales headcount is 48, and we expect to hit 58 by end of Q1.

Let me give you a quick look at the numbers behind the wins. Average enterprise deal size is $185K ACV, and mid-market is $62K ACV. Our overall win rate is 31%, but importantly, when we get to the proof-of-concept stage, our win rate jumps to 41%. The sales cycle averages 78 days. The takeaway here is that when prospects actually see the product in action, we win far more often than we lose. Marcus, Raj, and the engineering team deserve a lot of credit for that.

More to share at the sales kickoff next week, but I wanted to give everyone a taste of the momentum.

[VANESSA KLINE, VP PEOPLE — PEOPLE UPDATE]

Thanks, Kevin. Good morning, everyone.

A couple of things from the People team.

First, we have 38 open positions across all departments. If you know great people, please refer them. Our referral bonus is $5,000 for engineering roles and $3,000 for all other roles, paid out after the new hire's 90-day mark.

We're hiring in Engineering, Sales, Customer Success, Product, Finance, and Legal. The full list is on our careers page and in the #open-roles Slack channel. I want to emphasize that we are prioritizing speed and quality in this hiring cycle. Our time-to-fill last year averaged 34 days, and I'd like to get that down to 30 for 2025. Our offer acceptance rate is 88%, which is strong, but there's always room to improve.

Second, I want to remind everyone that benefits open enrollment closes on January 20. If you haven't made your selections yet, please do so this week. We've increased the 401(k) match to 5%, which is a meaningful increase, and we've added a new dental plan through Delta Dental. The three medical plan tiers remain: Bronze at $180 per month, Silver at $320, and Gold at $510. If you have questions about the plans, the Benefits Team has office hours every day this week from 12 to 1 PM in conference room 14-C.

Third, we welcomed our first cohort of 2025 new hires this week — 12 new teammates joining across the company. Please make them feel welcome. If you've been assigned as a buddy, reach out to your new hire by end of day today. That cohort includes 6 engineers, 3 sales reps, 2 customer success team members, and 1 finance hire. Orientation runs through January 17.

A final note: our new-hire 90-day retention rate is 96%, which is a number I'm very proud of. It speaks to the quality of our hiring process and the onboarding experience this company provides. Let's keep that number up.

That's it from me. Back to you, David.

[DAVID ALDRIC — Q&A SESSION]

Thank you, Vanessa. Now let's open it up for questions. We have about 25 minutes.

[Q&A — 25 MINUTES]

Q from floor (employee, engineering): "Are we thinking about an IPO timeline?"

Aldric: "We have the luxury of being well-capitalized. An IPO is not on our near-term radar. We're focused on getting to $200M ARR before we even think about that."

I want to be crystal clear: we are independent, we intend to stay independent, and every decision we make is about building long-term value for our employees and our customers. There are no conversations happening about selling the company, going public in the near term, or anything else along those lines. Our job is to build. That's what we do.

Q from floor (employee, sales): "What's the timeline for the new sales playbooks? We're hearing a lot about Kinaxis in the mid-market and could use updated competitive positioning."

Orosco: "Good question. Product marketing is updating the competitive battle cards right now. I expect the new versions to be out by end of January. In the meantime, if you're in a competitive deal against Kinaxis, reach out to Diana Marsh — she's running point on competitive intelligence."

Q from floor (employee, customer success): "Can we get more resources for the implementation team? We're three weeks behind on the Freight Corp deployment and it's stretching the team thin."

Aldric: "Amanda, do you want to take that?"

Amanda Briggs (VP Customer Success, from floor): "Yes, we're aware of the Freight Corp situation. Their IT team has been slow on the API integration, which has pushed our timeline. We're adding a dedicated implementation engineer to that account this week. More broadly, we've budgeted for 6 new hires in Customer Success in Q1 — two of those are implementation engineers. We should be in much better shape by end of February."

Q from Zoom (employee, remote — Portland office): "When are we getting the Portland office upgrade? The conference rooms don't have reliable video equipment and it makes remote meetings really painful."

Aldric: "Great question. Vanessa, do you have an update?"

Kline: "Yes — we've approved the Portland office AV upgrade. The equipment has been ordered and we expect installation the first week of February. New Poly cameras, microphones, and displays in all four conference rooms. We've also added a booking system so you can reserve rooms from the Nextera app."

Q from floor (employee, engineering): "Is there any update on the remote work policy? Are we still doing three days in office?"

Kline: "The policy hasn't changed. It's three days in office — Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday — with Monday and Friday as optional remote days. We're seeing about 74% office occupancy on the in-office days, which is right where we want it. If you have an individual accommodation request, please talk to your manager or reach out to me directly."

Q from floor (employee, product): "Marcus mentioned the Kubernetes migration has a maintenance window on February 5. How long will the platform be down?"

Webb: "Good question. We're planning for a four-hour maintenance window, from 2 AM to 6 AM Pacific. Customer-facing APIs will be unavailable during that period. We'll notify affected customers at least two weeks in advance through the status page and direct email. The engineering team has rehearsed the migration three times in staging and we're confident in the timing. We also have a rollback plan that can restore service within 30 minutes if we hit any issues."

Q from floor (employee, finance): "Priya, can you talk about the capex budget for 2025? $12.6 million seems like a significant investment."

Vasquez: "Sure. The $12.6 million in capex is primarily driven by three things. First, the Kubernetes migration and infrastructure modernization — that's approximately $4.5 million in new infrastructure costs, though we expect it to generate a 60% cost reduction in ongoing cloud spend. Second, office buildout and equipment for the 63 new hires — that's about $3.8 million including hardware, furniture, and buildout costs for expanding the Portland and San Francisco offices. Third, the remainder is allocated to software tooling, security infrastructure, and R&D equipment. The return on the infrastructure investment alone should pay for itself within 18 months."

[DAVID ALDRIC — CLOSING REMARKS]

Great questions, everyone. Thank you.

I'll close with this: 2025 is going to be a big year for Nextera. We have the product, the team, the customers, and the capital to make it happen. I've been doing this for a while, and I can tell you — the alignment between product-market fit, team capability, and financial strength that we have right now is something special. Not every company gets this moment. We have it, and we are not going to waste it.

Let's go build something great.

Next all-hands is scheduled for February 6. Have a great rest of your week.

[Meeting adjourned at 10:55 AM]

Post-meeting survey distributed via Culture Amp. Employee NPS from the post-meeting survey: 72.
Slides posted to #all-hands-slides channel.

TO: Engineering All
SUBJECT: Platform Migration Update — Kubernetes 1.29
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Engineering
REFERENCE: ENG-2025-MIG-002

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — ENGINEERING
Platform Migration Update: Kubernetes 1.29

To: All Engineering
From: Marcus Webb, VP Engineering
Date: January 9, 2025

Team,

I'm writing to give you a comprehensive update on our Kubernetes 1.29 migration project, which is a key initiative for Q1 2025.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Phase 1 is done. Staging is running clean on K8s 1.29. Lisa's team will begin production migration February 3. Plan for a 4-hour maintenance window on February 5.

PHASE 1 COMPLETION — STAGING ENVIRONMENT

Lisa Chen and the platform team completed the staging environment migration over the holiday break. The staging cluster is now fully running on Kubernetes 1.29 on our AWS EKS infrastructure. Key results from the staging migration:

  - All 47 microservices migrated successfully
  - Zero downtime during the migration process
  - All automated tests passing (integration, load, and smoke tests)
  - Datadog monitoring dashboards have been updated to reflect the new architecture
  - No rollback was required at any point during the migration

Load test results are particularly encouraging. Lisa's team has been running load tests at 2x peak traffic levels on the staging environment over the past week.

Load test results: p99 latency at 2x traffic is 340ms, well within our 500ms SLA.

Detailed load test metrics:
  - Concurrent connections tested: 15,000
  - Sustained throughput: 8,400 requests/second
  - p50 latency: 45ms
  - p95 latency: 190ms
  - p99 latency: 340ms
  - Error rate: 0.003%
  - Test duration: 4 hours continuous
  - CPU utilization at peak: 72%
  - Memory utilization at peak: 64%

The full load test report is available in Confluence: [K8s 1.29 Load Test Results](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/k8s-129-loadtest)

CURRENT INFRASTRUCTURE

For context, here's what our current production infrastructure looks like:

  - 94 EC2 instances across 3 AWS regions (us-west-2, us-east-1, eu-west-1)
  - 47 microservices
  - Primary region: us-west-2 (Portland, OR) — hosts 52 instances
  - Secondary region: us-east-1 (N. Virginia) — hosts 28 instances
  - DR region: eu-west-1 (Ireland) — hosts 14 instances
  - Total monthly infrastructure cost: approximately $185K/month
  - Target: 60% cost reduction through containerization (to approximately $74K/month)

The cost savings from containerization are significant. At $185K/month, we're spending $2.22M annually on infrastructure. A 60% reduction would save approximately $1.33M per year. This is one of the highest-ROI projects in the engineering portfolio.

PRODUCTION MIGRATION PLAN

Production migration is scheduled for February 3-7, with the following timeline:

  February 3 (Monday): Begin migration of stateless API services
    - Services affected: 12 API gateway services, 8 authentication services
    - Expected duration: 8 hours
    - Zero-downtime deployment using blue-green strategy

  February 4 (Tuesday): Migrate worker and queue services
    - Services affected: 15 background workers, 4 queue processors
    - Expected duration: 6 hours
    - Queue draining will be coordinated with on-call team

  February 5 (Wednesday): Main migration window — stateful services, databases, caches
    - Maintenance window: 2:00 AM - 6:00 AM Pacific
    - Customer-facing APIs unavailable during this period
    - Database migration includes PostgreSQL failover and Redis cluster reconfiguration
    - This is the highest-risk portion of the migration

  February 6 (Thursday): Post-migration validation and monitoring
    - Full regression test suite execution
    - Performance baseline comparison
    - Customer-facing monitoring verification

  February 7 (Friday): Final verification and migration sign-off
    - Sign-off from: Marcus Webb, Lisa Chen, Frank Gutierrez (security)
    - Migration declared complete or rollback initiated

ROLLBACK PLAN

We have a comprehensive rollback plan documented in Confluence: ENG-2025-MIG-001. Key elements:

  - Pre-migration snapshots of all production databases
  - DNS failover to legacy infrastructure within 15 minutes
  - Automated rollback scripts tested in staging (3 full rehearsals completed)
  - Rollback decision authority: Marcus Webb (primary), Lisa Chen (backup)
  - Maximum acceptable rollback time: 30 minutes
  - Rollback decision criteria: (1) customer-facing error rate exceeds 1%, or (2) p99 latency exceeds 1000ms for more than 10 minutes, or (3) data integrity check fails

DR MIGRATION (PHASE 3)

The disaster recovery environment migration is planned for March, after production migration is validated. We'll share more details on the DR migration timeline in February. The DR environment in eu-west-1 currently hosts 14 instances and serves as our cross-region failover. The migration approach will mirror the production migration with a separate maintenance window.

WHAT YOU NEED TO DO

1. Review the K8s 1.29 Compatibility Checklist for your services: [Link](https://wiki.nextera.io/eng/k8s-compat-129)
2. Update your Helm charts if your service uses deprecated API versions (check the deprecation list in Confluence)
3. Verify your service's resource limits and requests are correctly configured — K8s 1.29 has tighter enforcement on resource quotas
4. Review the updated Datadog dashboards for your service: [Link](https://app.datadoghq.com/dashboard/nextera-k8s-129)
5. If your service is in the February 5 maintenance window (stateful services), coordinate with Lisa Chen's team by January 24
6. Update your runbooks to reflect the new Kubernetes commands and dashboard locations
7. Attend the migration readiness review on January 27 at 10 AM in the large conference room (or join via Zoom)

QUESTIONS?

Please direct questions to #platform-migration Slack channel or reach out to Lisa Chen directly. We'll also be holding office hours every Wednesday at 2 PM through the migration period.

Marcus Webb
VP Engineering
Nextera Solutions

From: Rachel Dominguez <r.dominguez@nextera.io>
Date: January 12, 2025, 8:14 AM PST
To: Nathan Foley <n.foley@nextera.io>; Iris Chang <i.chang@nextera.io>; Legal-All@nextera.io
Subject: Q1 Legal Department Priorities

Team,

Happy New Year and welcome back from the holiday break. I want to lay out our Q1 priorities clearly so everyone can plan their workload for the next twelve weeks. We have a full plate and I want to make sure nothing slips.

Our department headcount stands at 8, which means we need to be disciplined about how we allocate time. I've organized priorities by assignee below.

NATHAN FOLEY — CORPORATE GOVERNANCE

Nathan, your primary Q1 deliverable is the annual corporate governance review. This is a comprehensive review of all governance documents including the Certificate of Incorporation, bylaws, committee charters, board meeting procedures, delegation of authority matrix, insider trading policy, and related party transaction procedures. The review needs to be completed by February 1 so that any recommended amendments can be presented at the February board meeting.

Specific items for the governance review:
- Confirm all committee charters reflect current board composition
- Review delegation of authority matrix against current organizational structure (we've added several VP-level positions since the last update)
- Verify insider trading policy window periods are current for the upcoming quarterly close calendar
- Review the related party transaction policy threshold levels ($25K disclosure, $100K board notification, $250K board approval)
- Ensure corporate minute books are current through Q4 2024

Q1 priorities are straightforward: Nathan, finish the governance review by February 1. Iris, the patent filings need to be submitted before the March 15 deadline.

IRIS CHANG — INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY

Iris, you have three new patent applications to file this quarter covering the recommendation engine IP. The inventions were disclosed by the engineering team in Q4 and the provisional applications need to be on file before the March 15 deadline imposed by the one-year grace period from the initial public disclosure at our customer conference last March.

Patent Application 1: "System and Method for Multi-Modal Logistics Data Fusion in Real-Time Supply Chain Recommendation Engines" — Inventors: Marcus Webb, Raj Patel, Lisa Chen. This covers the core data fusion architecture of the recommendation engine v3.

Patent Application 2: "Adaptive Sparse Matrix Processing for Supply Chain Network Optimization" — Inventors: Raj Patel, Sami Okoro. This covers the novel sparse matrix handling approach that was the subject of Raj's technical blog post in October.

Patent Application 3: "Dynamic Shipping Lane Optimization Through Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks" — Inventors: Lisa Chen, Marcus Webb. This covers the graph neural network approach to shipping lane optimization that was presented at the NeurIPS workshop in December.

Our current patent portfolio stands at 14 granted patents and 6 pending applications. These three new filings will bring our pending count to 9. The patent portfolio is a significant competitive asset and we need to continue building it aggressively.

Outside patent counsel at Morrison & Foerster has been briefed on all three applications. They will handle the drafting; your role is to coordinate with the inventors, review the claims for accuracy, and manage the filing timeline. Please set up inventor interviews by January 20.

COMPLIANCE TRAINING

Compliance training for people managers is mandatory this quarter. Please block two hours on your calendar between January 20 and February 7.

The training covers updated topics including:
- California Pay Transparency Act compliance (SB 1162 updates)
- Updated harassment prevention procedures
- Data privacy obligations under CCPA amendments
- Export control refresher (EAR/ITAR awareness for the engineering team working with international shipping data)
- Contract signing authority and delegation procedures

Training will be conducted in three sessions to accommodate scheduling. I'll send calendar invitations this week with the session options. All people managers must complete the training by February 7 — no exceptions. We will report completion rates to the board as part of our Q1 governance update.

OTHER ITEMS

Active litigation: We have one active matter — the trademark dispute with NextEra Energy, Inc. (the utility company). This is a minor matter involving our corporate name and their registered trademark. Our outside counsel at Sherman & Sterling believes we have a strong position given the different industries and markets served, and expects this to be resolved through a coexistence agreement rather than litigation. Status update expected in February.

Q4 contract review volume: The legal department reviewed 127 contracts in Q4 2024. This is consistent with our trailing quarterly average of 115-130 reviews. The breakdown was: customer agreements (82), vendor contracts (28), employment-related agreements (12), and miscellaneous (5). Average turnaround time was 3.2 business days, within our 5-business-day SLA.

Outside counsel spend in Q4: $340K total. The largest component was the Sherman & Sterling retainer for M&A advisory services at $180K per quarter (this is our standard corporate retainer — they are on call for general M&A advisory matters as needed). The remainder was split between Morrison & Foerster for IP work ($95K) and Cooley for employment law matters ($65K).

The outside counsel budget for Q1 2025 is $400K, reflecting an expected increase in patent filing activity and the anticipated resolution of the NextEra Energy trademark matter.

Please reach out to me directly if you have questions about your assignments or need to reprioritize anything. I want weekly status updates starting January 20 — brief email updates by end of day each Monday are sufficient.

Rachel

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
DECEMBER 2024 MONTHLY FINANCIAL SUMMARY
Period Ending: December 31, 2024
Report Date: January 12, 2025
Prepared By: Jordan Michaels, VP Finance
Reviewed By: Angela Torres, Controller

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

December closed strong. Bookings came in at $4.1M against $3.8M forecast. ARR exits the year at $118.7M.

This report presents the December 2024 monthly financial results and year-end summary for Nextera Solutions, Inc. All figures are unaudited and subject to final year-end adjustments pending completion of the FY2024 audit by Ernst & Young. Angela Torres has verified that all revenue recognition is complete for Q4 2024 in accordance with ASC 606 guidelines.

I. REVENUE AND BOOKINGS

                                December     November     October      Q4 Total      FY2024
Revenue                         $10.1M       $10.4M       $10.7M      $31.2M        $112.8M
New Bookings                    $4.1M        $3.4M        $3.8M       $11.3M        $38.4M
Expansion Revenue               $1.8M        $1.6M        $1.9M       $5.3M         $18.2M
Churn                           $0.1M        $0.0M        $0.0M       $0.1M         $2.4M

December revenue came in at $10.1M, slightly below November due to fewer business days (December had two fewer billing days due to the holiday period). Revenue was within 1% of the internal forecast of $10.2M. The variance is attributable to two mid-market deals that closed on December 30 and 31 and whose initial invoicing will fall into January.

New bookings of $4.1M exceeded the December forecast of $3.8M by approximately 8%. The outperformance was driven by the acceleration of three enterprise deals from the January pipeline, including a $340K deal with a major European logistics provider that was originally expected to close in the first week of January.

December bookings came in at $4.1M against $3.8M forecast. ARR exits the year at $118.7M.

Year-end ARR stands at $118.7M, representing approximately 14% year-over-year growth from $104.2M at the end of FY2023. The company added approximately $14.5M in net new ARR during the year after accounting for churn.

II. COST OF GOODS SOLD AND GROSS MARGIN

                                December     Q4 Avg       FY2024 Avg
Revenue                         $10.1M       $10.4M       $9.4M
COGS                            $2.2M        $2.3M        $2.1M
Gross Profit                    $7.9M        $8.1M        $7.3M
Gross Margin                    78.2%        77.9%        77.7%

December gross profit was $7.9M, representing a gross margin of 78.2%. This is consistent with the Q4 average of 77.9% and a slight improvement over the FY2024 average of 77.7%. The margin improvement is attributable to the increasing proportion of subscription revenue (now 89% of total revenue) versus professional services (11%).

COGS components for December:
- Cloud infrastructure (AWS): $1.28M
- Data providers: $0.34M
- Professional services direct costs: $0.22M
- Support team costs: $0.18M
- Other COGS: $0.18M

III. OPERATING EXPENSES

                                December     November     October      Q4 Total      FY2024
R&D                             $3.6M        $3.5M        $3.4M       $10.5M        $38.7M
Sales & Marketing               $2.8M        $2.9M        $2.8M       $8.5M         $31.2M
General & Administrative         $1.5M        $1.5M        $1.4M       $4.4M         $16.8M
Total Operating Expenses         $8.9M        $8.9M        $8.6M       $26.4M        $94.2M

Total operating expenses for December were $8.9M, consistent with November and within the monthly budget of $9.1M. The slight underspend relative to budget was driven by delayed hiring in the engineering department (two positions pushed to January) and lower-than-expected travel expenses.

R&D expense of $3.6M includes the costs of the 142-person engineering team, plus allocated infrastructure costs for development and staging environments. The year-over-year increase in R&D expense reflects the addition of 18 net new engineering hires during FY2024.

IV. EBITDA AND CASH FLOW

                                December     Q4 Total      FY2024
EBITDA                          -$1.0M       -$3.1M        -$13.1M
Free Cash Flow                  -$0.8M       -$2.8M        -$11.4M
Cash Position (EoP)              $28.4M       $28.4M        $28.4M

December EBITDA was negative $1.0M, an improvement from negative $1.8M in September and consistent with the company's trajectory toward breakeven. The improvement reflects operating leverage as revenue scales while operating expenses grow at a slower rate.

Cash position remains healthy at $28.4M. At current burn, we have approximately 24 months of runway without additional financing.

Cash consumption in December was approximately $0.8M after accounting for working capital changes (primarily the collection of outstanding receivables from Q3 invoicing). The cash position of $28.4M at year-end is consistent with the operating plan projection of $28.0M.

V. BALANCE SHEET HIGHLIGHTS

Total Assets                     $62.1M                  $61.4M
Accounts Payable                 $4.8M                   $4.2M
Deferred Revenue                 $22.8M                  $20.4M
Total Current Liabilities        $29.2M                  $26.1M
Total Stockholders' Equity       $62.4M                  $64.8M

Accounts receivable increased to $14.2M from $12.8M at the end of Q3, reflecting the higher Q4 bookings volume. Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) was 42 days, within the target range of 35-45 days. Angela Torres has reviewed all receivables over 60 days and confirms that all are expected to be collectible; no additional reserves are required.

Deferred revenue increased to $22.8M from $20.4M at end of Q3. The increase reflects the signing of several multi-year enterprise contracts in Q4, including three deals with prepaid annual terms that generated significant upfront cash collections. This is the highest deferred revenue balance in company history and provides strong revenue visibility for FY2025.

The vendor renewal pipeline for FY2025 includes 47 contracts up for renewal. The total annual value of these renewals is approximately $8.2M. The largest upcoming renewals are AWS ($4.2M, Q2), Snowflake ($2.1M, Q1), Salesforce ($0.9M, Q1), and Datadog ($0.6M, Q1).

- Department-specific onboarding continues
- 4:00 PM — End-of-week check-in with People Team

BUDDY PROGRAM

If you've been assigned as a buddy, please reach out to your new hire by end of day Monday. First impressions matter!

Buddy assignments have been distributed via email to all assigned buddies. As a reminder, the buddy program asks you to commit to:
- A welcome coffee or lunch in the first week
- A 30-minute check-in each week for the first 90 days
- Being available for questions via Slack throughout the onboarding period

If you have scheduling conflicts with your buddy assignment, please reach out to the People Team at people@nextera.io by end of day today.

CURRENT HEADCOUNT AND HIRING METRICS

With the January cohort, our headcount stands at 402. We continue to grow toward our FY2025 target of 465 FTEs.

Key hiring metrics:
- Open positions: 38
- Time to fill (average): 34 days
- Offer acceptance rate: 88%
- New hire 90-day retention rate: 96%
- January applicants: 1,247 across all open positions
- Interviews conducted in December: 186

Our Q1 hiring plan targets 18-22 additional hires across all departments, with the heaviest concentration in Engineering (8-10 positions) and Sales (5-7 positions). If you know outstanding candidates, please use the employee referral program — the referral bonus is $5,000 for engineering roles and $3,000 for all other positions.

UPCOMING PEOPLE TEAM EVENTS

- January 20: Martin Luther King Jr. Day (office closed)
- January 24: Company Game Night, 6 PM (sign up in #social-events)
- February 6: February All-Hands Meeting
- February 14: Valentine's Day office celebration + Rec Engine v3 launch party
- March 3-17: Annual Employee Engagement Survey

As always, my door is open. Please don't hesitate to reach out to anyone on the People Team if you have questions about benefits, policies, career development, or anything else.

EMPLOYEE REFERRAL PROGRAM — REMINDER

The employee referral program continues to be one of our most effective sourcing channels. In FY2024, employee referrals accounted for 31% of all hires — our second-largest source after LinkedIn direct sourcing. Referral hires also had a higher 90-day retention rate (98% vs. 94% for non-referral hires) and a shorter time-to-productivity (averaging 2.3 weeks faster to reach full productivity milestones).

Current referral bonuses:
- Engineering roles: $5,000
- Sales roles: $3,000
- All other roles: $3,000
- Executive/VP roles: $10,000

Referral bonuses are paid in two installments: 50% upon the new hire's start date and 50% after the new hire's 90-day milestone. All referrals must be submitted through the referral portal in Greenhouse before the candidate applies independently or is sourced through another channel.

Top referrers in FY2024:
1. Raj Patel (Engineering) — 4 successful referrals
2. Diana Marsh (Sales) — 3 successful referrals
3. Tomas Lindgren (Customer Success) — 3 successful referrals
4. Lisa Chen (Engineering) — 2 successful referrals
5. Ben Arujo (Product) — 2 successful referrals

Total referral bonuses paid in FY2024: $87,000 across 22 successful referrals.

WORKPLACE AND FACILITIES UPDATE

A few updates on our San Francisco headquarters:

The 14th floor kitchen renovation is now complete. The new space features an upgraded espresso machine (La Marzocca Linea PB), a second refrigerator to accommodate the growing team, and expanded counter space for the lunch rush. A big thank you to our facilities manager, Patricia Guerrero, for managing the renovation with minimal disruption.

Our office occupancy rate for Q4 2024 averaged 74% on Tuesdays through Thursdays and 41% on Mondays and Fridays. This is consistent with our hybrid work policy, which requires three days in-office per week with flexibility on which three days. We are not changing the hybrid policy at this time.

Parking: We have added 8 additional parking permits for the 655 Montgomery garage, bringing our total to 32. Permits are allocated on a first-come, first-served basis for employees who commute by car three or more days per week. Contact facilities@nextera.io to request a permit.

Conference room availability: With headcount growth, we've been seeing increased pressure on conference room bookings, particularly for the larger rooms (8+ capacity). Effective immediately, all conference room bookings longer than 2 hours require manager approval. Please release rooms you no longer need at least 30 minutes in advance so others can use them.

NEW HIRE SATISFACTION SURVEY RESULTS — Q4 2024 COHORT

The Q4 2024 new hire cohort (18 employees who started between October and December) completed their 90-day satisfaction survey. Results:

Overall onboarding experience: 4.3 / 5.0
Clarity of role expectations: 4.1 / 5.0
Manager support: 4.6 / 5.0
Buddy program effectiveness: 3.9 / 5.0
IT setup and tooling: 4.4 / 5.0
Company culture alignment: 4.5 / 5.0

Area for improvement: Several new hires noted that the buddy program check-ins became inconsistent after the first month. We are implementing a new structured cadence for buddy check-ins in Q1, with automated calendar reminders at weeks 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 12.

The Q4 cohort had a 100% retention rate at the 90-day mark — no departures. Our overall new hire 90-day retention rate remains at 96% on a trailing twelve-month basis, above the industry benchmark of 89%.

BENEFITS ENROLLMENT — FINAL STATUS

The 2025 benefits open enrollment window closed on January 20. Final enrollment statistics:

Medical plan selections:
- Gold plan ($510/mo): 124 employees (31%)
- Silver plan ($320/mo): 198 employees (49%)
- Bronze plan ($180/mo): 68 employees (17%)
- Waived coverage: 12 employees (3%)

Dental plan selections:
- Delta Dental (new option): 156 employees (39%)
- Aetna Dental: 212 employees (53%)
- Waived: 34 employees (8%)

The new Delta Dental option was well-received, with 39% of employees selecting it in its first year of availability. This exceeded our projection of 25% adoption. The plan offers broader network coverage in the Bay Area and lower out-of-pocket maximums compared to the Aetna plan.

401(k) enrollment:
- Participation rate: 91% (up from 87% in 2024)
- Average contribution rate: 8.2% of salary
- Employees contributing at or above the match threshold (5%): 78%
- New Fidelity 401(k) match: 5% (increased from 4% effective January 1)

ESPP enrollment:
- Participation rate: 62%
- ESPP discount: 15% off lower of grant date or exercise date fair market value
- Current 409A valuation: $14.20/share
- Standard vesting schedule for equity grants: 25% at 1 year cliff, monthly vesting thereafter over 4 years

The People Team will publish the full benefits enrollment report in the February bulletin. If you have questions about your elections or need to make a qualifying life event change, contact benefits@nextera.io.

Warm regards,
Vanessa Kline

Nextera Solutions
