DOCUMENT TYPE: All-Hands Meeting Transcript
DATE: January 15, 2025
PRESENTER: David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer
ATTENDEES: All Employees
SUBJECT: Mid-January Company Update
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-AH-2025-002

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
MID-JANUARY COMPANY UPDATE — ALL-HANDS MEETING TRANSCRIPT

Date: January 15, 2025
Format: Virtual via Zoom
Attendees: 380 (318 video-on, 62 audio-only)
Duration: 40 minutes
Recording: Available on the company intranet under All-Hands Recordings

[MEETING BEGINS]

DAVID ALDRIC (CEO): Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining our mid-January update. I know we just had the January all-hands last Thursday, but I wanted to do a quick pulse check on where we stand heading into the second half of the month. We've got updates from Marcus on the Kubernetes migration, Hannah on the Axion Labs evaluation, and Kevin on early pipeline momentum. Then I'll open it up for questions.

Before we dive in — a quick shout-out. I want to recognize the January new hire cohort. Twelve new teammates started this week. Vanessa's team put together an outstanding orientation program and I heard great things from the cohort about their first week. Welcome aboard, everyone. You joined at an exciting time.

I've said it before and I'll say it again: we are building Nextera to be the defining company in supply chain intelligence. Not for a quarter, not for a year — for a decade.

Every hire we make, every product decision, every customer we serve — it all ladders up to that ten-year vision. We are 402 people strong and growing. And every single person in this company plays a role in making that vision real.

Now let me hand it over to Marcus for the K8s migration update.

MARCUS WEBB (VP Engineering): Thanks, David. Quick update on the Kubernetes 1.29 migration. We're on track. Phase 1, the staging environment migration, completed in the first week of January with zero issues. Lisa Chen's platform team ran load tests at 2x peak traffic on the new staging environment and the results were strong: p99 latency at 2x traffic is 340ms, well within our 500ms SLA.

Production migration is scheduled for the February 3-7 maintenance window. The primary cutover will happen on February 5 between 2 AM and 6 AM Pacific. We're targeting zero customer-facing downtime using a rolling migration strategy. The rollback plan has been tested three times in staging and we're confident in our ability to roll back within 15 minutes if we hit any issues.

Engineering headcount update: we're at 142 engineers as of this week with the six new hires from the January cohort. Sprint 1 wrapped up last Friday with 14 stories completed and 340 story points delivered. Sprint 2 kicks off on Monday with priority focus on rec engine v3 performance benchmarks and K8s production migration preparation.

One more thing — the engineering hackathon is coming up February 7-8. Sign-ups open next week. Theme is "supply chain intelligence for everyone." $15K in prizes. Start forming your teams.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thanks, Marcus. Hannah, over to you on Axion Labs.

HANNAH CHOI (VP Product): Thanks, David. As you all know, we announced last week that we're kicking off a technical evaluation of Axion Labs' real-time logistics data feed API. The evaluation officially starts on Monday, January 20, and runs through February 14.

Hannah's team is evaluating a potential data partnership with Axion Labs. This is purely a product play — better data means better analytics for our customers.

A quick primer for those who aren't familiar: Axion Labs is a Series B startup based in Austin, Texas. They've raised about $45 million and have approximately 80 employees. Their core product is a real-time logistics data feed that covers over 340 shipping lanes globally. Our current logistics data providers cover about 220 lanes. So Axion offers a significant expansion in data coverage.

The evaluation team consists of five people: Raj Patel and Tyler Kim from engineering, Ben Arujo from product, Nina Okwu from data science, and myself as executive sponsor. We're going to test API reliability, latency, data quality, coverage breadth, and integration feasibility over the four-week sprint.

If the numbers hold up, we'll move to a partnership discussion. If not, we walk away. Simple as that. This is about product quality — giving our customers the best possible data for supply chain decision-making.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thanks, Hannah. Kevin, pipeline update.

KEVIN OROSCO (VP Sales): Thanks, David. Quick pipeline snapshot. We're 15 days into Q1 and the momentum is strong. Enterprise pipeline is sitting at $18.4M across 34 active opportunities. Weighted pipeline is $7.8M — we need $9.2M to hit Q1 quota.

We're also seeing strong traction in mid-market. Paulo Reyes's team has 52 active mid-market opportunities totaling $6.2M in pipeline. We did have two deals flagged as at-risk due to competitive pricing from Kinaxis in the logistics segment, but we're deploying the competitive displacement playbook and feeling good about our position.

Three new enterprise deals worth highlighting: we signed Maersk, DB Schenker, and Kuehne+Nagel in January's first two weeks. Combined, that's about $580K in new ACV. These are exactly the kinds of logos we want — global logistics leaders who will be reference customers and expand over time.

Sales headcount is at 48, targeting 58 by end of Q1. We have 10 open sales positions and we're actively interviewing for all of them. Time to fill in sales has been averaging 38 days, slightly longer than our company average of 34 days, but the quality of the candidates we're seeing is exceptional.

DAVID ALDRIC: Outstanding. Thank you, Kevin. Now I want to open it up for questions. We've got about 15 minutes.

[Q&A SESSION — 6 QUESTIONS]

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): Marcus, for the K8s migration — will there be any impact on our CI/CD pipelines during the cutover?

MARCUS WEBB: Good question. We've already migrated the CI/CD pipelines to the new K8s cluster in staging, so by the time we do the production cutover on February 5, the pipelines will be running on the new infrastructure. There will be a brief period during the rolling migration where builds might take slightly longer — maybe an extra 2-3 minutes per build — but there should be no functional impact. If you're planning a release for February 5, I'd recommend holding it until after the migration window closes at 6 AM.

EMPLOYEE (Sales): Kevin, are we seeing any impact from the current macroeconomic environment on deal cycles? Some of my prospects are mentioning budget freezes.

KEVIN OROSCO: We are seeing some elongation in mid-market deal cycles — average cycle has gone from about 65 days to 78 days over the last two quarters. Enterprise cycles have been more stable at around 85-90 days. That said, our pipeline coverage ratio is 3.2x against a 3.0x target, so we have enough at-bats to absorb some slippage. The key is qualification discipline — making sure we're spending time on deals that will close.

EMPLOYEE (Customer Success): Amanda's not here, so I'll ask David — any plans to expand the customer success team to handle the growing customer base?

DAVID ALDRIC: Great question. Yes, absolutely. We have two CS hires in the January cohort and we plan to add another three to four CSMs by end of Q1. Amanda and Vanessa are working on the hiring plan. Our CSM-to-account ratio is currently 1:12, and we'd like to bring that down to about 1:10 for enterprise accounts. That means we need to add specialized enterprise CSMs as the customer base grows.

EMPLOYEE (Product): Hannah, if the Axion eval goes well, what does the integration timeline look like?

HANNAH CHOI: If we give a green light after the evaluation ends on February 14, we'd move into partnership negotiations and start integration work in late February or early March. The estimated integration effort is 6-8 engineering weeks with a dedicated team. So we'd be looking at a beta in Q2 and GA in Q3. But that's getting ahead of ourselves — let's see what the evaluation shows first.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): David, with all the M&A happening in enterprise software, are we worried about being acquired?

DAVID ALDRIC: Absolutely not. We are building, not selling. Our best days are ahead of us.

I get some version of this question almost every week, and my answer is always the same. We are a $120 million ARR company growing at 14% year over year. We have $28 million in the bank and no debt. We have 218 customers who love our product. We have the best engineering team in supply chain intelligence.

Why would we sell? We are building a generational company. Our mission is to be the defining platform for supply chain intelligence — and we are well on our way. I started this company eight years ago with a conviction that the supply chain was the next great frontier for intelligent software, and every quarter, that conviction gets stronger.

So to directly answer the question: no, we are not worried about being acquired because we are not for sale.

EMPLOYEE (Finance): Priya isn't here — can someone speak to the Q1 budget status? Are all departments on track?

DAVID ALDRIC: I'll take that one. Yes, all departments are tracking within budget for January. Priya's team completed the FY2025 budget finalization on January 6 and all department heads have signed off on their allocations. Total operating budget for FY2025 is $108.6 million. We're in the early weeks so there's not much variance to report yet, but I can tell you that January payroll and vendor payments are processing on schedule and cash position is healthy. Priya will give a full financial update at the February all-hands.

DAVID ALDRIC: That's all the time we have today. Thank you, everyone, for your hard work and your commitment to Nextera's mission. We're 15 days into what I believe will be our best year yet. Let's keep executing.

[MEETING ENDS]

Post-meeting pulse survey results (273 responses):
- 68% rated the update as "very positive" about company direction
- 22% rated as "positive"
- 8% rated as "neutral"
- 2% rated as "somewhat concerned"

Next all-hands scheduled: February 6, 2025

DOCUMENT TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: January 15, 2025
FROM: Kevin Orosco, VP Sales
TO: Sales Team
SUBJECT: Q1 Sales Kickoff Recap and Pipeline Priorities
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Sales Team

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
SALES TEAM MEMORANDUM

To: All Sales Team Members
From: Kevin Orosco, VP Sales
Date: January 15, 2025
Re: Q1 Sales Kickoff Recap and Pipeline Priorities

Team,

Thank you to everyone who participated in the Q1 Sales Kickoff last Friday. It was our best kickoff yet — great energy, sharp presentations, and strong alignment on our Q1 goals. I want to recap the key takeaways and lay out our priorities for the next 11 weeks.

Q1 QUOTA AND TARGETS

Our Q1 quota is $36.8M in new ARR across the entire sales organization. Here's how that breaks down:

Enterprise (Diana Marsh's team):
- Team quota: $24.2M
- Active AEs: 18
- Average individual quota: $1.34M
- Pipeline required (at 31% win rate): $78M
- Current pipeline: $18.4M across 34 active opportunities
- Weighted pipeline: $7.8M

Mid-Market (Paulo Reyes's team):
- Team quota: $12.6M
- Active AEs: 14
- Average individual quota: $0.9M
- Pipeline required (at 38% win rate): $33.2M
- Current pipeline: $6.2M across 52 opportunities

Average deal sizes:
- Enterprise: $185K ACV
- Mid-Market: $62K ACV

Average sales cycle:
- Enterprise: 85-90 days
- Mid-Market: 65-78 days (note: elongation from macroeconomic factors)

Overall win rate: 31% (trailing 12 months)

Pipeline coverage ratio: 3.2x (target: 3.0x minimum)

COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE

Our primary competitive threats this quarter:

1. Palantir — Increasingly aggressive in mid-market pricing. They're offering sub-$500K deals with heavy discounting. Our win rate against Palantir is 62% and improving, but we cannot be complacent. The updated competitive battle card is available in Highspot.

2. Kinaxis — Strong in manufacturing-focused supply chain. We're seeing them in 3-4 enterprise deals per quarter. Our differentiation: rec engine v3, real-time analytics, and broader logistics data coverage. Battle card updating this week — I've asked product marketing to include the Axion Labs data partnership angle once it's announced.

3. Blue Yonder — Less frequent competitor but they have deep relationships in retail. Keep an eye on them in any retail vertical deals.

NEW LOGO HIGHLIGHTS

Three major new logos signed in January's first two weeks:

1. Maersk — $210K ACV, 2-year term. Enterprise. Global logistics leader. Signed by Sarah Kim (Enterprise AE). This is a marquee logo that will open doors across the logistics vertical.

2. DB Schenker — $195K ACV, 2-year term. Enterprise. German logistics giant. Signed by Chris Nadal (Enterprise AE). Our first major European logistics customer.

3. Kuehne+Nagel — $175K ACV, 3-year term. Enterprise. Swiss-headquartered logistics company. Signed by Diana Marsh (closing directly). Another tier-1 logistics logo.

Combined: $580K in new ACV from three reference-quality customers. Outstanding execution.

PROCESS REMINDERS

- All opportunities must be updated in Salesforce by end of day Friday each week. No exceptions.
- Forecast calls are every Monday at 9 AM. Come prepared with your top 5 and any deals that have changed stage.
- Competitive situations must be flagged in Salesforce using the "Competitor" field. Product marketing needs this data for battle card updates.
- Demo environment access: if your demo environment is not reflecting rec engine v3 features, contact Sami Okoro's team for an update.

Let's have a monster Q1. The product has never been better, the pipeline is healthy, and we have momentum. Now let's go execute.

PRESIDENT'S CLUB UPDATE

A quick reminder: President's Club 2025 qualification starts this quarter. Destination is Maui, Hawaii, September 15-19. Top 10% of quota attainment qualifies. We've also added a new category for highest expansion revenue — so if you're great at growing existing accounts, you have a shot at Maui too. Minimum quota attainment for consideration is 120%. Last year 8 reps qualified — let's see 12+ this year.

Full details were sent to the team on January 18. Talk to Diana or Paulo if you have questions about the qualification criteria.

SALES ENGINEERING SUPPORT

Quick note on SE capacity: we currently have 8 sales engineers supporting 32 quota-carrying AEs. That's a 1:4 ratio, which is tight. I've approved two additional SE hires and we're actively interviewing. In the meantime, please submit SE requests at least 5 business days before your scheduled demo or POC kickoff. Priority will be given to enterprise deals over $100K ACV that are in the evaluation stage.

SE utilization in Q4 was 91%, meaning our SEs were fully booked 91% of available hours. Industry benchmark is 75-80%. We're running hot and the additional hires will bring us back to a sustainable pace.

Kevin Orosco
VP Sales
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: January 18, 2025
FROM: Hannah Choi, VP Product
TO: Product Leadership, Marcus Webb
SUBJECT: Axion Labs Technical Evaluation — Week 1 Findings
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Product and Engineering Leadership
REFERENCE: NXS-PROD-2025-004

---

From: Hannah Choi <h.choi@nextera.io>
Date: January 18, 2025, 4:30 PM PST
To: Ben Arujo <b.arujo@nextera.io>; Marcus Webb <m.webb@nextera.io>; Raj Patel <r.patel@nextera.io>; Tyler Kim <t.kim@nextera.io>; Nina Okwu <n.okwu@nextera.io>
Subject: Axion Labs Technical Evaluation — Week 1 Findings

Team,

Sharing the Week 1 summary from our Axion Labs API evaluation. We're one week into the four-week evaluation sprint and I'm pleased with the progress. Here are the findings organized by workstream.

Week 1 results are encouraging. The Axion data feed has lower latency and broader coverage than our current logistics data sources.

API PERFORMANCE (Raj Patel, Lead)

Raj's benchmarks show 180ms average latency on their v2 API, with 99.7% uptime. That's well within our requirements.

Detailed findings:

Latency benchmarks (measured from our us-west-2 AWS region to Axion's us-east-1 infrastructure):
- Average latency: 180ms (our requirement: <250ms)
- p50 latency: 155ms
- p90 latency: 198ms
- p95 latency: 215ms
- p99 latency: 242ms
- Maximum observed latency: 380ms (single outlier during a brief network event on January 16)

Comparison with current logistics data provider (DataStream Inc.):
- DataStream average latency: 290ms
- DataStream p99 latency: 480ms
- Axion is approximately 38% faster on average and 50% faster at the p99 level

Uptime monitoring (continuous monitoring over 7-day period, January 13-19):
- Axion API uptime: 99.7% (23 minutes of degraded service on January 16 due to a planned maintenance window)
- Axion reported uptime SLA: 99.9% (the 99.7% observed includes the planned maintenance)
- Excluding planned maintenance: 99.98% uptime

API endpoints tested: 12 of 18 total endpoints available in the Axion Data Feed API v2. The remaining 6 endpoints are specialized endpoints for historical data retrieval, batch processing, and webhook configuration — we'll test those in Week 2.

Endpoints tested and results:
1. /v2/lanes/realtime — Real-time shipping lane data. 180ms avg. Clean JSON responses.
2. /v2/lanes/{lane_id}/metrics — Per-lane performance metrics. 165ms avg. Schema consistent.
3. /v2/ports/status — Global port status feed. 195ms avg. Data coverage: 340 ports.
4. /v2/vessels/tracking — Vessel tracking data. 210ms avg. AIS data integration verified.
5. /v2/routes/optimize — Route optimization endpoint. 225ms avg. Compute-intensive.
6. /v2/weather/maritime — Maritime weather data overlay. 170ms avg.
7. /v2/customs/clearance — Customs clearance status. 188ms avg.
8. /v2/rates/spot — Spot freight rates. 160ms avg.
9. /v2/rates/contract — Contract freight rate benchmarks. 155ms avg.
10. /v2/alerts/subscribe — Real-time alert subscription. Webhook-based, tested separately.
11. /v2/analytics/lane-performance — Aggregate lane performance analytics. 190ms avg.
12. /v2/analytics/port-congestion — Port congestion analytics. 175ms avg.

All 12 tested endpoints returned well-structured JSON with consistent schemas. Error handling is clean — proper HTTP status codes, meaningful error messages, and rate limit headers in every response.

DATA COVERAGE (Nina Okwu, Lead)

Data coverage: 340 shipping lanes vs. current provider's 220.

Nina completed the initial data coverage comparison between Axion's data and our current DataStream feed. Key findings:

Shipping lane coverage:
- Axion: 340 shipping lanes globally
- DataStream (current): 220 shipping lanes
- Coverage gap closed by Axion: 120 additional lanes
- Geographic breakdown of additional lanes:
  - Southeast Asia intra-regional: 28 lanes
  - Africa-Europe corridors: 22 lanes
  - South America intra-regional: 18 lanes
  - Middle East-Asia corridors: 16 lanes
  - Small island developing states (SIDS): 14 lanes
  - Other: 22 lanes

Port coverage:
- Axion: 340 ports with real-time status
- DataStream: 280 ports
- Additional ports: primarily in West Africa, Central America, and Pacific Islands

Data freshness:
- Axion: updates every 15 minutes for real-time endpoints, every 6 hours for analytics
- DataStream: updates every 30 minutes for real-time, every 12 hours for analytics
- Axion provides 2x better data freshness across all dimensions

Data quality assessment (preliminary — Nina will finalize in Week 2):
- Schema consistency: 99.4% (6 records out of 1,000 sampled had minor formatting issues in the vessel name field)
- Data completeness: 97.8% (missing ETA data for 22 out of 1,000 sampled shipments — primarily SIDS routes)
- Timestamp accuracy: validated against AIS reference data, deviation <30 seconds for 99.1% of records

INTEGRATION FEASIBILITY (Tyler Kim, Lead)

Tyler identified three primary integration points for Nextera's analytics pipeline:

1. Real-time data ingestion: Axion's webhook-based alert system can feed directly into our Kafka ingestion layer. Tyler has a proof-of-concept running in the dev environment that consumes Axion webhook events and writes them to our standard Kafka topic schema. Estimated effort to productionize: 2 engineering weeks.

2. Batch data sync: Axion's historical data API can be consumed via a nightly batch job to backfill analytics data. Tyler estimates 1 engineering week to build the batch sync pipeline, leveraging our existing Airflow DAG framework.

3. Dashboard integration: The Axion data can be rendered in our existing supply chain dashboard by adding a new data source adapter to our dashboard backend. Ben Arujo is working with the design team on how to present the additional lane data in the dashboard UI. Estimated effort: 3 engineering weeks (backend + frontend).

Total estimated integration effort: 6-8 engineering weeks with a dedicated team of 4-5 engineers.

COST ANALYSIS (Ben Arujo, Lead)

Ben has been in discussions with Axion's enterprise sales team on pricing. Preliminary cost analysis:

Axion enterprise tier pricing: $180K/year
- Includes: unlimited API calls, all 18 endpoints, real-time data access, dedicated support engineer
- Data retention: 24 months of historical data included
- SLA: 99.9% uptime with financial credits for breaches
- Support: dedicated technical account manager, 4-hour response SLA for critical issues

Comparison with current DataStream contract:
- DataStream annual cost: $132K/year
- Net incremental cost: $48K/year for significantly broader coverage and better performance
- Cost per lane: Axion at $529/lane vs. DataStream at $600/lane

The cost per lane is actually lower with Axion despite the higher total cost, because of the significantly broader coverage. The ROI case is strong — if even 10% of our customers adopt the enhanced logistics data features, the additional revenue from upselling would exceed the incremental cost within the first quarter.

WEEK 2 PLAN

I want to move to load testing next week. If the numbers hold, we should consider a formal partnership proposal.

Week 2 priorities:
1. Load testing: test Axion API at 10K requests/minute sustained for 30+ minutes (Raj)
2. Remaining endpoint testing: test the 6 untested endpoints (Tyler)
3. Data quality deep-dive: expand sample size from 1,000 to 10,000 records (Nina)
4. Customer interview synthesis: compile findings from customer interviews about logistics data needs (Ben)
5. Integration architecture review: review the POC integration with Marcus's team

COMPETITIVE CONTEXT

For context, our current logistics data provider ecosystem consists of:

1. DataStream Inc. (primary) — $132K/year, 220 shipping lanes, 280 ports, 30-min update frequency
2. MaritimeIQ — $48K/year, vessel tracking only, 190 vessels tracked
3. PortWatch (free tier) — basic port status for 120 major ports, hourly updates
4. Various government data feeds (CBP, EU customs) — free, 24-hour update frequency

The Axion evaluation, if successful, would consolidate DataStream and MaritimeIQ into a single data source with broader coverage and better performance. The net cost increase would be approximately $0K (Axion at $180K vs. current $180K combined for DataStream + MaritimeIQ). However, the data quality improvement would be substantial.

Customer context: 6 of our top 20 enterprise customers have specifically requested broader shipping lane coverage in their QBRs over the past two quarters. Our current coverage of 220 lanes leaves gaps in Southeast Asia intra-regional routes and Africa-Europe corridors that are important to customers like Maersk and Kuehne+Nagel.

TEAM RECOGNITION

I want to call out the evaluation team for their exceptional work this week. Raj set up the entire benchmarking harness from scratch in less than two days. Tyler got a proof-of-concept Kafka consumer running by Wednesday. Nina's data quality analysis methodology is rigorous and well-documented. Ben coordinated smoothly with Axion's product team on API documentation and test account setup.

This is exactly the kind of cross-functional collaboration that makes Nextera's product team effective. Thank you all.

Evaluation committee meets Friday January 24 at 2 PM for the Week 2 readout.

Hannah

---

From: Marcus Webb <m.webb@nextera.io>
Date: January 18, 2025, 5:15 PM PST
To: Hannah Choi <h.choi@nextera.io>
Subject: RE: Axion Labs Technical Evaluation — Week 1 Findings

Hannah,

Impressive results. The latency numbers are significantly better than what we're getting from DataStream. Raj's benchmarks are thorough and I trust the methodology.

I approve extending the evaluation to include load testing in Week 2. A few additional requests from the engineering side:

1. I'd like Tyler to also test the webhook system under load — specifically, what happens when Axion sends a burst of webhook events (e.g., 1,000 events in 10 seconds) to our Kafka consumer. We need to verify our ingestion layer can handle the throughput without backpressure.

2. Please have Raj test the API's behavior under concurrent connections. Our production environment runs 12-15 API consumer threads. I want to see latency characteristics at that concurrency level.

3. For the integration architecture review in Week 2, I'd like Lisa Chen to join. She'll need to assess the infrastructure requirements for running the Axion data pipeline alongside our existing data processing workloads on the new K8s cluster.

If the load testing results hold up, I'm supportive of moving to a partnership discussion. The data coverage improvement alone would be a significant value-add for our customers.

Marcus

---

From: Raj Patel <r.patel@nextera.io>
Date: January 18, 2025, 5:48 PM PST
To: Hannah Choi <h.choi@nextera.io>; Marcus Webb <m.webb@nextera.io>
Subject: RE: Axion Labs Technical Evaluation — Week 1 Findings

Hannah, Marcus,

Thanks for the feedback. I'll add the concurrent connection testing and webhook burst testing to the Week 2 plan.

One technical observation worth noting: Axion's API uses a connection pooling architecture that's well-suited for high-concurrency workloads. During my initial testing, I observed that they maintain persistent connections and use HTTP/2 multiplexing, which explains the low latency numbers. This is a more modern architecture than DataStream's HTTP/1.1 API, which creates a new TCP connection for each request.

I'll have the concurrency benchmarks ready by Wednesday January 22. The sustained load test (10K req/min for 30+ minutes) will start Thursday morning and I'll have results by Friday's readout.

One other thing — I spoke with Axion's engineering lead, James Whitworth, during the evaluation onboarding session on Monday. He mentioned they're planning to release API v3 in Q3 2025 with GraphQL support. That would give us even more flexibility in how we query their data. Worth keeping in mind for the partnership terms discussion.

Raj

DOCUMENT TYPE: Financial Report
DATE: January 18, 2025
FROM: Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer

CLASSIFICATION: Board Confidential

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
JANUARY 2025 BOARD PACKAGE — FINANCIAL UPDATE

Prepared By: Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer
Date: January 18, 2025
Period Covered: January 1-18, 2025

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

January is off to a strong start. Revenue is tracking 3% above plan, driven by two enterprise deals that pulled in from February.

This interim financial update is provided as part of the January board package for the Board of Directors' review. All figures are preliminary and unaudited.

I. REVENUE AND BOOKINGS — JANUARY MTD

Revenue (Jan 1-18): $5.8M
Revenue plan (Jan 1-18): $5.6M
Revenue vs. plan: +3.4%

New bookings MTD: $2.3M
Bookings plan (full month): $4.2M
Bookings pace: 55% of monthly plan at 58% of month elapsed — on track

The revenue outperformance is attributable to two enterprise deals that were originally forecasted for early February but accelerated to close in mid-January. Combined, these two deals represent approximately $0.4M in new ACV. Sales pipeline health remains strong with no unusual patterns in the pipeline velocity.

Recurring revenue for January is tracking in line with expected recognition from the existing customer base. No significant unanticipated churn or downgrade activity in the period.

II. CASH POSITION

Cash position: $27.8M. We project ending Q1 at $25.1M, consistent with our operating plan. No financing needed in 2025.

Cash position as of January 18: $27.8M
Cash position December 31: $28.4M
Change: -$0.6M

Cash movements in January MTD:
- Customer collections: +$4.2M
- Payroll and benefits: -$2.6M (bi-weekly payroll Jan 3 and Jan 17)
- Vendor payments: -$1.4M
- AWS monthly invoice: -$0.35M
- Other operating expenses: -$0.45M

Payroll expense January (full month projected): $5.1M
Vendor payments January (full month projected): $1.4M

Cash runway projection:
- Cash at end of Q1 (projected): $25.1M
- Monthly burn rate: $1.1M (trending down from $1.2M in Q4 due to operating leverage)
- Runway at current burn: approximately 23 months
- Credit facility: $15M undrawn (Silicon Valley Bank, SOFR + 175bps)
- Total available liquidity: $42.8M ($27.8M cash + $15M facility)

No additional financing is anticipated in FY2025. The operating plan projects cash breakeven by Q4 2025, at which point the company will begin generating positive free cash flow.

III. OPERATING EXPENSE RUN RATE

Operating expense run rate: $8.7M/month (within plan of $9.1M/month)

Expense breakdown by category (monthly run rate):
- Compensation (salary + benefits): $5.1M
- Cloud infrastructure: $1.3M
- Facilities (rent, utilities, insurance): $0.6M
- Software and tools: $0.5M
- Travel and entertainment: $0.3M
- Professional services (legal, audit): $0.2M
- Marketing: $0.4M
- Other: $0.3M

The $0.4M favorable variance to plan is primarily attributable to slower-than-planned hiring (3 engineering positions open that were budgeted for January start) and lower travel expenses due to a light conference schedule in January.

IV. HEADCOUNT UPDATE

Current headcount: 406 (up from 402 at year-end)
January net additions: 4 (12 new hires - 8 net due to 2 departures and 6 internal transfers counted separately)
Correction: January saw 12 new hires, 0 departures this month = 414 headcount expected by month-end including the additional hires starting Jan 20 and Jan 27.

Headcount by department:
- Engineering: 148 (including 6 January hires)
- Sales & Marketing: 91 (including 3 January hires)
- Customer Success: 54 (including 2 January hires)
- Product: 22
- G&A: 91 (including 1 January hire)

Open positions: 36 (down from 38 at year-end, 2 positions filled in January, 0 new positions opened)

V. KEY METRICS — JANUARY MTD

Pipeline coverage ratio: 3.2x (target: 3.0x)
Active opportunities: 86 (34 enterprise, 52 mid-market)
Customer count: 219 (1 new logo signed in January MTD)
Net revenue retention (trailing 12 months): 119%
Gross revenue retention (trailing 12 months): 94%

VI. OUTLOOK

The business is performing well in the early weeks of FY2025. Revenue and bookings are tracking ahead of plan, operating expenses are within budget, and the cash position is healthy. The management team remains confident in the FY2025 operating plan targets and does not anticipate any material revisions to guidance at this time.

The Board should note that Q1 has historically been our seasonally weakest quarter for new bookings (Q4 and Q3 are strongest due to enterprise budget cycles). However, the early pipeline momentum and the pull-forward of two enterprise deals from February provides a strong start to the quarter.

VII. ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE AGING

As of January 18, 2025:

Current (0-30 days): $10.8M (76.1%)
31-60 days: $2.4M (16.9%)
61-90 days: $0.7M (4.9%)
Over 90 days: $0.3M (2.1%)
Total AR: $14.2M

The accounts receivable balance is well-managed with 76% current. The $0.3M in over-90-day receivables consists of three accounts:
1. FreightLine Systems ($140K) — payment in process, expected within 2 weeks per their AP department
2. Nordic Transport Group ($95K) — disputed invoice related to a scope change in Q3, under resolution with CS team
3. Pacific Route Logistics ($65K) — company undergoing restructuring, classified as doubtful; $65K reserve taken in Q4

Our bad debt expense for FY2024 was $180K (0.16% of revenue), well below the industry average of 0.5-1.0% for enterprise SaaS companies.

VIII. CAPITAL EXPENDITURE UPDATE

FY2025 capex budget: $12.6M
January capex spend: $0.4M

Capex breakdown by category:
- Kubernetes infrastructure migration: $5.8M budget, $0.2M spent in January (staging environment costs)
- Office expansion (15th floor buildout): $3.2M budget, $0.0M spent (construction begins February)
- Lab and testing infrastructure: $1.8M budget, $0.1M spent
- IT equipment (new hire laptops, monitors): $1.2M budget, $0.1M spent
- Miscellaneous: $0.6M budget, $0.0M spent

The 15th floor buildout is on track to begin in February with an expected completion date of April 2025. The space will accommodate approximately 40 additional workstations, a new engineering lab, and two conference rooms. Permits have been obtained from the San Francisco Department of Building Inspection.

IX. TAX AND COMPLIANCE STATUS

Federal tax: Nextera Solutions has a federal net operating loss (NOL) carryforward of approximately $34M as of December 31, 2024. No federal income tax liability is expected for FY2025.

State tax: California minimum franchise tax of $800 applies. No material state income tax liability expected due to NOL carryforward.

International: The company has no international operations or subsidiaries. All revenue is denominated in USD.

Sales tax: The company collects and remits sales tax in 14 states where SaaS is subject to sales tax. Sales tax compliance is managed through Avalara and is current in all jurisdictions.

409A valuation: The most recent 409A valuation was completed in October 2024 at $14.20 per share. The next 409A valuation is scheduled for April 2025 following the annual audit.

X. RISK FACTORS

The following risk factors should be noted for the Board's consideration:

1. Customer concentration: Top 20 customers represent 44% of ARR. This is within our target range of 40-50% but warrants monitoring. No single customer represents more than 4% of ARR.

2. Vendor dependency: AWS represents 28% of total vendor spend. A significant price increase by AWS could impact margins. The recently signed 3-year commitment at 8% discount mitigates this risk through December 2027.

3. Competitive pricing pressure: Palantir and Kinaxis continue to apply pricing pressure in certain segments. Our win rate remains healthy at 62% against Palantir and 55% against Kinaxis.

4. Macroeconomic sensitivity: Extended sales cycles in mid-market (78 days vs. 65 days historical) may be attributable to macroeconomic caution among mid-market buyers. Pipeline coverage of 3.2x provides buffer against deal slippage.

No material risks are anticipated that would impact the FY2025 operating plan at this time.

Respectfully submitted,
Priya Vasquez
Chief Financial Officer
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

PREVIOUS PRESIDENT'S CLUBS

2023: Scottsdale, Arizona — 6 qualifiers
2022: Napa Valley, California — 5 qualifiers

LOGISTICS

- Flights: Business class for trips over 5 hours, economy plus for shorter flights

Q1 KICKOFF RECAP — CUSTOMER STORIES

I also want to share three customer stories from the kickoff presentations that illustrate why we win. These are the stories you should be telling in your demos and discovery calls.

CUSTOMER STORY 1: MAERSK (signed January 2025)

Challenge: Maersk needed real-time visibility into their container shipping operations across 12 major routes. Their existing tools provided data with 4-6 hour latency, making real-time decision-making impossible.

Solution: Nextera's supply chain analytics platform with the recommendation engine v2 providing sub-30-minute data refresh cycles and predictive ETAs accurate to within 2 hours.

Result: During the POC, Maersk identified $2.4M in potential annual savings from optimized route selection and reduced demurrage charges. The decision to go with Nextera was made by their VP of Global Operations after a 6-week evaluation that included Palantir and Blue Yonder.

Key quote from the Maersk VP: "Nextera's recommendation engine showed us optimization opportunities that our internal team had been looking for for two years. The data quality and the speed of insight were the deciding factors."

Deal details: $210K ACV, 2-year term, 120 users, signed by Sarah Kim.

CUSTOMER STORY 2: DB SCHENKER (signed January 2025)

Challenge: DB Schenker's European operations team was using spreadsheets and manual processes to manage supply chain analytics across their 430 warehouse locations. They needed a scalable analytics platform that could integrate with their SAP ERP system.

Solution: Nextera's platform with SAP integration module and the supply chain dashboard for real-time KPI tracking across all warehouse locations.

Result: During the 8-week POC, DB Schenker consolidated 14 separate reporting tools into a single Nextera dashboard. Their analytics team reduced report generation time from 3 days to 2 hours.

Key quote from the DB Schenker CTO: "We evaluated four vendors and Nextera was the only one that could handle our scale and integrate with SAP natively. The implementation team was exceptional."

Deal details: $195K ACV, 2-year term, 85 users, signed by Chris Nadal.

CUSTOMER STORY 3: KUEHNE+NAGEL (signed January 2025)

Challenge: Kuehne+Nagel wanted a predictive analytics capability for their ocean freight operations, specifically the ability to predict port congestion and recommend alternative routing 48-72 hours in advance.

Solution: Nextera's predictive analytics module powered by the recommendation engine, trained on historical port congestion data and real-time vessel tracking feeds.

Result: During the 10-week POC, the system correctly predicted 87% of significant port congestion events 48+ hours in advance, compared to their existing tool's 52% accuracy.

Key quote from the Kuehne+Nagel Head of Innovation: "The accuracy of Nextera's predictions fundamentally changes how we plan our ocean freight operations. This is the future of supply chain intelligence."

Deal details: $175K ACV, 3-year term, 60 users, signed by Diana Marsh.

COMPETITIVE WIN ANALYSIS — Q4 2024

While I'm on customer stories, here's our Q4 competitive win/loss analysis for reference:

Total competitive evaluations in Q4: 28
- Wins: 16 (57% win rate in competitive situations)
- Losses: 8 (29%)
- No decision: 4 (14%)

- vs. Palantir: 62% (8 evaluations, 5 wins)

- vs. Blue Yonder: 50% (4 evaluations, 2 wins)
- vs. Others (SAP, Oracle, Manhattan Associates): 60% (10 evaluations, 6 wins)

Top win drivers (cited by customers in post-decision surveys):

Top loss drivers:
1. Price (cited 5 of 8 losses)
2. Existing vendor relationship (cited 4 of 8)
3. Feature gaps (cited 2 of 8, both in manufacturing vertical)

The rec engine v3 launch in February will strengthen our competitive position further. Make sure your demo environments are updated with v3 capabilities by February 15.

These are the kinds of stories that win deals. Use them in your discovery calls and reference them in your proposals. Customer references are available for all three accounts — contact Amanda Briggs to arrange reference calls.

DOCUMENT 1 OF 3
Type: Board Meeting Minutes
Date: January 21, 2025
Prepared by: Corporate Secretary Maria Fuentes
Distribution: Board of Directors
Classification: Board Confidential — Project Lighthouse

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
MINUTES OF SPECIAL MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
January 21, 2025

A special meeting of the Board of Directors of Nextera Solutions, Inc. was held on Tuesday, January 21, 2025, via secure video conference. The meeting commenced at 2:00 PM Pacific Standard Time.

DIRECTORS PRESENT:
- Robert Kessler, Board Chair
- Sarah Jiang, Board Member
- Tom Whitfield, Board Member
- Nina Patel, Board Member
- David Aldric, CEO (ex officio)

ALSO PRESENT:
- Maria Fuentes, Corporate Secretary

Board convened special session with all five members present. The Corporate Secretary confirmed a quorum was present and the meeting was called to order by Mr. Kessler at 2:02 PM PST. The meeting was held via secure video conference, not at HQ, at the direction of the Board Chair. No external advisors were present at this session. Total meeting duration: one hour and forty-eight minutes.

AGENDA ITEM 1 — CALL TO ORDER AND APPROVAL OF AGENDA

Mr. Kessler called the meeting to order and presented the agenda for approval. Mr. Whitfield moved to approve the agenda as distributed. Ms. Patel seconded. The agenda was approved unanimously. The Corporate Secretary noted that a revised agenda had been distributed the prior evening reflecting the addition of a new item under agenda item 7, labeled Strategic Exploration.

AGENDA ITEM 2 — MINUTES OF PRIOR MEETING

The minutes of the regular December 2024 Board meeting, previously distributed to all directors on January 14, were presented for approval. Ms. Jiang moved to approve the minutes as written. Mr. Whitfield seconded. The minutes were approved unanimously without amendment. The Corporate Secretary confirmed that executed copies had been filed in the company's corporate records.

AGENDA ITEM 3 — Q1 FORECAST REVIEW AND STANDARD FINANCIAL UPDATE

Kessler opened with the standard financial update and Q1 forecast review. The CFO had prepared written materials in advance, which had been distributed to all directors on January 17 via the board portal. Mr. Kessler summarized the key points from the financial package: revenue tracking above plan across all customer segments, the bookings pipeline showing strength entering the new fiscal quarter with several large enterprise deals expected to close in February, and operating expenses within budget for the quarter. Cash reserves remained healthy.

The Board reviewed the materials at length. Ms. Patel asked several clarifying questions regarding the timing of certain large enterprise deal closings expected in Q1, specifically the pipeline concentration in two accounts that together represented approximately eighteen percent of the quarter's bookings target. Mr. Kessler acknowledged the concentration risk and noted that the CFO had provided a sensitivity analysis in the appendix materials.

Mr. Whitfield asked about headcount plan adherence. The materials showed that the company had ended Q4 with four hundred and six employees, slightly below the planned headcount of four hundred and twelve. Mr. Aldric noted that the remaining open positions were primarily in engineering and that recruiting was on track to fill them by the end of February.

Ms. Jiang asked about gross margin trends. The Q1 forecast showed gross margins holding steady at approximately seventy-eight percent, consistent with prior quarters. No action was required on this agenda item.

AGENDA ITEM 4 — PRODUCT ROADMAP UPDATE

Aldric presented the product roadmap update including Axion Labs evaluation status. The presentation covered three major workstreams for Q1 2025. First, the recommendation engine version 3 launch, which was tracking toward a February production deployment after completing integration testing. Second, the Kubernetes infrastructure migration, which the engineering team had been preparing since Q4. Third, the ongoing evaluation of Axion Labs as a potential data partnership candidate.

On the recommendation engine, Mr. Aldric noted that all integration tests were passing and performance benchmarks were scheduled to begin the following day. He described this as the most significant product upgrade in the past eighteen months and expected it to have a material positive impact on customer engagement metrics.

On the Kubernetes migration, Mr. Aldric summarized the load testing results: the platform had sustained three times peak traffic for two hours with maximum latency remaining within acceptable limits. The migration window was targeted for the first week of February.

On the Axion Labs evaluation, Mr. Aldric reported that the product team had completed approximately sixty percent of planned customer interviews, with early results showing strong demand for real-time logistics data. He noted that the evaluation was proceeding well and that a decision on the partnership was expected in the first week of February. The Board asked questions about the competitive implications and the resource commitment required for integration. Mr. Aldric estimated eight to twelve weeks of dedicated engineering time and described it as consistent with standard partnership integrations the company had undertaken in prior years.

Ms. Patel asked about the Axion Labs evaluation timeline and whether it could be accelerated. Mr. Aldric replied that the evaluation was already on an aggressive timeline. Ms. Jiang asked about the cost of the partnership. Mr. Aldric deferred to the product team's final analysis but noted the estimated range was between one hundred eighty thousand and two hundred fifty thousand dollars per year.

AGENDA ITEM 5 — COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE AND MARKET POSITIONING

Board discussed competitive landscape and market positioning at the request of Mr. Kessler. Mr. Aldric provided an overview of recent market developments in the supply chain analytics space. Two venture-backed competitors had raised significant rounds in Q4 2024: DataFreight had closed a Series C at eighty-five million dollars, and ChainVue had raised a Series B at forty million dollars. Additionally, a larger enterprise player, OracleSoft, had announced a supply chain analytics module that would be bundled with their existing ERP product.

The Board discussed the implications for Nextera's pricing strategy and market share trajectory at length. Mr. Whitfield asked whether any of the competitive developments changed the company's growth assumptions. Mr. Aldric said they did not, citing Nextera's customer retention rate of ninety-six percent and net revenue retention of one hundred and twelve percent as evidence that the company's competitive position remained strong. Ms. Patel concurred and noted that the Board had discussed similar competitive dynamics in prior quarters without material impact on company performance.

Mr. Kessler asked about the company's win rate in competitive evaluations. Mr. Aldric reported that the win rate against direct competitors had been approximately sixty-five percent in Q4, consistent with prior quarters. The win rate against the larger enterprise bundled solutions was approximately forty percent, though those deals typically had longer sales cycles and different buyer profiles. The Board discussed strategies for improving win rates in the enterprise segment.

AGENDA ITEM 6 — GOVERNANCE AND COMPLIANCE UPDATE

The Corporate Secretary provided a brief governance update. The annual directors and officers insurance renewal was being processed with the current carrier, Hartford Financial. The policy premium was increasing approximately seven percent year over year, consistent with broader market trends in the D&O insurance market. The current policy provided twenty-five million dollars in coverage with a fifty-thousand-dollar retention.

The Board's committee assignments for 2025 had been finalized and distributed. Ms. Patel would continue to chair the Audit Committee, Mr. Whitfield would continue to chair the Compensation Committee, and Ms. Jiang would chair the newly formed Technology Advisory Committee.

Ms. Fuentes also noted that the company's SOC 2 Type II audit was scheduled for March 3 through 21 and that the CISO's team had begun preparation work. The CISO had reported no material gaps in the preliminary readiness assessment. Mr. Kessler asked whether any issues were anticipated. Ms. Fuentes said the CISO had reported no material concerns, noting that the company had achieved a clean SOC 2 Type II report in the prior year and that no significant changes to the control environment had occurred since then.

The Corporate Secretary also reminded the Board that the annual Board effectiveness self-assessment was due by February 15. Questionnaires had been distributed via the board portal.

No action was required on this agenda item.

AGENDA ITEM 7 — STRATEGIC EXPLORATION: Mr. Aldric informed the Board of preliminary inbound interest from Meridian Corp regarding a potential strategic transaction. The Board discussed the matter.

Mr. Aldric provided background on Meridian Corp, describing it as an $8.2 billion enterprise software conglomerate listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Meridian Corp operates across four business segments: enterprise resource planning, customer relationship management, supply chain management, and business intelligence. They employ approximately twelve thousand people globally with headquarters in Boston, Massachusetts.

Mr. Aldric stated that the inbound interest had come through an introduction from a mutual contact and that the initial conversations had been preliminary in nature. He characterized the interest as exploratory and noted that no formal offer had been made, no term sheet had been exchanged, and no financial advisors had been retained by either party. The discussions to date had consisted of two phone calls between Mr. Aldric and a senior executive at Meridian.

Mr. Kessler asked about the nature of the interest. Mr. Aldric described it as a general expression of interest in a strategic transaction, without specifying whether Meridian was contemplating an acquisition, a partnership, a joint venture, or some other form of combination. Mr. Aldric recommended that the Board authorize him to continue exploratory discussions to better understand Meridian's intent and to assess whether further engagement would be in the best interests of the company and its stockholders.

Mr. Whitfield asked about Meridian's acquisition history. Mr. Aldric said Meridian had completed four acquisitions in the past three years, ranging from approximately one hundred fifty million to one point two billion dollars. Their most recent acquisition was in Q3 2024, when they acquired a business intelligence startup called DataPrism for approximately four hundred million dollars.

Ms. Patel asked whether Mr. Aldric had any preliminary view on valuation. Mr. Aldric said it was premature to discuss valuation given the early stage of conversations. Ms. Patel noted that the Board should establish guidelines for any further discussions to protect the company's interests and suggested that the company should retain independent legal counsel and a financial advisor before engaging in any substantive valuation discussions.

Mr. Kessler asked whether the company's existing outside counsel at Morrison & Partners had experience with transactions of this nature. The Corporate Secretary noted that Morrison & Partners had represented the company since incorporation but that their M&A practice was relatively small. Ms. Patel suggested that the company consider engaging a larger firm with dedicated M&A expertise if discussions progressed.

The Board debated the matter at length. The discussion under agenda item 7 lasted approximately thirty-five minutes.

Mr. Kessler expressed the view that it would be prudent to continue the conversations to understand the opportunity, characterizing it as a normal exercise of the Board's fiduciary responsibilities. Mr. Whitfield agreed, noting that the Board had a fiduciary duty to understand all options available to maximize stockholder value. He referenced Revlon duties and noted that while they were not currently in a sale process, the Board should be informed about the landscape.

Ms. Patel supported continuing the discussions but recommended that external legal counsel be retained before any substantive negotiations began. She also recommended that the Board establish a special committee if discussions progressed beyond the exploratory phase.

Ms. Jiang expressed opposition to continuing the discussions. Ms. Jiang: "I want my opposition recorded. I believe our best path is organic growth and I do not support exploring this."

Ms. Jiang stated that the company's growth trajectory was strong, that the team had executed well across every metric that mattered, and that exploring a transaction at this stage could be distracting and demoralizing for employees if word leaked. She noted that inbound interest from larger companies was a regular occurrence for successful growth-stage companies and that the Board should not feel obligated to engage with every expression of interest. She further noted that the company had received similar inbound interest on at least three prior occasions during her Board tenure and had declined to engage each time.

Mr. Whitfield responded that the prior instances had involved companies that were not strategic fits. He noted that Meridian's supply chain management division made this inquiry qualitatively different from prior inbound interest.

After further discussion, Mr. Kessler called for a vote on the following resolution:

RESOLVED: The Board authorizes the CEO to continue exploratory discussions regarding Project Lighthouse, with updates to be provided at each regular Board meeting. Vote: 4-1 (Jiang opposed).

Mr. Kessler noted that the codename "Project Lighthouse" would be used for all future Board communications regarding this matter. All materials related to Project Lighthouse would be marked Board Confidential and restricted to Board members, the CEO, and the General Counsel. No information regarding Project Lighthouse was to be shared with any other company employee, officer, or advisor without prior Board approval.

Ms. Fuentes confirmed that a separate secure folder had been created on the board portal for Project Lighthouse materials and that access had been restricted to the five directors and the CEO.

AGENDA ITEM 8 — OTHER BUSINESS

No other business was raised by any director. Mr. Kessler reminded the Board of the upcoming February regular meeting and noted that the agenda would include an update on Project Lighthouse as a standing item.

AGENDA ITEM 9 — ADJOURNMENT

There being no further business to come before the meeting, Mr. Kessler adjourned the meeting at 3:50 PM PST. The next update is scheduled for the February regular Board meeting.

Respectfully submitted,

Maria Fuentes
Corporate Secretary
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

Minutes marked: Board Confidential — Project Lighthouse

MEMORANDUM

TO:      Rachel Dominguez, General Counsel
FROM:    Nathan Foley, Senior Corporate Counsel
DATE:    January 24, 2025
RE:      Review of Change-of-Control Provisions in Executive Employment Agreements

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Per your request, I have completed the review of change-of-control provisions across all 14 executive employment agreements. This memorandum summarizes the current state of the provisions, identifies areas where our agreements deviate from current market practice, and proposes revisions to align with benchmarking data from the Compensia 2024 Executive Compensation Survey. The proposed revisions differentiate between C-suite and VP-level executives, reflecting the market trend toward tiered acceleration structures.

II. SCOPE OF REVIEW

I reviewed executive employment agreements for the following individuals:

C-Suite Executives (5):
1. David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer — agreement effective March 15, 2019 (date of hire), last amended October 2023
2. Priya Vasquez, Chief Financial Officer — agreement effective June 1, 2020, last amended October 2023
3. Marcus Webb, Chief Technology Officer — agreement effective January 10, 2020, last amended October 2023
4. Rachel Dominguez, General Counsel — agreement effective September 1, 2021, last amended October 2023
5. Vanessa Kline, Vice President of People — agreement effective February 15, 2021, last amended October 2023

VP-Level Executives (9):
6. Hannah Choi, Vice President of Product — agreement effective April 1, 2022
7. Kevin Orosco, Vice President of Sales — agreement effective July 15, 2021
8. Amanda Briggs, Vice President of Customer Success — agreement effective November 1, 2021
9. Jordan Michaels, Vice President of Finance — agreement effective March 1, 2022
10. Frank Gutierrez, Chief Information Security Officer — agreement effective August 1, 2022
11. Lisa Chen, Director of Platform (VP-equivalent per agreement terms) — agreement effective May 15, 2020
12. Sami Okoro, Engineering Manager (VP-equivalent per agreement terms) — agreement effective January 3, 2022
13. Derek Hollis, FP&A Manager (VP-equivalent per recent promotion agreement) — agreement effective September 1, 2023
14. Angela Torres, Controller (VP-equivalent per agreement terms) — agreement effective March 15, 2021

Executive agreements reviewed: 14 total (5 C-suite, 9 VP-level).

III. CURRENT PROVISIONS

Current provisions: all executives receive double-trigger acceleration (termination + change of control). I recommend aligning with current market practice. The current change-of-control provisions are identical across all 14 agreements and contain the following terms:

A. Change of Control Definition

The current change-of-control definition in all 14 agreements is as follows: acquisition of 50% or more of voting shares or substantially all assets of the company by a person or group. The definition also includes certain board composition changes (a majority of the board being replaced within any 12-month period by directors whose appointment was not endorsed by a majority of the existing board).

The current definition does not address mergers where the company's stockholders retain less than 50% of the surviving entity, which is a common market provision. I recommend adding this to the revised definition. Additionally, the current definition does not address tender offers or reverse mergers, which are increasingly common transaction structures in the enterprise software sector. For completeness, I recommend including these in the revised definition as well.

I also note that the current definition does not include a carve-out for internal restructurings or reorganizations that do not involve a third-party acquirer. This is standard market practice and should be added to prevent inadvertent triggering of acceleration provisions in connection with routine corporate transactions such as holding company formations or divisional restructurings.

B. Acceleration Trigger

All 14 agreements currently contain a double-trigger acceleration mechanism: 100% of unvested equity accelerates only upon both (i) a change of control and (ii) the executive's involuntary termination without cause or resignation for good reason within 12 months following the change of control.

The "cause" definition in the current agreements includes: material breach of the agreement, conviction of a felony, willful misconduct causing material harm to the company, or failure to perform duties after written notice and 30-day cure period. The "good reason" definition includes: material reduction in base salary (more than 10%), material reduction in authority or responsibilities, relocation of more than 50 miles, or material breach of the agreement by the company.

C. Severance Terms

All 14 agreements currently provide 12 months of base salary as severance upon a qualifying double-trigger event. There is no distinction between C-suite and VP-level severance under the current agreements. The severance is paid in a lump sum within 30 days of the qualifying termination, subject to the executive's execution of a general release of claims. The agreements also provide for 12 months of continued COBRA benefits at the company's expense.

D. Non-Competition and Non-Solicitation

All 14 agreements contain 12-month post-termination non-competition and 18-month non-solicitation covenants. These covenants apply regardless of the circumstances of termination. I note that the enforceability of non-competition provisions varies by jurisdiction and that California, where 12 of 14 executives are based, generally does not enforce post-employment non-competition covenants under Business and Professions Code Section 16600. The non-solicitation provisions are generally enforceable in California, however.

E. Estimated Values

At the current 409A valuation of $14.20 per share, the estimated equity value subject to acceleration across all 14 executives is approximately $42 million. This figure breaks down as follows:

- CEO (Aldric): $12.4M in unvested equity (874,648 unvested shares)
- CFO (Vasquez): $6.8M in unvested equity (478,873 unvested shares)
- CTO (Webb): $5.2M in unvested equity (366,197 unvested shares)
- GC (Dominguez): $4.1M in unvested equity (288,732 unvested shares)
- VP People (Kline): $3.5M in unvested equity (246,479 unvested shares)
- VP-level executives (9 total): $10.0M in unvested equity aggregate (704,225 unvested shares)

Total shares subject to acceleration: 2,959,154

IV. MARKET BENCHMARKING

I reviewed the Compensia 2024 Executive Compensation Survey, which covers compensation practices at 287 technology companies with revenues between $50 million and $500 million. The survey, published in September 2024, is the most current source of market benchmarking data available for companies at our revenue stage. The survey reports the following market practices for change-of-control provisions:

Single-Trigger Acceleration (C-Suite):
- 68% of surveyed companies provide single-trigger acceleration for CEO
- 54% provide single-trigger acceleration for other C-suite executives
- Median acceleration: 100% of unvested equity
- Trend: The percentage of companies offering single-trigger acceleration to C-suite has increased from 58% in the 2022 survey to 68% in 2024, reflecting a clear market shift

Double-Trigger Acceleration (VP-Level):
- 82% of surveyed companies use double-trigger acceleration for VP-level executives
- Most common employment requirement: 12 months post-closing
- Median acceleration: 100% of unvested equity upon qualifying termination
- Only 11% of companies provide single-trigger acceleration at the VP level

Severance Multiples:
- CEO median: 24 months base salary + target bonus
- Other C-suite median: 18 months base salary + target bonus
- VP-level median: 12 months base salary (no bonus multiplier)
- 73% of companies provide COBRA continuation for the severance period

Change of Control Definition:
- 91% include acquisition of 50%+ voting shares
- 87% include sale of substantially all assets
- 79% include mergers resulting in stockholder dilution below 50%
- 62% include board composition changes

V. PROPOSED REVISIONS

Based on the benchmarking analysis, I propose the following revisions to align with current market standards:

A. C-Suite Executives (CEO, CFO, CTO, GC, VP People)

Proposed revision for C-Suite (CEO, CFO, CTO, GC, VP People): single-trigger acceleration of 100% of unvested equity upon a qualifying change-of-control event. This means that upon a change of control, all unvested equity would accelerate immediately without any requirement for termination. This change aligns with the majority practice (54-68%) reported in the Compensia survey.

Proposed severance for C-suite: 24 months base salary + target bonus. This is an increase from the current 12 months base salary and aligns with the median practice reported in the Compensia survey. The aggregate severance exposure for the 5 C-suite executives, based on current compensation, is approximately $5.8 million (salary component only) plus approximately $2.9 million in target bonus, for a total of approximately $8.7 million.

COBRA continuation: extended from 12 months to 24 months for C-suite executives, consistent with the severance period.

B. VP-Level Executives

VP-level executives: double-trigger acceleration with a 12-month post-closing continued employment requirement. This aligns with the 2024 Compensia survey data. Under this provision, VP-level executives would receive 100% acceleration of unvested equity only if they are terminated without cause or resign for good reason within 12 months following the change of control.

Proposed severance for VP-level: 12 months base salary. This maintains the current severance level for VP-level executives, which is at the market median. No change to the COBRA continuation period for VP-level executives.

C. Updated Change of Control Definition

I recommend expanding the change-of-control definition to include:
- Acquisition of 50% or more of voting shares
- Sale of substantially all assets
- Merger or consolidation where existing stockholders hold less than 50% of surviving entity
- Board composition change (majority replacement within 12 months)
- Tender offer resulting in acquirer holding more than 50% of outstanding shares
- Carve-out: excludes internal restructurings, recapitalizations, and IPO transactions

This expanded definition is consistent with market practice and provides clearer coverage for a broader range of transaction structures.

VI. IMPLEMENTATION

I recommend the following implementation approach:

1. Present the proposed revisions to the Compensation Committee for review — targeting February 2025
2. Obtain Board approval at the next regular Board meeting — targeting February 2025
3. Prepare amended employment agreements for execution — within 30 days of Board approval
4. Coordinate with VP People on communication to affected executives — concurrent with agreement execution
5. File updated equity plan provisions with the SEC as required — within 10 business days of amendment

The estimated timeline is:
- Compensation Committee review: first week of February 2025
- Board approval: February 2025 Board meeting (tentatively February 10)
- Agreement execution: within 30 days of Board approval
- Employee notification: concurrent with agreement execution

I recommend Board approval at the next regular meeting. The documentation required for Board review includes: (1) this memorandum, (2) redlined versions of each executive agreement showing proposed changes, (3) a summary of the Compensia benchmarking data, and (4) a financial impact analysis prepared by the CFO's office.

VII. TAX CONSIDERATIONS

I have consulted with our outside tax counsel at Morrison & Partners regarding the Section 280G implications of the proposed changes. The single-trigger acceleration for C-suite executives could result in parachute payments that exceed the safe harbor threshold under Section 280G. The safe harbor threshold is three times the executive's "base amount" (defined as the average W-2 compensation over the preceding five years).

I recommend that the revised agreements include a best-of-net provision, which would reduce payments to the safe harbor amount only if the executive would receive a greater after-tax benefit. This approach avoids the need for stockholder approval under Section 280G(b)(5)(B) and is the most common approach among our peer group (used by 64% of companies in the Compensia survey).

The estimated Section 280G exposure based on current compensation levels and equity values is approximately $8.2 million across all C-suite executives. This figure would change based on the actual transaction price in any future change-of-control event. Morrison & Partners has provided detailed calculations for each C-suite executive, which are available upon request.

I also note that the Section 409A implications of the proposed changes need to be reviewed. The acceleration of vesting upon a change of control is generally not treated as a modification of the equity award for 409A purposes if the acceleration is provided under the equity plan rather than as an individual arrangement. Morrison & Partners is reviewing this issue and will provide a supplemental opinion by January 31.

VIII. PEER COMPANY COMPARISON

For additional context, I compiled change-of-control provisions from publicly available information at five peer companies in the enterprise software space with comparable revenue and employee count:

1. Veeva Systems (FY2024 revenue: $2.4B) — Single-trigger for CEO, double-trigger for all others, 18-month post-closing period
2. Datadog (FY2024 revenue: $2.1B) — Single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP+, 12-month post-closing period
3. Confluent (FY2024 revenue: $780M) — Single-trigger for CEO and CFO only, double-trigger for all others
4. Braze (FY2024 revenue: $470M) — Double-trigger for all executives, 12-month post-closing period
5. nCino (FY2024 revenue: $480M) — Single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP+, 12-month post-closing period

Our proposed structure (single-trigger for C-suite, double-trigger for VP-level) is consistent with the most common approach among our peers.

IX. CONCLUSION

The proposed revisions bring our executive agreements in line with current market practice as reported in the Compensia 2024 survey. The key changes are: (1) moving from double-trigger to single-trigger acceleration for C-suite executives, (2) raising C-suite severance to 24 months base salary plus target bonus, (3) standardizing the change-of-control definition, and (4) maintaining double-trigger acceleration with 12-month employment requirement for VP-level executives. These changes would apply to all 14 executive agreements.

I am available to discuss these recommendations at your convenience and can prepare the draft amended agreements upon your approval. I anticipate the drafting process will take approximately one week once direction is given.

Respectfully submitted,

Nathan Foley
Senior Corporate Counsel
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

Attachments:
- Appendix A: Compensia 2024 Survey Summary (relevant excerpts)
- Appendix B: Peer Company Comparison Table
- Appendix C: Estimated 280G Exposure by Executive (Morrison & Partners analysis)
- Appendix D: Current Agreement Summary Table

Type: Email Thread
Subject: RE: Equity Acceleration Policy — Proposed Updates
Date: January 24, 2025
From: Vanessa Kline (VP People)
To: David Aldric (CEO), Rachel Dominguez (GC)
Classification: Confidential — Executive

--- Original Message ---
From: Vanessa Kline <v.kline@nexterasolutions.com>
To: David Aldric <d.aldric@nexterasolutions.com>, Rachel Dominguez <r.dominguez@nexterasolutions.com>
Date: January 24, 2025, 9:08 AM PST
Subject: Equity Acceleration Policy — Proposed Updates

David, Rachel,

Per our discussion, I've drafted updates to the equity acceleration policy. The key change is adding a 'qualifying event' definition that would trigger acceleration for eligible employees.

I've been working on this since our conversation last week and have incorporated the feedback from our preliminary review. Here's a summary of the proposed changes and the rationale:

1. QUALIFYING EVENT DEFINITION

We're proposing to add a "qualifying event" definition to the Nextera Equity Plan. Currently, the equity plan does not contain a standalone definition of qualifying events that trigger acceleration. The acceleration provisions are embedded in individual employment agreements, which creates inconsistency across the employee population.

The proposed qualifying event definition includes:
- Change of control (acquisition of 50% or more of voting shares or substantially all assets)
- Initial public offering
- Specified asset sale exceeding $50 million

This definition would be incorporated into the equity plan itself, creating a single source of truth for all participants. Currently, 380 of our 406 employees hold equity under the plan, so this change affects the vast majority of our workforce.

I've reviewed the definitions used by comparable companies in the Compensia survey and our proposed language is consistent with the most common formulations. I've also ensured alignment with the language Nathan Foley is using in the executive agreement revisions.

2. ACCELERATION TIERS

The proposed policy creates three tiers of acceleration upon a qualifying event:

Tier 1 (C-Suite): Single-trigger acceleration of 100% of unvested equity
  - Applies to: CEO, CFO, CTO, GC, VP People (5 individuals)
  - Trigger: qualifying event alone, no termination required
  - Rationale: aligns with 68% of peer companies for CEO, 54% for other C-suite

Tier 2 (VP-Level): Double-trigger acceleration of 100% of unvested equity, requiring termination within 12 months post-closing
  - Applies to: 9 VP-level executives
  - Trigger: qualifying event + involuntary termination without cause or resignation for good reason
  - Rationale: aligns with 82% of peer companies at VP level

Tier 3 (All Other Employees): Double-trigger acceleration of 50% of unvested equity, requiring termination within 12 months post-closing
  - Applies to: 366 employees holding equity
  - Trigger: qualifying event + involuntary termination without cause
  - Rationale: new benefit not previously available; 50% acceleration is at the upper end of market practice for non-executive employees

This tiered approach is consistent with the recommendations in Nathan Foley's legal memo, which I understand he submitted to Rachel today.

3. FINANCIAL IMPACT

Total unvested equity pool: $68 million at the current 409A valuation of $14.20 per share.

Breakdown by tier:
- Tier 1 (C-Suite, 5 individuals): $32.0M in unvested equity
- Tier 2 (VP-Level, 9 individuals): $10.0M in unvested equity
- Tier 3 (All other employees, 366 individuals): $26.0M in unvested equity

The maximum acceleration exposure under the proposed policy (assuming all triggers are met for all tiers) is the full $68 million. In practice, Tier 2 and Tier 3 would only accelerate upon qualifying terminations. Based on industry data, approximately 30-40% of employees experience qualifying terminations within 12 months of a change of control, so the expected exposure is more likely in the range of $40-50 million.

For budgeting and board presentation purposes, I've prepared three scenarios:
- Conservative (Tier 1 only triggers): $32.0M
- Base case (Tier 1 + 35% of Tier 2/3): $44.6M
- Full exposure (all tiers, all triggers): $68.0M

I've also noted that the 409A valuation of $14.20 per share was set in October 2024 and is scheduled for an update in April 2025. Any qualifying event would likely result in a transaction price significantly above the 409A valuation, so the actual dollar exposure would exceed these estimates.

4. COMMUNICATION PLAN

I'm planning to communicate the updated policy as follows:
- Board approval: target the February Board meeting
- Company-wide announcement: within one week of Board approval, via all-hands presentation
- Employee information session: scheduled for February 10 (tentative), in-person + Zoom
- FAQ document: posted to HR intranet concurrent with announcement
- Individual equity statement updates: distributed within 30 days of effective date
- Manager toolkit: talking points and Q&A guide distributed to all managers 48 hours before company announcement

I'd like both of your input on the communication approach. The key message I want to convey is that this is a routine update to align with market best practices, not a response to any specific event. We want employees to see this as a positive enhancement to their compensation package.

5. RETENTION ANALYSIS

I've also analyzed the retention implications of the proposed changes. With 380 equity holders, the acceleration provisions are a meaningful retention tool. Here's the analysis:

Average unvested equity value by level:
- C-Suite: $6.4M per executive
- VP-Level: $1.1M per executive
- Senior IC/Manager: $142K per employee
- Mid-level: $68K per employee
- Junior: $22K per employee

The Tier 3 acceleration provision (50% acceleration on qualifying termination) represents a new benefit worth approximately $11K-$71K per employee depending on level. For senior ICs and managers, this is a material benefit that strengthens retention.

Our current voluntary turnover rate is 8.2% (trailing 12 months). Among employees in the top quartile of unvested equity value, voluntary turnover is 3.1%. The acceleration provision reinforces the retention value of unvested equity by providing protection against involuntary loss of equity in a change-of-control scenario.

6. TIMELINE

- January 24: Submit to legal for review (today)

   - We currently target the 60th percentile for new hire grants, which is slightly above median
   - Refresh grants target the 50th percentile

2. Vesting schedules (we're at 4-year with 1-year cliff, which is standard)
   - 89% of companies in the Compensia survey use 4-year vesting
   - 74% use a 1-year cliff, which is what we do
   - Monthly vesting after cliff (our approach) is used by 68% of companies

3. Refresh grant cadence and size (we currently do annual refreshes at ~25% of initial grant)
   - Market median for annual refresh is 20-25% of initial grant
   - We're at the upper end of market practice, which is good for retention
   - Some companies are moving to semi-annual refreshes, but that's still a minority practice

4. Burn rate analysis (our annual equity burn rate is approximately 3.8%, which is within the ISS guideline of 5%)
   - ISS benchmark for technology companies: 5.0% burn rate threshold
   - Our 3.8% gives us headroom for additional grants without exceeding guidelines
   - Peer median: 4.1%

   - Current overhang: 18.2% (shares outstanding + available pool as % of fully diluted shares)

Team,

Two major items to align on this week: the hackathon on February 7-8 and the rec engine v3 launch preparation.

HACKATHON — FEBRUARY 7-8

Hackathon Feb 7-8 is a go. 23 teams registered. Pizza, energy drinks, and $15K in prizes. Let's see what you build.

RECOMMENDATION ENGINE V3 — LAUNCH PREP

rec engine v3 beta: throughput is 15% above our target. Query latency at p99 is 220ms against 300ms target. This thing is ready.

- Throughput: 1,150 queries/sec (target: 1,000 queries/sec) — 15% above target

KUBERNETES 1.29 PRODUCTION MIGRATION

K8s prod migration: green light for Feb 3. Rollback plan tested and verified. Lisa's team will be on-call through Feb 7.

Lisa, confirming the migration schedule:

- Tuesday Feb 4: Final staging validation. On-call team briefing at 6 PM.
