DOCUMENT TYPE: All-Hands Meeting Transcript
DATE: January 27, 2025
PRESENTER: David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer
ATTENDEES: All Employees
SUBJECT: Late January All-Hands
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-AH-2025-003

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
LATE JANUARY ALL-HANDS MEETING TRANSCRIPT

Date: January 27, 2025
Format: In-person (main auditorium) + Zoom
Attendees: 348 in-person, 58 remote (406 total)
Duration: 50 minutes
Recording: Available on intranet

[MEETING BEGINS]

DAVID ALDRIC (CEO): Good afternoon, Nextera. Welcome to the late January all-hands. I want to cover a lot of ground today, so let's dive in.

First — the numbers. We are in the strongest position this company has ever been. Revenue is growing, customers love us, and our product roadmap is the most ambitious in our history. January bookings are tracking ahead of plan, with $4.8M in new bookings through the 27th against a monthly target of $4.2M. That's our best January ever.

Let me bring up Priya for the financial highlights.

PRIYA VASQUEZ (CFO): Thank you, David. January is looking like a strong month. Revenue is tracking at approximately $10.4M for the month, about 4% above our plan of $10.0M. Cash position is healthy at $27.1M. Operating expenses are within budget at $8.8M for the month. We have approximately 24 months of runway at current burn rates, and our burn rate is declining as we approach the breakeven trajectory in Q4.

The FY2025 operating plan is fully funded and we do not anticipate the need for any additional financing. Our pipeline coverage ratio is healthy at 3.2x and the business is performing well across all dimensions.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Priya. Marcus, hackathon and rec engine update.

MARCUS WEBB (VP Engineering): Quick updates. The engineering hackathon is February 7-8. Twenty-three teams have registered, 92 participants. We have $15K in prizes and I'm excited to see what you all build. Theme is "supply chain intelligence for everyone."

On rec engine v3 — the beta performance is exceptional. Throughput is 15% above target and p99 latency is 220ms against our 300ms target. We're on track for the February 14 launch. All 3,350 tests are passing with zero P1 or P2 bugs.

And on the K8s migration — production cutover starts next week, February 3 through 7. The main event is February 5 at 2 AM. Lisa Chen's platform team has this well in hand. Rollback plan tested three times, zero downtime expected.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Marcus. Hannah, Axion Labs update.

HANNAH CHOI (VP Product): The Axion Labs evaluation is in its second week and the results continue to be strong. Week 1 showed latency of 180ms average, 99.7% uptime, and significantly broader data coverage than our current providers — 340 shipping lanes versus 220. This week we're running load tests and doing a deep data quality analysis.

If the Week 2 results hold up, we'll be moving toward a formal partnership discussion. I'm visiting their Austin office the first week of February with Ben Arujo to discuss partnership terms.

The Axion partnership, if we proceed, would be a significant upgrade to our analytics platform's data layer. It's purely a product investment — better data means better analytics for our customers.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Hannah. Now I want to address something directly.

I get asked this a lot, so let me be direct: Nextera is not for sale. We are building a company that will define supply chain intelligence for the next decade. Full stop.

I know there's been chatter — there always is in enterprise software. Companies get acquired every week. But Nextera is not one of those companies. We have $27 million in the bank. We have no debt. We have 218 customers who trust us with their most critical operations. We have the best engineering team in supply chain intelligence.

I see us as a $1B ARR platform company. Independent. Category-defining. That's the company I'm building. And that's the company every single one of you is building alongside me.

Now let me take some questions.

[Q&A SESSION — 8 QUESTIONS]

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): David, what's your 10-year vision for Nextera?

DAVID ALDRIC: I see us as a $1B ARR platform company. Independent. Category-defining. That's the company I'm building.

In 10 years, I want Nextera to be the platform that every major supply chain on earth runs through. Not just analytics — full supply chain orchestration, prediction, and optimization. We're at $120M ARR today. I believe we can get to $500M in five years and $1B in eight to ten years through a combination of organic growth, product expansion, and strategic partnerships like the one we're evaluating with Axion Labs.

The supply chain intelligence market is massive and underpenetrated. Most companies are still running their supply chains on spreadsheets and legacy ERPs. We're building the future. And the future is ours for the taking.

EMPLOYEE (Sales): Kevin isn't here — can you comment on the competitive landscape?

DAVID ALDRIC: Sure. We compete primarily against Palantir in enterprise and Kinaxis in the manufacturing vertical. Our win rate against Palantir is 62% and rising. Our differentiation is product — specifically the recommendation engine, which nobody else has at our level of sophistication. The Axion data partnership will further strengthen our competitive position by giving our customers access to the broadest and highest-quality logistics data in the market.

I'm not worried about competition. I'm focused on building the best product. When you build the best product, customers find you.

EMPLOYEE (Product): Are there plans for international expansion?

DAVID ALDRIC: Not in the near term. Our customers are global — Maersk, DB Schenker, Kuehne+Nagel are all international companies — but our go-to-market motion is US-based with international expansion through channel partnerships. We may look at opening a European sales office in 2026 or 2027, but it's not a priority for this year.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): What happens to our equity if the company goes public?

DAVID ALDRIC: Good question. An IPO is not on our near-term radar. I've said this publicly and I'll say it again here — we want to get to $200M ARR before we even think about the public markets. That said, your equity is valuable and will become more valuable as the company grows. Our 409A valuation is $14.20 per share as of October 2024. Every quarter that we grow revenue and expand the customer base, that number goes up.

When the time comes for a liquidity event — whether that's an IPO or something else down the road — your equity will be a significant part of your total compensation. That's by design. We want everyone at Nextera to share in the value we're building together.

EMPLOYEE (HR): Vanessa, can you share any updates on the annual engagement survey?

VANESSA KLINE (VP People): Yes! The annual employee engagement survey launches March 3 and runs through March 17. It's anonymous and takes about 15 minutes. Last year's engagement score was 78 out of 100, which puts us in the top quartile for tech companies in the Bay Area. Our goal this year is 80. The survey results will be shared at the March all-hands.

EMPLOYEE (Customer Success): What's our plan for customer retention as we scale?

DAVID ALDRIC: Amanda Briggs is leading our retention strategy. The short answer is: we invest heavily in customer success. Our net revenue retention is 119% — that means on average, existing customers are spending 19% more each year. Our CSM-to-account ratio is 1:12 for enterprise and we're hiring to bring it down to 1:10. We're also investing in self-service capabilities so that smaller customers can get value without needing as much hands-on support.

Customer retention is existential for a SaaS company. If you don't retain and expand your customers, nothing else matters. We take it seriously.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): Marcus, will the hackathon projects ever ship as real features?

MARCUS WEBB: Great question. Last year's hackathon produced three projects that went through formal product evaluation, and one of them — the anomaly detection module in the supply chain dashboard — is now in production. This year, the first-place team gets a fast-track product evaluation, which means Hannah's team will assess the project for product-market fit within 30 days of the hackathon. So yes, your hackathon project could become a real Nextera feature.

EMPLOYEE (Finance): Can we get more transparency into departmental budgets?

DAVID ALDRIC: Fair ask. Priya publishes quarterly financial updates to the executive team and I share highlights at all-hands. Department budgets are managed by each VP with oversight from finance. If you want more detail about your specific department's budget, talk to your VP — they should be able to share the high-level allocation. We're not going to publish detailed budgets company-wide because some of that information is competitively sensitive, but we believe in transparency within the chain of command.

DAVID ALDRIC: One more thing before we wrap. I want to recognize some people.

First, the platform team — Lisa Chen, Tyler Kim, Amara Williams, Devi Krishnan — for the flawless staging migration. Zero customer impact. That's how you execute.

Second, the rec engine team — Sami Okoro, Raj Patel, Carlos Rivera, Fatima Al-Rashid — for delivering beta performance that exceeded every target we set. When you over-deliver by 15% on throughput, that's not luck. That's engineering excellence.

And finally, Vanessa's People Team for another outstanding new hire orientation. Twelve new teammates, zero friction, great feedback from the cohort. That's the Nextera standard.

You are all building something extraordinary. Don't lose sight of that. The work you do every day — every line of code, every customer call, every deal closed, every new hire onboarded — it all adds up to something bigger than any one of us.

DOCUMENT TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: January 27, 2025
FROM: Frank Gutierrez, CISO
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: Mandatory Security Awareness Training — Due Feb 14
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-SEC-2025-002

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
INFORMATION SECURITY BULLETIN

To: All Nextera Employees
From: Frank Gutierrez, Chief Information Security Officer
Date: January 27, 2025
Re: Mandatory Annual Security Awareness Training

MANDATORY TRAINING NOTICE

Annual security awareness training is now available on KnowBe4. You have until February 14 to complete it. This is mandatory — no exceptions.

The training is required for all employees regardless of role, department, or tenure. Completion is tracked at the individual level and will be reported to the Board of Directors as part of our SOC 2 Type II audit preparation.

TRAINING MODULES

The 2025 security awareness training consists of four modules:

Module 1: Phishing and Social Engineering (15 minutes)
- Updated scenarios reflecting current threat landscape
- Examples include: fake vendor invoice emails, spoofed executive requests, LinkedIn-based pretexting
- Interactive quiz at the end (minimum 80% to pass)

Module 2: Data Handling and Classification (10 minutes)
- Review of Nextera's data classification framework:
  - Public: marketing materials, public blog posts
  - Internal: all-hands slides, team meeting notes, general Slack conversations
  - Confidential: financial data, customer data, product roadmaps, employee compensation
  - Restricted: board minutes, legal privileged communications, security incident details
- Proper handling procedures for each classification level
- When and how to use encryption

Module 3: Password Hygiene and Multi-Factor Authentication (10 minutes)
- Password requirements: minimum 16 characters, unique per service
- Required MFA for all Nextera systems (Okta SSO with hardware key or authenticator app)
- Password manager recommendations (1Password provided by company)
- What to do if you suspect credential compromise

Module 4: Social Engineering Awareness (10 minutes)
- Voice phishing (vishing) scenarios
- Physical security awareness
- Tailgating prevention
- USB drop attacks
- Deepfake awareness (new for 2025)

Estimated total time: 45 minutes

ACCESS THE TRAINING

Log in to KnowBe4 at https://training.knowbe4.com using your Nextera SSO credentials. The training modules are listed under "2025 Required Training." You must complete all four modules and pass each quiz with a score of 80% or higher.

COMPLETION TIMELINE

- Training available: January 27, 2025
- Manager notification for non-completion: February 7, 2025
- VP notification for non-completion: February 12, 2025
- Completion deadline: February 14, 2025
- Board reporting: March 3, 2025 (part of SOC 2 audit preparation)

Last year we had 97% completion by deadline. Let's hit 100% this year. Your managers will be notified of non-completion.

PHISHING SIMULATION

Following the training, we will conduct a phishing simulation campaign in February. The simulation will use realistic scenarios tailored to each department (engineering will see fake GitHub and CI/CD alerts, sales will see fake CRM notifications, etc.). Results will be aggregated by department — individual results are confidential.

Last year's phishing simulation click rate: 4.2% (industry average for our peer group: 6.8%). Our target for 2025: below 3%.

If you click on a simulated phishing email, you will be redirected to a learning page — it's a teaching moment, not a punishment. However, repeated failures may result in additional targeted training.

CONTACT

For questions about the training or general security inquiries, reach out to the security team via #security-compliance on Slack or email security@nextera.io.

INCIDENT RESPONSE REMINDER

While we're on the topic of security, a reminder about our incident response procedures:

If you identify a potential security incident (suspicious email, unauthorized access, data exposure, etc.):
1. Do NOT attempt to investigate on your own
2. Report immediately to security@nextera.io or call the security hotline at x4911
3. Preserve any evidence (screenshots, email headers, etc.)
4. Do not forward suspicious emails — use the "Report Phishing" button in Outlook/Gmail

Our incident response SLA:
- Critical (data breach, active intrusion): 15-minute response, 1-hour initial assessment
- High (suspected compromise, malware detection): 1-hour response
- Medium (policy violation, unusual activity): 4-hour response
- Low (informational, best practice questions): next business day

In FY2024, we had zero critical security incidents, one high-severity incident (an employee's personal device was compromised — not connected to Nextera systems), and four medium-severity incidents (all policy violations that were resolved through additional training).

Our security posture is strong, but it requires everyone's participation. Security is not just the security team's job — it's everyone's job.

UPCOMING SECURITY EVENTS

- February 7: CrowdStrike penetration test kickoff call
- February 10-14: Penetration test execution (staging environment)
- February 14: Security awareness training deadline
- February 17-21: Phishing simulation campaign
- March 3-21: SOC 2 Type II audit (Ernst & Young)

Please mark your calendars and plan accordingly. The SOC 2 audit is our most important compliance milestone of the year and strong training completion rates contribute to a clean audit opinion.

Thank you for your attention to security. Together, we keep Nextera and our customers safe.

Frank Gutierrez
Chief Information Security Officer
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT 1 OF 3
Type: Audit Report
Title: SOC 2 Type II Readiness Assessment — Q3 2025 Interim Report
Author: Priya Mehta, Director of Information Security
Date: 2025-09-08
Recipients: InfoSec Team, Compliance Committee
Classification: Internal — Confidential

--- BEGIN DOCUMENT ---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — SOC 2 TYPE II READINESS ASSESSMENT
Q3 2025 INTERIM REPORT
Prepared by: Priya Mehta, Director of Information Security
Date of Report: September 8, 2025
Distribution: InfoSec Team, Compliance Committee
Document Classification: Internal — Confidential

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This interim report provides the Compliance Committee and InfoSec Team with a comprehensive status update on Nextera Solutions' SOC 2 Type II audit readiness as of September 8, 2025. Deloitte & Touche LLP has been retained as the external auditor for the engagement, consistent with the prior fiscal year arrangement. The observation period under review spans July 1 through December 31, 2025. Nextera Solutions is pursuing attestation across the Security, Availability, and Confidentiality Trust Services Criteria as defined by the AICPA.

As of the date of this report, evidence collection has been completed for 47 of 62 controls, representing a current completion rate of 75.8%. Three open gaps have been identified and documented below, each of which has a defined remediation path that does not require architectural changes to Nextera's production infrastructure. The prior fiscal year audit concluded with zero exceptions, and the operational target for the current engagement is a repeat clean opinion. The audit fee for the Type II engagement is $185,000, unchanged from the FY2024 engagement.

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES AND SYSTEMS

The following individuals, organizations, and systems are referenced throughout this report and are material to the readiness assessment:

    Priya Mehta, Director of Information Security — report author and SOC 2 audit program owner. Priya serves as the primary liaison between Nextera and Deloitte's audit team and is responsible for coordinating evidence collection across all contributing departments.

    Deloitte & Touche LLP — external auditor retained for the SOC 2 Type II engagement. Deloitte has served as Nextera's SOC 2 auditor since the FY2022 engagement and brings institutional knowledge of Nextera's control environment. The engagement partner is Michael Rosenstein, who has led the Nextera account for the past two audit cycles.

    AWS us-east-1 and us-west-2 regions — the primary and secondary production hosting environments for Nextera's SaaS platform infrastructure. All customer-facing services are deployed across both regions with active-passive failover, and the SOC 2 scope includes controls governing access, change management, and monitoring for both regions.

    Nextera Solutions SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria — the specific criteria selected for the Type II attestation: Security (Common Criteria), Availability, and Confidentiality. Processing Integrity and Privacy criteria are not in scope for this engagement, consistent with the prior year.

    Jira ticket INFOSEC-2287 — the master tracking ticket for the SOC 2 readiness program, containing all sub-tasks for evidence collection, gap remediation, auditor communication, and timeline management. As of September 8, there are 147 sub-tasks, of which 98 are marked complete, 31 are in progress, and 18 are in the backlog.

    Kevin Cho, Staff SRE — subject matter expert for infrastructure controls, database-layer encryption, and production environment access management. Kevin is the designated control owner for seven controls in the Security and Confidentiality categories.

3. CONTROL EVIDENCE COLLECTION STATUS

Evidence collection is organized by Trust Services Criteria category. Each control requires one or more evidence artifacts, which may include system configuration screenshots, access logs, policy documents, process documentation, or attestation statements from control owners. Evidence is uploaded to the shared Deloitte evidence repository hosted on Deloitte's secure file transfer platform.

3.1 Security Controls (CC6.x Series)

Total controls in scope: 28
Evidence collected and uploaded: 22
Remaining: 6

The Security criteria represent the largest category in the assessment and cover logical access controls, system boundary protections, change management, and risk management processes. Of the 22 completed controls, evidence packages include IAM role definitions and screenshots from AWS IAM, Okta access policies, VPN configuration exports, network segmentation diagrams, and change management workflow documentation from Jira.

The six remaining controls fall into three groups. First, CC6.1 (privileged access review) is the subject of Gap 1, described in Section 4 below. Second, three controls (CC6.2, CC6.3, and CC6.5) require updated screenshots of firewall rules and security group configurations from the September monthly review, which is scheduled for September 12. Third, two controls (CC6.6 and CC6.8) require attestation statements from the VP of Engineering and the Head of DevOps confirming that their teams follow the documented change management process. These attestation requests were sent on September 3 and responses are expected by September 12.

3.2 Availability Controls (A1.x Series)

Total controls in scope: 18
Evidence collected and uploaded: 14
Remaining: 4

The Availability criteria address system monitoring, incident response, business continuity, and disaster recovery. The 14 completed controls include evidence of uptime monitoring via Datadog, PagerDuty on-call rotation configurations and escalation policies, incident postmortem documentation for Q2 and Q3 incidents, and business continuity plan documentation.

The four remaining controls relate to disaster recovery testing and business continuity exercises. The DR runbook for the us-west-2 failover region was updated in August 2025 to reflect infrastructure changes made during the Q2 platform migration, but the updated runbook has not yet been formally tested in the current observation period. A DR test is scheduled for the week of October 6, which will generate the required evidence artifacts including test execution logs, recovery time measurements, and a post-test report. The remaining three controls require documentation of the business continuity tabletop exercise (related to Gap 3 in Section 4 below).

3.3 Confidentiality Controls (C1.x Series)

Total controls in scope: 16
Evidence collected and uploaded: 11
Remaining: 5

The Confidentiality criteria cover data classification, encryption, confidential data handling procedures, and data retention and disposal. The 11 completed controls include the data classification framework document, encryption-at-rest configurations for AWS S3, RDS, and EBS volumes, encryption-in-transit configurations (TLS 1.2/1.3 enforcement), and data handling training completion records.

The five remaining controls include data classification policy attestations from three department heads (Engineering, Sales, and Customer Success) that are pending signature. These attestations confirm that each department follows the data classification framework when handling confidential information. The attestation forms were distributed on August 28, and two of three have been returned. The Customer Success department head attestation is expected by September 12. The other two remaining controls relate to encryption key management documentation for legacy database clusters, which is the subject of Gap 2 in Section 4 below.

4. IDENTIFIED GAPS AND REMEDIATION PLANS

Three open gaps have been identified during the readiness assessment. Each gap is documented below with its Trust Services Criteria reference, a description of the gap, root cause analysis, remediation plan, and target completion date. None of the three gaps require architectural changes to Nextera's production infrastructure, and all remediation activities are within the team's capacity to complete before the November fieldwork window.

Gap 1: Privileged Access Review Cadence (CC6.1)

Criteria Reference: CC6.1 — The entity restricts logical access to information assets, including logical access to infrastructure, applications, and data, and validates that access on a periodic basis.

Description: Nextera's privileged access review policy requires quarterly reviews of all privileged accounts across AWS IAM, Okta, database superuser accounts, and CI/CD pipeline service accounts. The Q1 2025 and Q3 2025 reviews were completed on schedule. However, the Q2 2025 review, which was due for completion by June 30, was completed on July 11 — eleven days past the scheduled deadline. The review itself was thorough and identified no unauthorized access grants, but the late completion represents a control execution failure that auditors are likely to note.

Root Cause: The primary reviewer for the Q2 privileged access review was out on medical leave from June 10 through July 5. No backup reviewer had been designated in the process documentation, and the review was not reassigned until the primary reviewer returned. The absence was not anticipated to extend through the review deadline, and by the time it became clear that coverage was needed, the deadline had passed.

Remediation Plan: A remediation sprint has been scheduled with the IAM team targeting September 19, 2025 for completion. The sprint deliverables include: (a) updating the privileged access review procedure to designate a primary and backup reviewer for each quarterly cycle; (b) implementing automated calendar reminders at 14, 7, and 3 days before each review deadline; (c) documenting the escalation path if a review is at risk of missing its deadline, with escalation to the Director of Information Security at the 7-day mark; (d) conducting a supplementary access review as of September 15 to demonstrate that the control is operating effectively in the current observation period. The IAM team lead has confirmed that the September quarterly review is already underway and on track for on-time completion.

Gap 2: Encryption Key Rotation for Legacy PostgreSQL Clusters (CC6.7)

Criteria Reference: CC6.7 — The entity restricts the transmission, movement, and removal of information to authorized internal and external users and processes, and protects it during transmission, movement, or removal to meet the entity's objectives.

Description: Nextera rotates application-layer encryption keys on a quarterly cycle using AWS KMS. This process is fully automated, logged in CloudTrail, and documented in the encryption management runbook. However, the database-level encryption keys for two legacy PostgreSQL clusters (postgres-legacy-01 and postgres-legacy-02, both in the us-east-1 region) have been rotated manually on an approximately semi-annual basis. The manual rotation process lacks a formal runbook, and rotation events are not logged in a centralized audit trail. The clusters use PostgreSQL native encryption (pgcrypto) rather than the AWS KMS-integrated encryption used by the newer Aurora PostgreSQL instances.

Kevin Cho, Staff SRE, provided the following technical assessment during the readiness review meeting: "The encryption key rotation issue is a tooling gap, not a design flaw. We rotate application-layer keys quarterly but the database-level rotation was manual and undocumented. — Kevin Cho, Staff SRE"

Root Cause: The two legacy PostgreSQL clusters predate Nextera's migration to Aurora PostgreSQL, which was completed for all other database workloads in Q4 2024. The legacy clusters support two internal tools (the legacy reporting engine and the migration verification service) and were deprioritized for migration because they do not handle customer data directly. Because they were not part of the Aurora migration, they were not included in the automated KMS-based key rotation framework. The manual rotation was performed by the on-call SRE as a periodic maintenance task without formal scheduling or documentation.

Remediation Plan: The SRE team will complete the following by October 1, 2025: (a) create a formal runbook for legacy PostgreSQL encryption key rotation, including step-by-step procedures, verification steps, and rollback instructions; (b) implement logging for all key rotation events to a centralized audit log in CloudWatch, with retention configured for 12 months; (c) schedule quarterly key rotations aligned with the application-layer KMS rotation cycle, with the next rotation to be performed under the new documented process in October; (d) create a Jira ticket template for each scheduled rotation event to provide an audit trail of execution. The two legacy clusters are scheduled for migration to Aurora PostgreSQL in Q1 2026 as part of the legacy decommissioning project, at which point they will inherit the automated KMS-based key rotation and this manual process will be retired.

Gap 3: Incident Response Tabletop Exercise Documentation (CC7.2)

Criteria Reference: CC7.2 — The entity monitors system components and the operation of those components for anomalies that are indicative of malicious acts, natural disasters, and errors affecting the entity's ability to meet its objectives; anomalies are analyzed to determine whether they represent security events.

Description: Nextera's incident response program includes semi-annual tabletop exercises to test the organization's ability to respond to security incidents. The H1 2025 tabletop exercise was conducted on April 14, 2025, with participation from InfoSec, Engineering, SRE, Legal, and Communications teams. The exercise simulated a ransomware attack affecting the us-east-1 production environment. However, the formal documentation package for the exercise was not completed. The required documentation includes the exercise scenario description, full participant list with roles, chronological log of decisions and actions, lessons learned, and follow-up action items with owners and due dates.

Root Cause: The exercise was facilitated by Senior Security Analyst Raj Patel, who departed Nextera on May 16, 2025, for a position at another company. Raj had drafted partial notes during the exercise but had not compiled the formal documentation package before his departure. The incomplete notes were found in Raj's Confluence space after his departure, but they lacked the structured format required by the SOC 2 evidence template. No handoff of the documentation responsibility occurred during Raj's notice period, as the departure was handled by HR and the documentation gap was not identified until the evidence collection process began in August.

Remediation Plan: The InfoSec team will address this gap through two parallel workstreams. First, the H1 2025 tabletop exercise documentation will be reconstructed using the following source materials: the Zoom meeting recording from April 14 (retained in the InfoSec shared drive), Slack channel archives from #incident-response and #tabletop-exercise channels for the day of the exercise, Raj Patel's partial notes in Confluence, and interviews with three participating team leads who have confirmed their availability for a documentation reconstruction session on September 16. Second, the H2 2025 tabletop exercise is scheduled for October 22, 2025, and a comprehensive documentation checklist has been created to ensure real-time capture of all required elements during the exercise. A designated scribe (separate from the facilitator) will be assigned to each future exercise. Jira ticket INFOSEC-2287 has been updated with sub-tasks for both the retroactive H1 documentation and the H2 exercise preparation.

5. OBSERVATION PERIOD AND AUDIT TIMELINE

The formal observation period for the current SOC 2 Type II engagement runs from July 1 through December 31, 2025. Deloitte & Touche LLP has been requested to provide written confirmation of this window, and Nextera expects the confirmation letter by September 15, 2025.

Key milestones in the audit timeline:

    July 1, 2025 — Observation period begins
    September 8, 2025 — Interim readiness report (this document)
    September 12, 2025 — Outstanding attestation statements due from department heads
    September 15, 2025 — Deloitte confirmation of observation period window expected
    September 16, 2025 — H1 tabletop exercise documentation reconstruction session
    September 19, 2025 — CC6.1 remediation sprint completion target
    October 1, 2025 — CC6.7 encryption key rotation documentation and logging implementation target
    October 6, 2025 — Disaster recovery test (us-west-2 failover) scheduled
    October 22, 2025 — H2 2025 incident response tabletop exercise
    November 3, 2025 — Deloitte on-site fieldwork begins (tentative, pending confirmation)
    November 3-14, 2025 — On-site fieldwork window (two weeks)
    December 31, 2025 — Observation period ends
    January 2026 — Deloitte reviews final evidence packages and prepares draft report
    February 2026 — Draft Type II report expected from Deloitte for management review
    March 2026 — Final Type II report issuance target

6. FINANCIAL SUMMARY

The audit fee for the SOC 2 Type II engagement is $185,000, consistent with the FY2024 engagement fee. This amount covers the full Type II examination including planning, interim testing, on-site fieldwork, evidence review, management representation letter processing, and final report issuance. The fee was negotiated during the Q1 2025 engagement letter renewal and is locked for two fiscal years. No additional fees are expected unless the scope of criteria is expanded beyond Security, Availability, and Confidentiality to include Processing Integrity or Privacy.

Internal labor costs for the SOC 2 readiness program are tracked in Jira under INFOSEC-2287. As of September 8, approximately 340 hours of internal labor have been logged across the InfoSec, SRE, Engineering, and IT Governance teams. The total internal labor estimate for the full audit cycle (preparation through report issuance) is 600 hours.

7. CONCLUSION AND NEXT STEPS

Priya Mehta provided the following summary assessment: "We are on track for the Type II audit window. The three open gaps are manageable — none require architectural changes, just process documentation and scheduling. — Priya Mehta"

The InfoSec team will provide a follow-up status report on October 6, 2025, covering remediation progress on all three gaps, updated evidence collection metrics, and preliminary results from the disaster recovery test. The Compliance Committee is asked to review this report and submit any questions or additional information requests by September 15, 2025, so they can be addressed before the Deloitte confirmation call.

Respectfully submitted,
Priya Mehta
Director of Information Security
Nextera Solutions

--- BEGIN DOCUMENT ---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — QUARTERLY VENDOR SECURITY ASSESSMENT
Q3 2025 REVIEW CYCLE
Vendors Under Review: Datadog Inc., PagerDuty Inc., Snowflake Inc.
Prepared by: Marcus Bell, Vendor Risk Analyst
Date: September 8, 2025
Distribution: Procurement, InfoSec, Legal
Document Classification: Internal — Restricted

1. OVERVIEW AND METHODOLOGY

This report documents the Q3 2025 quarterly vendor security assessment for three of Nextera Solutions' critical SaaS infrastructure vendors: Datadog Inc. (application performance monitoring and logging), PagerDuty Inc. (incident management and on-call scheduling), and Snowflake Inc. (cloud data warehouse). These three vendors are classified as Tier 1 critical vendors under Nextera's vendor risk management program, meaning that a significant disruption to any of them would directly impact Nextera's ability to deliver services to customers.

Assessments were conducted using the SIG Lite questionnaire framework, supplemented by review of each vendor's most recent SOC 2 Type II audit report, publicly available security certifications, data processing agreements, and contractual terms. The SIG Lite (Standardized Information Gathering) questionnaire is a streamlined version of the Shared Assessments Program's full SIG questionnaire containing 74 questions across 18 risk domains. Nextera utilizes SIG Lite for Tier 1 and Tier 2 vendors on a quarterly cycle. The full SIG questionnaire (386 questions) is reserved for annual deep-dive assessments and onboarding assessments for new Tier 1 vendors.

Each vendor is scored on a 100-point composite scale that weights the following categories: security program maturity (25%), data protection controls (20%), incident response capabilities (15%), business continuity and resilience (15%), regulatory compliance posture (15%), and contractual protections (10%).

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES

    Marcus Bell, Vendor Risk Analyst — assessment author and vendor risk program owner at Nextera Solutions. Marcus conducts all quarterly vendor assessments and maintains the vendor risk register.

    Datadog Inc. — provides application performance monitoring (APM), log management, infrastructure monitoring, and real-user monitoring (RUM) for Nextera's production environment. Nextera has been a Datadog customer since 2021.

    PagerDuty Inc. — provides incident management, on-call rotation scheduling, escalation workflows, and status page capabilities. Nextera has been a PagerDuty customer since 2019.

    Snowflake Inc. — provides the primary cloud data warehouse for Nextera's analytics, reporting, and data science workloads. Nextera migrated to Snowflake from Amazon Redshift in 2023.

    SIG Lite questionnaire framework — the standardized assessment instrument developed by the Shared Assessments Program, used as the primary data collection tool for Nextera's vendor security reviews.

3. ASSESSMENT RESULTS BY VENDOR

3.1 Datadog Inc.

Vendor Risk Score: 92 out of 100 (Low Risk)
Annual Spend: $412,000
Contract Type: Enterprise subscription, annual commitment
Contract Status: Active, renewal date August 2026
Business Criticality: Tier 1 — Critical Infrastructure

Assessment Process:
SIG Lite questionnaires were distributed to all three vendors on August 25, 2025. Datadog returned the completed assessment on September 3, 2025, which represents 9 calendar days of turnaround — well within the 15-day SLA established in Nextera's vendor risk management policy. Datadog's response was thorough, with all 74 questions answered and 12 supporting documents attached, including their current SOC 2 Type II report, ISO 27001 certificate, penetration testing executive summary, and business continuity plan overview.

SOC 2 Type II Report Review:
Datadog's most recent SOC 2 Type II report is dated June 2025 and covers the observation period January 1 through December 31, 2024. The report was issued by Ernst & Young LLP. No exceptions were noted in the examination. The report covers all five Trust Services Criteria (Security, Availability, Processing Integrity, Confidentiality, and Privacy).

The subservice organization carve-outs in the report are unchanged from the prior year. Datadog carves out the following subservice organizations: Amazon Web Services (primary infrastructure hosting), Google Cloud Platform (secondary infrastructure hosting), and Salesforce (customer relationship management). Nextera's review confirmed that the complementary user entity controls (CUECs) applicable to Nextera have not changed and that Nextera's current practices satisfy the CUECs.

Security Certifications and Compliance:
Datadog maintains ISO 27001 certification, which was re-certified in April 2025 by BSI Group. Datadog also maintains SOC 2 Type II attestation (described above), SOC 3 report (publicly available), CSA STAR Level 2 certification, HIPAA compliance (BAA available for eligible customers), and GDPR compliance attestation. Datadog's security program is mature, well-documented, and externally validated through multiple independent assessments.

Data Handling:
Datadog's data retention policy allows customers to configure retention periods for different data types. Nextera's current configuration retains APM trace data for 15 days, log data for 30 days, and infrastructure metrics for 15 months. These settings are consistent with Nextera's internal data retention policy and the SOC 2 evidence retention requirements. All data transmitted to Datadog is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2 or higher, and data at rest is encrypted using AES-256.

Scoring Breakdown: Security program (24/25), Data protection (19/20), Incident response (14/15), Business continuity (14/15), Regulatory compliance (14/15), Contractual protections (7/10). Total: 92/100.

Recommendation: Maintain current vendor relationship. No action items.

3.2 PagerDuty Inc.

Vendor Risk Score: 87 out of 100 (Low Risk)
Annual Spend: $78,000
Contract Type: Enterprise subscription, annual commitment
Contract Status: Active, renewal date October 15, 2025
Business Criticality: Tier 1 — Critical Infrastructure

Assessment Process:
SIG Lite questionnaire was distributed on August 25, 2025. PagerDuty returned the completed assessment on September 5, 2025 (11 calendar days, within the 15-day SLA). PagerDuty's response addressed all questions and included their SOC 2 Type II report and updated data processing addendum.

SOC 2 Type II Report Review:
PagerDuty's most recent SOC 2 Type II report covers the observation period January 1 through June 30, 2025. PagerDuty issues SOC 2 reports on a semi-annual basis, which provides more frequent attestation than the typical annual cycle. No exceptions were noted in the report. The report covers Security, Availability, and Confidentiality Trust Services Criteria.

Data Processing Addendum (DPA) Update:
PagerDuty issued an updated DPA effective September 1, 2025. The primary change in the updated DPA is a revised sub-processor list. Two new sub-processor entities have been added, both located in the European Union:

    (1) CloudServe GmbH (Frankfurt, Germany) — a cloud infrastructure provider used for PagerDuty's EU data residency option. This sub-processor handles compute and storage for PagerDuty customers who have selected the EU data residency configuration.

    (2) AnalyticsBridge Ltd. (Dublin, Ireland) — an analytics services company providing aggregate usage telemetry processing. This sub-processor receives anonymized, aggregated usage data for PagerDuty's product analytics and does not process customer-specific incident data.

While neither sub-processor handles Nextera customer data directly (Nextera's PagerDuty instance is hosted in the US and does not use the EU data residency option), the revised sub-processor list represents a material change to the DPA that requires legal review per Nextera's vendor management policy. The addition of any new sub-processor, regardless of whether Nextera data flows to that sub-processor, triggers a mandatory legal review to assess potential GDPR implications and confirm that the contractual flow-down provisions remain adequate.

Action Required: Legal must review and sign off on PagerDuty's revised DPA before the October 15, 2025 contract renewal. The contract includes an auto-renewal clause that triggers 30 days before the renewal date, so the DPA review must be completed by September 15 to allow time for any negotiation if needed.

Operational Performance:
PagerDuty's status page shows 99.98% uptime over the trailing 12 months, exceeding their contractual SLA commitment of 99.9%. There were two brief service degradations in the trailing period: a 12-minute partial API latency spike on March 18, 2025, and a 23-minute notification delivery delay on June 2, 2025. Neither incident resulted in missed notifications for Nextera, and PagerDuty published detailed postmortem reports for both incidents.

Scoring Breakdown: Security program (22/25), Data protection (18/20), Incident response (14/15), Business continuity (13/15), Regulatory compliance (13/15), Contractual protections (7/10). Total: 87/100.

Recommendation: Maintain current vendor relationship. Complete legal review of revised DPA before October 15 renewal.

3.3 Snowflake Inc.

Vendor Risk Score: 94 out of 100 (Low Risk)
Annual Spend: $1.34M
Contract Type: Enterprise capacity commitment, annual
Contract Status: Active, renewal date January 15, 2026
Business Criticality: Tier 1 — Critical Infrastructure

Assessment Process:
SIG Lite questionnaire was distributed on August 25, 2025. Snowflake requested a 10-day extension on September 4, 2025, citing internal resource scheduling constraints related to their annual security certification renewal cycle. Expected completion date: September 18, 2025. The extension request was granted, given Snowflake's strong historical assessment performance and the fact that the extended deadline falls within the quarterly review period. Snowflake has received scores of 93, 94, and 95 in the prior three quarterly assessments.

FedRAMP Authorization:
Snowflake's FedRAMP Moderate authorization was confirmed as active through March 2026. The authorization is maintained through the FedRAMP Program Management Office's continuous monitoring program, which requires monthly vulnerability scanning, quarterly reporting, and annual assessment. Snowflake's most recent continuous monitoring submission was reviewed in July 2025 with no findings. While Nextera does not currently require FedRAMP authorization for its vendor relationships (Nextera is not a federal contractor), the FedRAMP certification provides substantial additional assurance regarding Snowflake's security controls, vulnerability management, incident response, and governance practices, as FedRAMP Moderate requires compliance with 325 security controls derived from NIST SP 800-53.

SOC 2 Type II Report:
Snowflake's most recent Type II report, covering the observation period July 1, 2024, through June 30, 2025, is expected to be available by October 2025. The prior year report (July 2023 through June 2024) contained no exceptions. Nextera will review the updated report during the Q4 vendor review cycle in December 2025.

Contract Renewal Preparation:
The January 15, 2026 contract renewal represents Nextera's largest single SaaS vendor renewal by spend. Snowflake's consumption-based pricing model means that actual costs can vary from the committed capacity, and Nextera's consumption has tracked approximately 8% above committed capacity for the past two quarters. Procurement has been notified of the renewal timeline and will begin vendor negotiation preparation in November 2025, with the goal of securing a volume discount that reflects Nextera's growth trajectory.

Scoring Breakdown: Security program (24/25), Data protection (20/20), Incident response (14/15), Business continuity (15/15), Regulatory compliance (14/15), Contractual protections (7/10). Total: 94/100. (Note: final score pending completion of SIG Lite questionnaire; preliminary score based on prior assessment data and available documentation.)

Recommendation: Maintain current vendor relationship. Complete review of updated SOC 2 report in Q4 cycle. Begin renewal negotiation preparation in November.

4. OVERALL RISK ASSESSMENT AND SUMMARY

Marcus Bell provided the following summary assessment: "All three vendors remain within acceptable risk tolerance. The only action item is legal sign-off on PagerDuty's revised DPA before the October renewal. — Marcus Bell"

Vendor Risk Score Summary:

No vendors assessed in this cycle require escalation to the Compliance Committee or placement on the vendor risk watch list. All three vendors maintain robust security programs with independent third-party attestation and no material concerns were identified.

DOCUMENT 3 OF 3
Type: IT Governance Policy Update
Title: IT Policy Refresh — Acceptable Use Policy v4.2 and Remote Access Policy v3.1
Author: Diana Rosales, IT Governance Manager
Date: 2025-09-08
Recipients: All Employees (via Confluence)
Classification: Internal

--- BEGIN DOCUMENT ---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — IT POLICY REFRESH BULLETIN
EFFECTIVE DATE: September 8, 2025

POLICIES UPDATED:
    1. Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) — Version 4.2 (replaces v4.1)
    2. Remote Access Policy (RAP) — Version 3.1 (replaces v3.0)

Prepared by: Diana Rosales, IT Governance Manager
Approved by: Nextera IT Governance Committee
Distribution: All Employees (published via Confluence, email notification sent)
Document Classification: Internal

TO ALL NEXTERA SOLUTIONS EMPLOYEES:

This bulletin notifies you of updates to two IT governance policies that affect all employees. Please read this bulletin carefully and acknowledge the updated policies by the deadline specified below.

1. PURPOSE AND SCOPE

The Nextera IT Governance Committee has approved updates to the Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) and the Remote Access Policy (RAP). Both updated policies take effect on September 8, 2025 and apply to all Nextera Solutions employees, contractors, and temporary workers who access Nextera information systems, networks, applications, or data, regardless of whether access occurs from corporate offices, remote locations, or personal devices.

The policies are published in their entirety on Confluence at the following locations:
    AUP v4.2: confluence.nextera.io/policies/acceptable-use-v4.2
    RAP v3.1: confluence.nextera.io/policies/remote-access-v3.1

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES AND SYSTEMS

    Diana Rosales, IT Governance Manager — policy author and IT governance program owner

    Nextera IT Governance Committee — the cross-functional committee responsible for reviewing, approving, and overseeing IT policies at Nextera Solutions. Committee membership includes representatives from IT Operations, Information Security, Legal, Human Resources, Engineering, and Finance. The committee meets monthly and conducts policy reviews on a semi-annual cycle or as needed when material changes in technology, regulation, or business operations warrant interim updates.

    Okta — Nextera's Single Sign-On (SSO) and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) provider. All access to corporate applications is brokered through Okta, and MFA is enforced for all users regardless of access location or device type. Okta serves as the identity provider for approximately 85 corporate SaaS applications.

    CrowdStrike Falcon — Nextera's endpoint detection and response (EDR) platform. CrowdStrike Falcon is deployed on all corporate-managed devices (laptops and workstations) and is now required on personal devices enrolled in the BYOD program. The Falcon agent provides real-time threat detection, behavioral analysis, and device health attestation.

3. ACCEPTABLE USE POLICY v4.2 — DETAILED SUMMARY OF CHANGES

The Acceptable Use Policy has been updated from version 4.1 (effective March 15, 2025) to version 4.2. Version 4.1 addressed general information system usage, email and messaging standards, internet usage, personal use of corporate resources, and data handling. Version 4.2 retains all existing sections and adds one new section and modifies one existing section as described below.

3.1 Section 7.4 — Generative AI Tool Usage (NEW SECTION)

This is the most significant change in the v4.2 update. The new section establishes Nextera's policy governing employee use of generative AI tools for work purposes. The key provisions are:

    (a) Employees must use only generative AI tools that appear on the Nextera Internal AI Registry when performing work-related tasks, accessing company data, or producing work product intended for use in Nextera's business operations.

    (b) The AI Registry is maintained by the IT Governance team and published on Confluence at confluence.nextera.io/it-governance/ai-registry. The registry is reviewed monthly by the IT Governance Committee, and tools may be added or removed based on security assessments, contractual terms, and business needs.

    (c) As of September 8, 2025, the AI Registry includes the following 11 approved tools:

        1. GitHub Copilot — code completion and generation (Engineering department, IDE integration)
        2. ChatGPT Enterprise — general-purpose language model (OpenAI, enterprise license with data isolation)
        3. Grammarly Business — writing assistance and grammar checking (all departments)
        4. Jasper AI — marketing content generation (Marketing department)
        5. Notion AI — document drafting and summarization (all departments, integrated with Nextera's Notion workspace)
        6. Otter.ai — meeting transcription and summarization (all departments)
        7. Midjourney — image generation (Marketing department only, brand asset creation)
        8. Anthropic Claude for Business — general-purpose language model (enterprise license, all departments)
        9. Databricks AI/BI — data analysis and business intelligence (Analytics team, restricted access)
        10. Amazon CodeWhisperer — code completion (Engineering department, AWS-integrated workflows)
        11. Tableau AI — visualization and insight generation (Analytics and Business Intelligence teams)

    (d) Employees are prohibited from entering Nextera proprietary data, customer data, personally identifiable information (PII), protected health information (PHI), or confidential business information into any AI tool not on the approved registry. This prohibition applies regardless of whether the tool offers enterprise-grade data isolation or contractual confidentiality protections.

    (e) Employees who identify a generative AI tool they believe should be added to the registry may submit a request through the IT self-service portal in ServiceNow. The IT Governance team will conduct a security and privacy assessment of the tool within 15 business days of the request and communicate the decision to the requesting employee.

    (f) Violations of this section will be handled through the standard information security incident response process. First-time violations resulting from use of unapproved tools where no sensitive data was exposed will be addressed through education and counseling. Violations involving exposure of sensitive data will be escalated per the data breach response plan.

Diana Rosales provided the following context for this policy addition: "The AI usage additions reflect the reality that 68% of our engineering staff reported using at least one generative AI tool in the Q2 survey. We need guardrails, not bans. — Diana Rosales"

Background on the Q2 2025 AI Usage Survey:
The Q2 2025 internal survey on AI tool usage was conducted across all departments from June 1-15, 2025, with a 72% response rate (288 of 398 employees). Key findings from the survey:
    — 68% of engineering employees reported using at least one generative AI tool for work purposes
    — 42% of non-engineering employees reported using at least one generative AI tool for work purposes
    — Of all AI tool users, approximately 30% reported using at least one tool that was not on any approved list at the time of the survey
    — The most commonly used unapproved tools were personal ChatGPT accounts (not the Enterprise version), Google Gemini, and various open-source code generation tools
    — 89% of AI tool users said they would comply with an approved registry as long as the registry included "the tools that actually work"

The IT Governance Committee considered the survey results during its July 2025 meeting and directed Diana Rosales to develop the AI registry and policy language that is now incorporated into AUP v4.2.

3.2 Section 3.2 — Personal Device Usage (MODIFIED)

The existing language on personal device usage has been updated to align with the new BYOD enrollment requirements introduced in Remote Access Policy v3.1. The modified language specifies that employees who access corporate SaaS applications from personal devices must enroll those devices in the Nextera BYOD program. The enrollment process and requirements are detailed in the Remote Access Policy and summarized in Section 5 of this bulletin.

BYOD enrollment is currently at 34% of the Nextera workforce. The IT Governance Committee has established a target of 80% enrollment by the end of Q4 2025. The gap between current enrollment and the target is concentrated in the Sales and Marketing departments, where personal device usage for accessing corporate applications (particularly Salesforce, Slack, and email) is most common. A targeted enrollment campaign for Sales and Marketing will be conducted in October 2025.

4. REMOTE ACCESS POLICY v3.1 — DETAILED SUMMARY OF CHANGES

The Remote Access Policy has been updated from version 3.0 (effective January 10, 2025) to version 3.1. The primary changes are the addition of a pre-connect endpoint verification requirement and a new BYOD device enrollment section.

4.1 Section 4.1 — Endpoint Verification Before VPN Establishment (MODIFIED)

Effective September 8, 2025, all VPN connections to the Nextera corporate network require that the connecting device has the CrowdStrike Falcon agent installed, running, and reporting a healthy status before the VPN tunnel is established. Under the previous policy (RAP v3.0), CrowdStrike verification was performed after VPN connection as a post-connect health check — meaning that a device could briefly access the corporate network before the health check determined whether it met security requirements. The updated policy moves verification to the pre-connect stage, implementing a "verify-then-connect" model.

The pre-connect verification is implemented through Okta's Device Trust integration with CrowdStrike. When an employee initiates a VPN connection, the VPN client communicates with Okta, which queries the CrowdStrike cloud API to verify that: (a) the Falcon agent is installed on the connecting device, (b) the agent is running and communicating with the CrowdStrike cloud, (c) the agent's sensor version is within the supported version range, and (d) no critical unresolved security alerts exist for the device. If any of these checks fail, the VPN connection is denied and the employee receives a notification with instructions for remediation.

The estimated daily volume of remote access sessions requiring CrowdStrike verification is approximately 2,400 sessions per day across approximately 400 employees. This estimate is based on the average of 6 VPN sessions per remote employee per day, including session reconnections and timeouts, as observed in Q2 2025 VPN usage logs. The Engineering department accounts for approximately 45% of daily VPN sessions, followed by Sales (25%), Customer Success (15%), and other departments (15%).

Pilot Program Results:
The pre-connect verification was tested in a pilot program with the Engineering department during August 2025. The pilot ran for two weeks (August 11-22) and covered approximately 180 employees. Results: zero false denials (no legitimate connections were incorrectly blocked), 3 true denials (employees with outdated Falcon agent versions, resolved within same day through self-service update), and average connection time increase of 0.4 seconds (within acceptable UX threshold). Based on the successful pilot, the IT Governance Committee approved the rollout to all departments.

4.2 Section 5.3 — BYOD Device Enrollment (NEW SECTION)

A new section specifies the requirements and process for personal device enrollment when accessing corporate SaaS applications. The enrollment process is designed to balance security requirements with employee convenience:

    Step 1: Employee submits BYOD enrollment request through the IT self-service portal in ServiceNow. The request form collects device type, operating system version, and intended use case.

    Step 2: IT Operations verifies device compatibility against the following minimum requirements: macOS 13 (Ventura) or later, Windows 11 or later, iOS 16 or later, Android 13 or later. Devices running older operating systems are not eligible for BYOD enrollment due to security limitations.

    Step 3: Employee installs the CrowdStrike Falcon agent and Okta Verify application on the personal device. Installation instructions are provided through the ServiceNow ticket and are also available on the IT support Confluence page. For macOS and iOS devices, installation is facilitated through Jamf Pro. For Windows and Android devices, installation is facilitated through Microsoft Intune.

    Step 4: IT Operations validates that the CrowdStrike agent and Okta Verify are installed, running, and reporting correctly. This validation is performed remotely through Jamf Pro (for macOS/iOS) or Microsoft Intune (for Windows/Android).

    Step 5: Employee signs the BYOD terms of service via DocuSign. The terms of service acknowledge that: corporate data on the personal device may be remotely wiped in the event of device loss, theft, or employment termination; IT Operations may collect device health telemetry (OS version, agent status, encryption status) but will not access personal files, photos, messages, or browsing history; and the employee is responsible for maintaining the device's operating system at a supported version.

    Step 6: Upon completion of all steps, the device is added to the Okta device trust registry, enabling the employee to access corporate SaaS applications (Salesforce, Slack, Jira, Confluence, Gmail, etc.) from the enrolled device.

Enforcement Timeline:
Employees who do not enroll personal devices used for corporate access by the end of Q4 2025 will have access to corporate SaaS applications restricted from those devices. Access from corporate-managed devices (issued by Nextera IT) will not be affected. A 30-day grace period will follow the Q4 deadline before enforcement begins.

5. POLICY ACKNOWLEDGMENT REQUIREMENTS

All Nextera Solutions employees are required to acknowledge both updated policies by September 22, 2025. The acknowledgment process is as follows:

    (a) A DocuSign envelope will be sent to each employee's corporate email address on September 8, 2025, containing a single acknowledgment form covering both policies.

    (b) The acknowledgment form includes a brief summary of the key changes in each policy and a certification statement reading: "I have read and understand the Acceptable Use Policy v4.2 and the Remote Access Policy v3.1. I agree to comply with both policies as a condition of my continued access to Nextera Solutions information systems and resources."

    (c) Employees are expected to read the full policy documents on Confluence before signing the acknowledgment. The acknowledgment form includes direct links to both policy documents.

    (d) The deadline for acknowledgment is September 22, 2025, at 5:00 PM Pacific Time.

    (e) Employees who have not acknowledged by the deadline will receive automated reminder emails on September 19 and September 22. After the deadline, non-acknowledging employees will be reported to their department managers and HR business partners for follow-up per the standard compliance escalation process.

The prior version of the Acceptable Use Policy (v4.1) achieved a 96.3% acknowledgment rate within the two-week deadline. The remaining 3.7% of employees acknowledged within 5 business days of the deadline after manager follow-up. The IT Governance Committee expects a similar acknowledgment rate for the current update.

6. TRAINING AND SUPPORT

Training sessions on the new generative AI usage guidelines will be offered during the weeks of September 15 and September 22. Sessions are organized as follows:

    Engineering Staff Sessions:
    — September 16, 11:00 AM PT (60 minutes, covers GitHub Copilot, CodeWhisperer, and ChatGPT Enterprise usage guidelines)
    — September 18, 2:00 PM PT (repeat session)

    Non-Engineering Staff Sessions:
    — September 17, 10:00 AM PT (45 minutes, covers ChatGPT Enterprise, Grammarly Business, Notion AI, and Otter.ai usage guidelines)
    — September 22, 1:00 PM PT (repeat session)

All sessions will be recorded and posted to Confluence for employees who cannot attend live. Attendance is encouraged but not mandatory; the policy acknowledgment is the formal compliance requirement.

For questions about the updated policies, employees may contact:
    Slack: #it-governance
    Email: it-governance@nextera.io
    ServiceNow: IT Governance category

Diana Rosales
IT Governance Manager
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: January 30, 2025
FROM: Hannah Choi, VP Product
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: Nextera Partners with Axion Labs for Real-Time Logistics Data
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-PROD-2025-006

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
PRODUCT PARTNERSHIP ANNOUNCEMENT

To: All Nextera Employees
From: Hannah Choi, VP Product
Date: January 30, 2025

I'm thrilled to announce that Nextera Solutions has signed a product partnership with Axion Labs to integrate their real-time logistics data into our analytics platform.

After a rigorous four-week technical evaluation, we have signed a 3-year commercial agreement with Axion Labs to bring their industry-leading real-time logistics data feed into the Nextera platform. This is a significant product investment that will give our customers access to the broadest and highest-quality logistics data available.

WHAT THIS MEANS

Axion Labs operates the most comprehensive real-time logistics data platform in the market. Their data feed covers 340+ shipping lanes globally — compared to our current coverage of 220 lanes. Their data is fresher (15-minute updates vs. 30 minutes from our current providers), more accurate (99.8% schema compliance), and faster to access (180ms average API latency vs. 290ms from our current provider).

This partnership is about one thing: giving our customers the best possible data for supply chain decision-making. Axion has the best real-time logistics data product on the market, period.

By integrating Axion's data into our platform, we will:
1. Expand shipping lane coverage by 55% (from 220 to 340+ lanes)
2. Improve data freshness by 2x across all logistics data dimensions
3. Enable real-time port congestion analytics for 340 ports globally
4. Provide vessel tracking data integrated with our recommendation engine
5. Deliver maritime weather overlays for route optimization

TIMELINE

The integration is underway. Here's the plan:

- Integration sprint: February 3 - February 28 (4 weeks, already started)
- Internal demo: February 28
- Customer beta launch: June 2025
- GA launch: September 2025

The integration team consists of 8 Nextera engineers plus 4 Axion engineers who will be working from our San Francisco office during the sprint. All 18 Axion API endpoints will be integrated into our analytics platform.

LEADERSHIP

Kai Brennan, CEO of Axion Labs, and I will be publishing a joint blog post next week announcing the partnership to the broader market. The press release has been distributed to supply chain trade publications and the embargo lifts February 3, 2025.

David Aldric: "This is exactly the kind of strategic product investment that defines Nextera. We partner to build, not to sell."

Kai Brennan: "Nextera is the clear leader in supply chain intelligence, and we're honored to bring our data to their platform. This partnership will create enormous value for the supply chain industry."

ABOUT AXION LABS

Axion Labs is a Series B startup headquartered in Austin, Texas. They have raised $45M in total funding and employ approximately 80 people. Their core product is a real-time logistics data platform that aggregates data from maritime AIS signals, port authorities, customs agencies, and satellite imagery to provide comprehensive shipping lane and port status data.

Their leadership team includes:
- Kai Brennan, CEO and co-founder (previously VP Data Products at FourKites)
- James Whitworth, CTO and co-founder (previously Principal Engineer at Amazon Logistics)
- Maria Santos, VP Business Development (previously Director at project44)

WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW

1. This is a product partnership, not a corporate transaction. Nextera and Axion Labs remain independent companies.
2. The integration will not require changes to any customer's existing Nextera deployment. The Axion data will be available as an additional data layer in the analytics platform.
3. Customers will be able to opt in to the Axion data features during the beta period. There may be a premium pricing tier for enhanced logistics data access — product and sales teams will finalize pricing by May.
4. The partnership commercial terms are a 3-year agreement with mutual renewal options.

INTEGRATION DETAILS

For those interested in the technical details, here's how the integration will work:

Architecture:
- Axion's API endpoints will be consumed by a dedicated Nextera microservice ("axion-ingestion-service")
- Real-time data flows through our existing Kafka infrastructure (topic: nextera.axion.logistics.raw)
- Data is processed by our standard ETL pipeline and stored in Snowflake for analytics
- Dashboard frontend will add new visualization components for the Axion data layers
- The recommendation engine v3 will be updated in a future release to incorporate Axion data as an input signal

Integration team (Nextera side):
- Tyler Kim (Platform Engineer, Lead)
- Raj Patel (Senior Engineer, API integration)
- Devi Krishnan (Data Engineer, data pipeline)
- Carlos Rivera (Software Engineer, backend services)
- Amara Williams (Senior Engineer, infrastructure)
- Fatima Al-Rashid (ML Engineer, data quality validation)
- Ethan Novak (Software Engineer, frontend dashboard)
- Grace Zhou (QA Engineer, testing)

Integration team (Axion side — visiting San Francisco Feb 3-28):
- Two backend engineers
- One data engineer
- One product manager

Sprint cadence:
- Week 1 (Feb 3-7): Core API connectivity, authentication, basic data flow
- Week 2 (Feb 10-14): Full endpoint integration (all 18 endpoints)
- Week 3 (Feb 17-21): Data quality validation, error handling, monitoring
- Week 4 (Feb 24-28): End-to-end testing, internal demo preparation

CUSTOMER IMPACT ASSESSMENT

Product marketing has conducted a preliminary assessment of customer impact:

- Estimated customer interest: 60-70% of enterprise customers will want access to the enhanced logistics data
- Upsell potential: $15-25/user/month premium for Axion data access (pricing TBD)
- Estimated incremental ARR from Axion features at full adoption: $4-6M/year
- Customer beta participants targeted: 30-40 accounts
- Customer beta waitlist (already expressed interest): 12 accounts

Competitive impact:
- Nextera will have the broadest logistics data coverage of any supply chain analytics platform in the market
- Kinaxis covers approximately 180 shipping lanes (vs. our new 340+)
- Palantir's data coverage varies by deployment but typically covers 200-250 lanes
- Blue Yonder relies on customer-provided data and does not have a native logistics data feed

This partnership positions Nextera as the clear data leader in our category. Product marketing will update all competitive battle cards by February 10.

PRESS AND MEDIA

Press release distributed to the following publications (embargo lifts February 3):
- Supply Chain Dive
- Logistics Management
- FreightWaves
- TechCrunch
- The Information
- Bloomberg (tech reporter)

Joint blog post (authored by Kai Brennan and Hannah Choi) publishing February 3 on both companies' blogs.

Social media coordination:
- Nextera LinkedIn post: February 3, 9 AM EST
- Nextera Twitter post: February 3, 9 AM EST
- Axion Labs will cross-post on their channels
- Employees are encouraged to share and engage with the posts

If you have questions about the partnership, please join the Q&A session I'm hosting on February 3 at 2 PM in the main auditorium, or reach out to the product team via #product on Slack.

Hannah Choi
VP Product
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: January 30, 2025
FROM: Priya Vasquez, CFO
TO: Jordan Michaels (VP Finance), Angela Torres (Controller)
SUBJECT: Vendor Contract Guidance — Updated Policy
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — Finance Leadership Only
REFERENCE: NXS-FIN-2025-006

---

From: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
Date: January 30, 2025, 7:45 AM PST
To: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>; Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
Subject: Vendor Contract Guidance — Updated Policy

Jordan, Angela,

Effective immediately, please do not approve any new vendor contracts or renewals with terms exceeding 18 months without my explicit written approval.

This applies to all vendor categories — infrastructure, software, professional services, facilities, and any other vendor commitments. The only exception is the AWS 3-year contract that was already executed on January 15 — that agreement is grandfathered.

Specific action items:

1. Jordan — update the renewal tracker to flag all contracts with terms over 18 months. I want to review each one individually. This includes contracts that are currently in negotiation (Snowflake, Datadog) and any that come up for renewal in the remainder of Q1 and Q2.

2. Angela — for any contracts currently in the approval pipeline that have terms exceeding 18 months, please hold them until I can review. Do not execute.

3. For contracts under 18 months, the existing approval workflow (manager → VP → CFO for >$100K) remains unchanged.

This is a financial discipline measure. We want maximum flexibility in our vendor commitments going forward. Please communicate this to your teams as a budgetary best practice.

A few specific notes:

Snowflake renewal: Currently structured as a 36-month term at 12% volume discount. This now requires my review before execution. Please pause the negotiation until I can assess whether we should restructure to a shorter term.

Datadog renewal: The 36-month commitment at 15% discount was approved by me before this policy change. However, given the new guidance, I'd like to re-evaluate the term length. Please reach out to the Datadog account team about restructuring to 18 months. We may lose the discount, but I want to understand the cost differential.

New vendor onboarding: Any new vendor contract should default to a 12-month term unless there is a compelling pricing justification for a longer commitment. All new vendor contracts over $50K/year require my review regardless of term length.

Effective date: January 30, 2025
Policy scope: All vendor contracts and renewals company-wide
Exception: AWS 3-year contract (already executed, grandfathered)

Additional context: I've been reviewing our vendor commitment profile as part of our overall financial strategy. Having long-term vendor commitments is generally good for pricing, but it reduces our flexibility. In a fast-moving market, I want us to have the ability to adjust our vendor mix quickly if our needs change.

This is not about any specific vendor relationship — it's a general financial discipline that I want to institutionalize across the organization. Many of our peer companies (I've benchmarked against 8 enterprise SaaS companies in our revenue range) have adopted similar policies, with maximum vendor commitment terms of 12-24 months.

The formal vendor management policy will include:

1. Maximum term: 18 months without CFO written approval
2. Preferred term: 12 months for all new vendor relationships
3. Exception process: written request to CFO with justification for longer terms (e.g., significant pricing benefit, strategic importance)
4. Renewal review: all renewals >$50K require finance team review 60 days before expiration
5. Contract flexibility: all new contracts should include a termination for convenience clause with 90-day notice
6. Assignability: all new contracts should include an assignability clause allowing Nextera to assign the contract to an affiliate or successor entity

On the assignability clause specifically — this is a standard enterprise SaaS best practice. Nathan Foley in legal has confirmed that our standard vendor contract template already includes this language, but about 30% of our existing contracts were signed using vendor paper and may not have it. I'd like Nathan to do a spot-check on our top 20 vendor contracts to verify assignability provisions are in place.

I'll update the formal vendor management policy document on the intranet by end of week. In the meantime, please treat this email as the operative guidance.

Priya

---

From: Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
Date: January 30, 2025, 9:38 AM PST
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
Subject: RE: Vendor Contract Guidance — Updated Policy

Priya,

Quick follow-up: I ran a preliminary analysis of the financial impact of restructuring our top vendor commitments to shorter terms.

Impact analysis — switching from 36-month to 12-month terms on major vendors:

Vendor          Current Term    Current Discount    12-month Discount    Annual Cost Increase
Snowflake       36-month        12%                 0%                   $252K
Datadog         36-month        15%                 3%                   $72K
MongoDB         24-month        8%                  3%                   $12K
Confluent       24-month        6%                  0%                   $10.8K
LaunchDarkly    24-month        10%                 0%                   $9.6K
Others (8)      Various         Various             Various              ~$40K

Total estimated annual cost increase from term restructuring: ~$396K

For perspective, $396K per year is approximately 0.4% of our total operating expense budget. The flexibility benefit may justify this cost, but I want to make sure you have the full picture.

Also noting: the termination for convenience clause and the assignability clause are important additions to our standard terms. I'll work with Nathan Foley to ensure these are included in all ongoing and future negotiations.

Angela

From: Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
Date: January 30, 2025, 8:22 AM PST
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>
CC: Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
Subject: RE: Vendor Contract Guidance — Updated Policy

Priya,

Understood. I'll update the renewal tracker today to flag all contracts with terms exceeding 18 months. Quick question: for the Snowflake renewal, we had verbal agreement with their enterprise team on the 36-month / 12% discount structure. If we restructure to 12 or 18 months, we'll likely lose the full 12% discount. Snowflake typically offers:

- 12-month term: 0% discount (standard pricing)
- 18-month term: 5-7% discount
- 24-month term: 8-10% discount
- 36-month term: 12-15% discount

At our current Snowflake spend of $2.1M/year, the difference between a 12-month term (0% discount) and the 36-month term (12% discount) is approximately $252K/year. Over 3 years, that's $756K in additional cost.

Do you want me to proceed with the shorter term despite the cost increase, or should we discuss?

Jordan
