DOCUMENT TYPE: All-Hands Meeting Transcript
DATE: February 14, 2025
PRESENTER: David Aldric, Chief Executive Officer
ATTENDEES: All Employees
SUBJECT: February All-Hands — Rec Engine v3 Launch Celebration
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-AH-2025-004

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
FEBRUARY ALL-HANDS MEETING — REC ENGINE V3 LAUNCH CELEBRATION
FULL TRANSCRIPT

Date: February 14, 2025
Format: In-person (main auditorium) + Zoom
Attendees: 362 in-person, 48 remote (410 total)
Duration: 65 minutes (longest all-hands this year)
Recording: Available on intranet

[MEETING BEGINS]

DAVID ALDRIC (CEO): Good afternoon, Nextera! Happy Valentine's Day! And more importantly — happy launch day!

[applause]

Today is a great day. Rec engine v3 is live and our customers are already seeing results. This is what it looks like when a team executes at the highest level.

I want to start by recognizing the people who made this happen. Marcus, Sami, Raj — your engineering team has been working on v3 for eight months. From concept to GA in eight months, with 3,350 tests passing, zero P1 bugs, and performance that exceeded every single target we set. Throughput 15% above target. Latency at p99 of 220ms against a 300ms target. This is world-class engineering.

Let me bring Marcus up to give us a live demo.

MARCUS WEBB (VP Engineering): Thanks, David. I'm going to show you rec engine v3 running live with anonymized customer data. Let me share my screen.

[screen share begins]

What you're seeing here is the v3 recommendation dashboard for a logistics company — anonymized, of course. The company operates 14 shipping lanes between North America and Europe. Let me walk you through what v3 does differently from v2.

First — speed. I'm going to run a route optimization query across all 14 lanes. Watch the response time in the bottom right corner. [clicks] There it is — 142 milliseconds. In v2, this same query took approximately 400 milliseconds. That's a 65% improvement in response time.

Second — accuracy. The v3 recommendation engine uses a new sparse matrix processing algorithm that Raj Patel's team developed. It can handle datasets with 95% sparsity — which is typical for international shipping lane data — without the computational overhead of traditional matrix operations. The result is recommendations that are 23% more accurate than v2 as measured by backtesting against historical shipping decisions.

Third — scale. V3 can process 1,150 queries per second, up from 720 in v2. That means we can serve our largest customers — companies with hundreds of shipping lanes and thousands of daily routing decisions — without any degradation in performance.

Let me show you one more thing. I'm going to simulate a port congestion event at Rotterdam and show how v3 automatically generates alternative route recommendations.

[demonstrates port congestion simulation]

See that? Within 200 milliseconds of detecting the congestion signal, v3 generated three alternative routing options, each with estimated cost impact and delivery time comparison. This is the kind of real-time supply chain intelligence that no other platform can deliver.

[applause]

DAVID ALDRIC: Incredible, Marcus. Thank you. Now let me bring Hannah up for the product roadmap.

HANNAH CHOI (VP Product): Thank you, David. I want to give everyone a preview of what's coming for the rest of the year. Our product roadmap is the most ambitious in Nextera's history.

Q1 (current):
- Rec engine v3 GA — DONE! Shipping today.
- Axion Labs data integration — on track for internal demo February 28, customer beta June, GA September
- Supply chain dashboard redesign — on track for March GA

Q2 (April-June):
- Axion data features beta launch (June)
- NLP query interface — inspired by the hackathon winning project "ChainWhisperer," we're fast-tracking a natural language query capability
- Mobile app redesign — first major mobile update in 18 months
- API v3 with GraphQL support

Q3 (July-September):
- Axion data features GA (September)
- Predictive supply chain disruption module — new ML capability
- Multi-language support (Spanish, German, Mandarin, Japanese)
- Customer self-service analytics builder

Q4 (October-December):
- Next-generation recommendation engine (v4 planning begins)
- AI-powered contract analysis for supply chain agreements
- Platform marketplace for third-party integrations

This roadmap reflects approximately $42M in R&D investment and the efforts of our 150-person engineering team and 22-person product team.

A few additional product highlights:

The hackathon winning project "ChainWhisperer" is being fast-tracked into the product evaluation process. For those who weren't at the hackathon demos, the ChainWhisperer team — Fatima Al-Rashid, Carlos Rivera, Ethan Novak, and Owen Park — built a natural language query interface in 24 hours that can translate plain English questions into supply chain analytics queries. During the demo, they showed queries like "which shipping lanes had the highest delay rates in January?" and the system generated the correct API calls and returned formatted results in under 2 seconds. If the product evaluation confirms market fit, we'll target a beta release in Q3.

The supply chain dashboard redesign is also progressing well. Ben Arujo and Jess Morrow have completed the UX research and the mockups are in final review. Key improvements include: customizable widget layouts (the #1 customer request from Q4), drill-down views that reduce clicks from 4 to 2, export-to-PDF functionality, and a saved-views feature that lets different stakeholders create personalized dashboard configurations. March GA is on track.

One other item I want to highlight: our product team headcount has grown to 22, and we're hiring 2 more PMs in Q1. The product organization is structured into four pods:
1. Core Platform (rec engine, API, infrastructure) — 2 PMs, led by Sami Okoro
2. Analytics & Dashboard (dashboard, reporting, exports) — 2 PMs, led by Ben Arujo
3. Data & Integration (Axion, data providers, ETL) — 1 PM + 1 hiring
4. Growth & Experience (onboarding, mobile, self-service) — 1 PM + 1 hiring

Each pod operates with a dedicated engineering squad of 8-12 engineers. This pod structure allows us to ship independently and move fast while maintaining quality.

Now let me bring Priya up for financials.

PRIYA VASQUEZ (CFO): Thank you, Hannah. Quick financial update. Q1 is shaping up to be our best quarter ever. Revenue is tracking 5% above plan. Bookings are 14% above target through mid-February. ARR has grown from $118.7M at year-end to approximately $121M today. Cash position is healthy at $26.5M.

Our gross margin has improved to 79.1%, driven by the K8s migration cost savings and the increasing proportion of subscription revenue. We're on track for EBITDA breakeven in Q4, which is a major milestone for the company.

I won't go deep on numbers today — this is a launch party! But I want to emphasize: the financial health of this company has never been stronger. We are well-capitalized, growing, and in control of our own destiny.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Priya. Now I want to address a few things directly.

Let me address the elephant in the room — Sarah Jiang's departure. Board members come and go. Sarah made valuable contributions and we wish her well. Nothing changes about our direction.

I know some of you have been connecting dots between the equity policy update, the Axion partnership, and Sarah's departure. I understand the impulse. When you work at a company you care about, you pay attention to these things. That's a good instinct. But in this case, the dots don't connect.

The equity acceleration policy update was a routine market alignment that we would have done regardless of any other circumstances. The Compensia data supports it. The Axion partnership is a product investment — better data for our customers. And Sarah's departure was her personal decision based on her own strategic views.

We are not for sale. We are not looking to be acquired. We are building a company that will outlast all of us. When someone asks you about Nextera's future, tell them: we're just getting started.

Now let me take your questions.

[Q&A SESSION — 10 QUESTIONS]

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): Marcus, can you talk about the hackathon results? The ChainWhisperer project sounds amazing.

MARCUS WEBB: It was incredible. Team ChainWhisperer — led by Fatima Al-Rashid and Carlos Rivera — built a natural language interface that translates plain English questions into supply chain API queries. You type something like "show me all delayed shipments from Shanghai in the last 7 days" and it generates the appropriate API call, fetches the data, and presents it in a formatted table. The prototype was rough around the edges but the core capability is sound. Hannah's team has already started the product evaluation process.

EMPLOYEE (Customer Success): How are customers reacting to rec engine v3 launch?

AMANDA BRIGGS (VP Customer Success): Early reception is outstanding. 47 customers activated v3 on day one — that's 22% of our customer base. We've received overwhelmingly positive feedback from the early adopters. Freight Corp's CTO sent an email this morning saying it "exceeded all expectations."

EMPLOYEE (Finance): Can you talk about the retention bonus program that was announced this morning?

DAVID ALDRIC: Vanessa can address that.

VANESSA KLINE (VP People): Sure. We announced a new Retention Bonus Program today that rewards critical team members for their commitment to Nextera. Eligible employees — approximately 120 people identified as critical talent — will receive a cash retention bonus upon a qualifying event, provided they remain employed through the event date and for 12 months following. The program uses the same "qualifying event" definition as the equity acceleration policy: change of control, IPO, or major asset sale.

EMPLOYEE (Product): The equity policy changes and Sarah's departure feel connected. Can you give us more clarity?

DAVID ALDRIC: They're not connected. The equity changes are routine market alignment. Sarah left for personal reasons. I understand why people connect dots, but these dots don't connect.

I want to be as transparent as I can be. The equity acceleration policy was something we'd been working on since Q3 last year. Vanessa's team ran the Compensia benchmarking study in October, and the board approved the update in January. The timing is coincidental with Sarah's departure, not causal.

Sarah was a valuable board member. She had strong views about the company's strategic direction — specifically, she was a passionate advocate for organic growth. That's a legitimate strategic perspective and I respect it. But the board's direction is the board's direction, and Sarah felt she couldn't continue to serve on a board whose direction she disagreed with. That's her prerogative and I respect her decision.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): What's the long-term vision for the recommendation engine? v4?

MARCUS WEBB: v3 is a major architectural leap. The sparse matrix processing and the real-time optimization capabilities give us a platform we can build on for 2-3 years. v4, when it comes, will likely incorporate the Axion data natively and introduce multi-objective optimization — meaning customers can optimize for cost, time, carbon footprint, and risk simultaneously. But that's Q4 2025 planning territory at the earliest.

EMPLOYEE (Sales): How is the Axion partnership landing with prospects?

KEVIN OROSCO (VP Sales): Extremely well. We've had 8 inbound leads since the announcement — three are enterprise quality. Every prospect I've talked to in the last two weeks has mentioned the Axion data coverage expansion. It's a genuine competitive differentiator. Kinaxis and Palantir can't match 340+ shipping lanes with real-time data.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): Lisa, how is the K8s migration performing post-cutover?

LISA CHEN (Director, Platform): Clean. Zero customer-facing downtime during the migration. p99 latency improved from 380ms to 290ms. Error rate during migration was 0.02% — well below our 0.5% threshold. And the early cost data is encouraging: we're seeing a 42% reduction in compute costs. Annualized, that's $1.68M in savings.

EMPLOYEE (HR): Vanessa, can you explain the retention bonus tiers?

VANESSA KLINE: Sure. There are three tiers based on role criticality: Tier 1 (approximately 20 employees) receives 100% of base salary; Tier 2 (approximately 40 employees) receives 50% of base salary; and Tier 3 (approximately 60 employees) receives 25% of base salary. The bonus is paid upon a qualifying event — provided you remain employed through the event and for 12 months after. Enrollment requires signing a retention agreement that includes an 18-month post-event non-compete. Information sessions are February 18 and 20. Enrollment deadline is March 15.

EMPLOYEE (Engineering): The non-compete clause feels aggressive. Can you elaborate?

VANESSA KLINE: The 18-month non-compete is standard for retention bonus programs at companies our size. It only applies to employees who voluntarily enroll in the program and only activates upon a qualifying event. If no qualifying event occurs, the non-compete never takes effect. And in California, non-competes are generally unenforceable under California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 — though this could apply in other jurisdictions. We recommend consulting with an attorney if you have concerns.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, everyone. I want to close by saying this: today is a celebration. Rec engine v3 is a genuine breakthrough. The Axion integration is progressing beautifully. Our financial results are the best in our history. We have 410 incredible people building the future of supply chain intelligence.

Happy Valentine's Day, Nextera. There are heart-shaped cookies in the auditorium lobby. Enjoy the rest of your afternoon.

[MEETING ENDS]

POST-MEETING NOTES

Meeting logistics:
- Total attendees: 362 in-person, 48 remote (410 total)
- Duration: 65 minutes — the longest all-hands meeting of 2025 to date
- Q&A session: 10 questions over 25 minutes
- Heart-shaped cookies (both chocolate chip and sugar cookie varieties) distributed at the launch party in the auditorium lobby
- Rec engine v3 branded t-shirts distributed to the engineering team

Post-meeting sentiment poll (298 responses):
- 61% "very confident" in company direction (down from 74% in January, 68% in mid-January)
- 24% "confident"
- 11% "neutral"
- 4% "somewhat concerned"

The decline in "very confident" sentiment from 74% in early January to 61% in mid-February represents a 13-percentage-point drop over approximately 5 weeks. The sentiment poll does not ask for reasons; the decline is concurrent with the equity policy update, Sarah Jiang's board departure, the retention bonus announcement, and general market commentary about enterprise software M&A activity.

Rec engine v3 launch day metrics:
- Customers activated on day 1: 47 (21.5% of customer base)
- API calls processed on launch day: 2.4M (3x normal daily volume)
- Peak queries per second: 890 (well within 1,150 capacity)
- Error rate on launch day: 0.003% (below 0.01% target)
- Customer support tickets related to v3: 3 (all P4, resolved within 2 hours)
- Customer NPS for v3 launch experience: pending survey (launching February 15)

Aldric's closing remarks — which emphasized independence and long-term vision — were the longest closing remarks of any all-hands this year at approximately 8 minutes. Previous all-hands closing remarks have averaged 3-4 minutes.

Next all-hands: February 24

DOCUMENT TYPE: HR Policy Bulletin
DATE: February 14, 2025
FROM: Vanessa Kline, VP People
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: New Retention Bonus Program — Effective March 1
CLASSIFICATION: Internal — All Employees
REFERENCE: NXS-HR-2025-010

---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS
PEOPLE TEAM POLICY BULLETIN

To: All Nextera Employees
From: Vanessa Kline, VP People
Date: February 14, 2025

NEW RETENTION BONUS PROGRAM — EFFECTIVE MARCH 1, 2025

We're excited to announce a new Retention Bonus Program designed to reward our most critical team members for their commitment to Nextera.

PROGRAM OVERVIEW

Eligible employees will receive a cash retention bonus upon the occurrence of a "qualifying event," provided they remain employed through the event date and for 12 months following.

A qualifying event is defined as: (a) a change of control of Nextera Solutions, (b) an initial public offering, or (c) a sale of substantially all assets exceeding $50M in value.

This program reflects our commitment to rewarding loyalty and ensuring our best people share in Nextera's success, whatever form that takes.

ELIGIBILITY AND TIERS

Approximately 120 employees have been identified as "critical talent" based on role criticality, institutional knowledge, and strategic importance. These employees have been notified individually via email and are eligible to enroll in the program.

Tier 1 — Critical Leadership (approximately 20 employees):
- Bonus: 100% of base salary
- Roles: Senior directors, technical fellows, key architects, and essential leadership positions
- Estimated total Tier 1 payout: $3.2M

Tier 2 — Key Contributors (approximately 40 employees):
- Bonus: 50% of base salary
- Roles: Managers with critical institutional knowledge, specialized engineers, key customer relationships
- Estimated total Tier 2 payout: $2.8M

Tier 3 — Critical Individual Contributors (approximately 60 employees):
- Bonus: 25% of base salary
- Roles: High-performing individual contributors in engineering, sales, and customer success
- Estimated total Tier 3 payout: $2.2M

Total program cost estimate: $8.2M upon qualifying event

ENROLLMENT REQUIREMENTS

To participate, eligible employees must sign a Retention Agreement that includes:

1. Commitment to remain employed through a qualifying event and for 12 months following
2. An 18-month post-qualifying-event non-compete clause (applicable in jurisdictions where enforceable)
3. Non-solicitation clause covering Nextera employees and customers for 18 months post-event
4. Confidentiality provisions regarding the terms of the retention agreement

The retention agreement is voluntary. No employee is required to enroll. However, the retention bonus is only available to employees who have signed the agreement prior to the enrollment deadline.

ENROLLMENT DEADLINE: March 15, 2025

INFORMATION SESSIONS

Two information sessions are scheduled:
- February 18, 2025, 2:00 PM — Main auditorium + Zoom
- February 20, 2025, 10:00 AM — Main auditorium + Zoom

Both sessions will cover the program details, answer questions, and walk through the retention agreement. Attendance is optional but recommended for all eligible employees.

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

Q: Why is the company introducing this program now?
A: We regularly benchmark our compensation programs against the market. Retention bonus programs are standard at companies our size and stage. This is part of our overall talent retention strategy.

Q: Does this mean the company is planning a transaction?
A: No. The program covers multiple qualifying events, including IPO, which is the most commonly cited qualifying event in similar programs at peer companies. The program is designed to be prepared for various growth scenarios, not to signal any specific plan.

Q: What if no qualifying event occurs?
A: If no qualifying event occurs during your employment, the retention agreement has no financial effect. The non-compete and non-solicitation provisions only activate upon a qualifying event.

Q: Can I opt out after enrolling?
A: Yes. You may terminate the retention agreement with 30 days written notice. Upon termination, you forfeit eligibility for the retention bonus. The non-compete and non-solicitation provisions would also terminate.

Q: How was "critical talent" determined?
A: Critical talent was identified by each VP in consultation with the People Team based on role criticality, institutional knowledge, technical specialization, customer relationship importance, and difficulty of replacement. If you believe you should have been included and were not, please reach out to your VP or to people@nextera.io.

Q: Are executives eligible?
A: C-suite executives have separate compensation arrangements and are not part of this program. VP-level executives may be eligible depending on their individual employment agreements.

Q: How does the retention bonus interact with the equity acceleration policy?
A: They are separate programs. The equity acceleration policy governs what happens to your unvested equity upon a qualifying event. The retention bonus provides an additional cash payment for employees who enroll. You can benefit from both programs simultaneously.

Q: What happens if I'm terminated before a qualifying event?
A: If you are terminated (whether voluntarily or involuntarily) before a qualifying event, the retention agreement terminates and you receive no retention bonus. The non-compete and non-solicitation provisions also terminate upon your departure if no qualifying event has occurred.

Q: Can I negotiate the retention bonus amount?
A: No. Retention bonus amounts are determined by tier and are standardized within each tier. The tier assignment was made by your VP in consultation with the People Team and is not subject to negotiation.

Q: When exactly is the retention bonus paid?
A: The retention bonus is paid within 30 days following the qualifying event date, subject to applicable tax withholdings. If the qualifying event is a change of control, the event date is the closing date of the transaction. If the qualifying event is an IPO, the event date is the effective date of the registration statement. If the qualifying event is an asset sale, the event date is the closing date of the sale.

Q: What if I'm on leave (maternity, medical, sabbatical) at the time of a qualifying event?
A: Employees on approved leave are considered "employed" for purposes of the retention bonus. You remain eligible as long as you are on an approved leave of absence at the time of the qualifying event.

TAX CONSIDERATIONS

Retention bonuses are taxed as supplemental wages. The federal supplemental wage tax rate is 22% for amounts up to $1M and 37% for amounts exceeding $1M. State taxes (California) apply at the marginal rate. FICA taxes apply up to the Social Security wage base ($168,600 for 2025).

The company will withhold applicable taxes at the time of payment. We recommend consulting with a tax advisor to understand the specific impact on your tax situation.

PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION

The Retention Bonus Program is administered by the People Team in coordination with the Finance Team and General Counsel's office. Program documents include:

1. Retention Bonus Program Summary (this document)
2. Individual Retention Agreement (provided to eligible employees via email)
3. Program FAQ (available on the HR intranet)
4. Non-Compete and Non-Solicitation Terms Sheet (appendix to the retention agreement)

All program documents have been reviewed and approved by Rachel Dominguez (General Counsel), Priya Vasquez (CFO), and outside counsel at Cooley LLP.

ENROLLMENT TIMELINE

- February 14: Program announced
- February 18: Information session #1 (2:00 PM)
- February 20: Information session #2 (10:00 AM)
- March 1: Program effective date
- March 15: Enrollment deadline

Eligible employees who do not enroll by March 15 will forfeit eligibility for the current enrollment period. Future enrollment periods may be offered at the company's discretion.

COMPARISON TO PEER COMPANIES

For context, retention bonus programs are common at enterprise software companies in our revenue range:

- 68% of venture-backed enterprise SaaS companies with $100M+ ARR have some form of retention bonus or stay bonus program (source: Compensia 2024 survey)
- Median retention bonus for Tier 1 employees: 75-100% of base salary
- Median retention bonus for Tier 2 employees: 40-60% of base salary
- Median retention bonus for Tier 3 employees: 20-30% of base salary
- Our program is at the median across all tiers

CONTACT

For questions, reach out to the People Team at people@nextera.io or attend one of the information sessions.

Vanessa Kline
VP People
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: February 17, 2025
FROM: Angela Torres, Controller
TO: Priya Vasquez (CFO), Jordan Michaels (VP Finance)
SUBJECT: Long-Term Prepaid Contract Write-Down Analysis
CLASSIFICATION: Finance — Confidential
REFERENCE: NXS-FIN-2025-009

---

From: Angela Torres <a.torres@nextera.io>
Date: February 17, 2025, 8:15 AM PST
To: Priya Vasquez <p.vasquez@nextera.io>; Jordan Michaels <j.michaels@nextera.io>
Subject: Long-Term Prepaid Contract Write-Down Analysis

Priya, Jordan,

Per the new vendor contract guidance, I've identified $4.2M in prepaid commitments with remaining terms exceeding 18 months.

Following the vendor contract policy update on January 30, I've completed a comprehensive analysis of our prepaid vendor commitments. This memo summarizes the findings and presents a recommendation for accelerated amortization to bring our prepaid balance in line with the new 18-month maximum term policy.

I. PREPAID COMMITMENTS OVER 18 MONTHS

Seven vendor contracts currently have prepaid balances with remaining terms exceeding 18 months:

1. Snowflake (Data Warehouse)
   - Original term: 36 months (signed January 2024)
   - Original prepaid amount: $6.3M ($2.1M/year x 3 years)
   - Remaining prepaid balance: $4.2M (24 months remaining as of Feb 1, 2025)
   - Monthly amortization (current): $175K
   - STATUS: Renewal restructured from 36 months to 12 months per new policy (see below)

   Jordan: "Snowflake renewal is done — restructured from 36 months to 12 months. We gave up the 12% volume discount to get the shorter term. Net cost increase: $180K/year."

   Vasquez: "Approved. The flexibility is worth the cost increase. Process all other renewals under the same framework."

2. Datadog (Monitoring)
   - Original term: 36 months (signed December 2024)
   - Original prepaid amount: $1.53M ($0.51M/year x 3 years, post-discount)
   - Remaining prepaid balance: $1.44M (34 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization (current): $42.5K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0147
   - Primary use case: application performance monitoring, infrastructure monitoring, log management
   - Monthly usage: 2.4M host-hours, 18TB log ingestion
   - STATUS: Restructured from 36 months to 18 months. Retained partial discount (8% vs original 15%). Additional cost: $42K/year.
   - Restructuring note: Datadog account team initially resisted the shorter term. After two weeks of negotiation, they agreed to 18 months with a partial discount. The original 36-month term included a 15% volume discount; the restructured 18-month term retains an 8% discount, representing a 7-percentage-point concession. The incremental annual cost of $42K reflects this reduced discount applied to the full contract value.

3. MongoDB Atlas (Database)
   - Original term: 24 months (signed March 2024)
   - Prepaid balance: $480K (12 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization: $20K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0089
   - Primary use case: primary application database, analytics data store
   - Cluster configuration: M80 dedicated cluster, 3 shards, cross-region replication
   - Monthly throughput: 12.8M read operations, 4.2M write operations
   - STATUS: Under 18 months remaining — no action needed. Next renewal will be 12-month term.

4. Confluent (Kafka Managed Service)
   - Original term: 24 months (signed February 2024)
   - Prepaid balance: $360K (12 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization: $15K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0072
   - Primary use case: event streaming, data pipeline backbone, real-time analytics
   - Monthly throughput: 850M messages, 4.2TB data processed
   - STATUS: Under 18 months remaining — no action needed. Next renewal will be 12-month term.

5. LaunchDarkly (Feature Flags)
   - Original term: 24 months (signed February 2024)
   - Prepaid balance: $192K (12 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization: $8K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0068
   - Primary use case: feature flag management, progressive rollouts, A/B testing
   - Active flags: 347 (up from 212 at contract signing)
   - STATUS: Under 18 months remaining — no action needed.

6. Segment (Customer Data Platform)
   - Original term: 24 months (signed February 2024)
   - Prepaid balance: $312K (12 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization: $13K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0071
   - Primary use case: customer data collection, identity resolution, audience segmentation
   - Monthly tracked users: 2.1M (up from 1.4M at signing)
   - STATUS: Under 18 months remaining — no action needed.

7. HashiCorp (Infrastructure Automation)
   - Original term: 24 months (signed September 2024)
   - Prepaid balance: $168K (19 months remaining)
   - Monthly amortization: $8.4K
   - Contract ID: VND-2024-0138
   - Primary use case: Terraform Cloud, Vault secrets management, Consul service mesh
   - Active workspaces: 89, secrets managed: 1,240
   - STATUS: 1 month over 18-month threshold. Will amortize down to 18 months by March. No restructuring needed — natural runoff brings this into compliance.

Total prepaid contracts over 18 months: 7 vendors, $4.2M total (but only $1.44M + $168K = $1.61M actually exceeds 18-month remaining terms)

Summary of prepaid vendor commitments:

| Vendor         | Contract ID     | Original Term | Remaining Term | Prepaid Balance | Monthly Amort | Status              |
|----------------|-----------------|---------------|----------------|-----------------|---------------|---------------------|
| Snowflake      | VND-2024-0041   | 36 months     | 24 months      | $4.2M           | $175K         | Restructured to 12m |
| Datadog        | VND-2024-0147   | 36 months     | 34 months      | $1.44M          | $42.5K        | Restructured to 18m |
| MongoDB Atlas  | VND-2024-0089   | 24 months     | 12 months      | $480K           | $20K          | Compliant            |
| Confluent      | VND-2024-0072   | 24 months     | 12 months      | $360K           | $15K          | Compliant            |
| LaunchDarkly   | VND-2024-0068   | 24 months     | 12 months      | $192K           | $8K           | Compliant            |
| Segment        | VND-2024-0071   | 24 months     | 12 months      | $312K           | $13K          | Compliant            |
| HashiCorp      | VND-2024-0138   | 24 months     | 19 months      | $168K           | $8.4K         | Runoff by March      |

Total aggregate prepaid balance across these 7 vendors: $7.152M
Total monthly amortization: $281.9K
Contracts requiring active restructuring: 2 (Snowflake, Datadog)
Contracts naturally compliant: 4 (MongoDB, Confluent, LaunchDarkly, Segment)
Contracts in natural runoff: 1 (HashiCorp)

II. ACCELERATED AMORTIZATION RECOMMENDATION

I recommend accelerated amortization to bring these balances down by end of Q2. The impact to operating expense is approximately $1.8M spread over Q1 and Q2.

Accelerated amortization schedule:

Q1 2025 (January-March): $900K additional amortization expense
- Snowflake: $500K (accelerate 2.9 months of expense into Q1)
- Datadog: $280K (accelerate portion of 36-month to 18-month restructure)
- Other contracts: $120K (minor adjustments)

Q2 2025 (April-June): $900K additional amortization expense
- Snowflake: $600K (complete write-down to 12-month remaining term)
- Datadog: $200K (complete restructure amortization)
- Other contracts: $100K (minor adjustments)

Total incremental operating expense impact: $1.8M over Q1-Q2

III. IMPACT ON FINANCIAL METRICS

The accelerated amortization will affect the following metrics:

EBITDA impact:
- Q1 2025 EBITDA: -$900K incremental expense (reduces Q1 EBITDA by $900K)
- Q2 2025 EBITDA: -$900K incremental expense
- Net annual impact: $1.8M additional opex in FY2025 (one-time catch-up)

Cash flow impact:
- No cash impact — the cash was already spent when the prepaid contracts were signed
- Accelerated amortization is a non-cash expense adjustment

Balance sheet impact:
- Prepaid assets decrease by $1.8M over H1 2025
- Retained earnings decrease by $1.8M (net of tax)

Cash position impact:
- Q1 ending cash projection revised from $25.1M to $24.2M (due to the operating expense impact on EBITDA, not the amortization itself — the EBITDA decline reflects higher reported opex which affects investor/board metrics)
- Correction: cash is not affected by non-cash amortization. Q1 ending cash is affected by the actual cost increases from restructuring vendors to shorter terms.

Actual cash impact from vendor restructuring:
- Snowflake shorter term (lost discount): $180K/year = $45K in Q1
- Datadog shorter term (reduced discount): $42K/year = $10.5K in Q1
- Total Q1 cash impact from restructuring: $55.5K

IV. COMPLIANCE STATUS

New policy compliance: 89% of renewals now under 18 months.

Summary of vendor contract restructuring progress:
- Snowflake: restructured to 12 months (completed)
- Datadog: restructured to 18 months (completed)
- MongoDB: renewing at 12 months in March (in process)
- Confluent: renewing at 12 months in February (in process)
- All new vendor contracts: defaulting to 12-month terms per policy
- Remaining prepaids to restructure: 5 contracts in negotiation

Contracts still exceeding 18-month term:
- AWS: 3-year term (grandfathered, not subject to new policy)
- HashiCorp: 19 months remaining (will be under 18 months by March)

V. BOARD REPORTING

I recommend including the following in the February board package:

1. Summary of vendor contract policy change and rationale
2. Accelerated amortization impact ($1.8M over Q1-Q2)
3. Updated Q1 EBITDA guidance reflecting the additional expense
4. Note that cash position is minimally impacted ($55.5K in Q1)

The board should understand that this is a one-time catch-up expense, not a recurring increase. After H1 2025, operating expenses will normalize because vendor commitments will be on shorter terms with lower (but more frequent) amortization.

Respectfully submitted,
Angela Torres
Controller
Nextera Solutions

2. On the Snowflake restructuring — losing the 12% discount is unfortunate but the shorter term is more important right now. We can revisit volume pricing when the next renewal comes up.

3. For the remaining 5 contracts in negotiation, push hard for 12-month terms. If vendors push back, 18 months is acceptable. Nothing over 18 months without my explicit approval. Have Jordan track each negotiation individually and report weekly until all five are resolved.

DOCUMENT 1 OF 4
TYPE: Email Thread
DATE: February 20, 2025
FROM: Nathan Foley (Senior Corporate Counsel)
TO: Rachel Dominguez (General Counsel)
SUBJECT: Comprehensive Change-of-Control Summary — Draft Review
CLASSIFICATION: Attorney-Client Privileged

--- Original Message ---
From: Nathan Foley
To: Rachel Dominguez
Date: February 20, 2025, 9:14 AM PST
Subject: Comprehensive Change-of-Control Summary — Draft Review

Rachel,

Draft comprehensive CoC summary attached. 377 agreements reviewed. Key findings below.

I've completed the comprehensive review of every existing agreement in the company's contract management system for change-of-control provisions. The review spanned four major categories: employment agreements, vendor contracts, customer agreements, and real estate leases. The project required approximately three weeks of concentrated effort, including pulling agreements from both our current CLM platform and the archived legacy files that predated the system migration in 2022. I'm confident we have captured every material provision.

Below is the detailed breakdown by category with observations on each.

EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENTS

Of the 416 current employees, 14 executive-level employment agreements contain explicit change-of-control provisions. These 14 agreements follow the standard executive employment template that has been in use since the board approved the revised executive compensation framework in Q2 2021. Each agreement includes the following provisions triggered upon a qualifying change-of-control event:

(a) Accelerated vesting of all outstanding equity awards, including stock options and restricted stock units, with vesting occurring immediately prior to the closing of the change-of-control transaction;

(b) Severance multipliers ranging from 1.5x to 3x base salary depending on the executive's tier designation, payable in a lump sum within 30 days of termination following a change of control;

(c) COBRA continuation coverage for 18 to 24 months, depending on the executive's tier designation, with the company paying the full premium cost during the continuation period;

(d) A prorated annual bonus based on target bonus percentage and the number of days employed during the fiscal year in which the change of control occurs.

I've catalogued the specific trigger definitions for each of the 14 agreements. The definitions are substantially similar but not identical — the agreements executed in 2021 and 2022 use a broader definition that includes asset sales exceeding 50% of the company's total assets, while the agreements executed in 2023 and 2024 use a narrower definition that requires a change in majority ownership of voting shares. This discrepancy should be harmonized if the company enters into any transaction that could trigger the broader definition without triggering the narrower one.

The remaining 402 non-executive employee agreements do not contain individual change-of-control provisions. Those employees are covered under the company's general severance plan, which was recently restructured effective March 1, 2025, reducing non-executive severance from a 2x base salary multiplier to a 1x base salary multiplier. The general severance plan does not contain a change-of-control trigger — it applies only in cases of involuntary termination without cause.

A few notes on the employment category:

- Two of the 14 executive agreements (CFO Priya Vasquez and VP Engineering Marcus Webb) include additional "gross-up" provisions for excise taxes under Section 280G/4999 of the Internal Revenue Code. These were negotiated as part of their original offer packages and are not present in any other executive agreement.

- The General Counsel (Rachel Dominguez) agreement includes a specific provision requiring continuation of D&O insurance coverage for 6 years following a change of control, which is separate from the standard tail coverage in the company's D&O policy.

- VP People Vanessa Kline's agreement includes a provision requiring 90 days' advance notice of any contemplated reduction in force following a change of control, which is unique among the executive agreements.

VENDOR CONTRACTS

42 vendor contracts require notification within 30 days of a change-of-control event. 18 customer contracts require affirmative consent from the customer prior to assignment. 3 leases require landlord consent for assignment.

The vendor notification obligations are straightforward in the majority of cases. Most use boilerplate language requiring written notice within 30 calendar days of the effective date of any change-of-control event. The notification is informational only — none of these 42 contracts grant the vendor a termination right triggered solely by change of control. However, several contracts do include provisions that allow the vendor to renegotiate pricing or modify service terms following a change of control, which could have financial implications.

I've organized the vendor contracts by tier based on annual spend:

Tier 1 (annual spend exceeding $500,000 per year): 8 contracts
- Amazon Web Services — Enterprise Agreement ($4.2M annual, multi-year term expiring December 2026). CoC provision requires 30 days' written notice plus a certification that the successor entity will assume all obligations under the existing service terms. AWS retains the right to conduct a credit review of the successor entity and may require modified payment terms based on that review.
- Snowflake — Data Cloud Agreement ($1.8M annual, term expiring March 2026). Standard 30-day notification. Includes a most-favored-nation pricing clause that survives assignment.
- Salesforce — Enterprise License ($980K annual, 3-year term). Standard 30-day notification with automatic assignment to successor entity.
- Datadog — Monitoring Platform ($720K annual, annual renewal). Standard notification. Month-to-month cancellation provision unaffected by CoC.
- Cloudflare — Enterprise Security ($640K annual, 2-year term). Standard notification.
- Okta — Identity Management ($580K annual, 3-year term). Standard notification. Includes data processing addendum that requires separate counterparty acknowledgment.
- Confluent — Event Streaming Platform ($560K annual, annual). Standard notification.
- Elastic — Search and Observability ($510K annual, 2-year term). Standard notification.

Tier 2 (annual spend $100,000 to $500,000): 14 contracts across various SaaS and infrastructure providers including Twilio, SendGrid, PagerDuty, CircleCI, GitHub Enterprise, Jira/Atlassian, Figma, Notion, Zoom, Slack, and four others. All contain standard 30-day notification provisions without material variations.

Tier 3 (annual spend under $100,000): 20 contracts with primarily professional services firms, staffing agencies, and specialty consultants. All standard notification provisions.

Total annual vendor spend covered by CoC notification requirements: approximately $14.8M.

CUSTOMER CONTRACTS

18 customer contracts contain change-of-control consent requirements. These are enterprise customer agreements negotiated with counterparties who had sufficient leverage during the sales cycle to include assignment restrictions. Unlike the vendor notifications, these require affirmative written consent from the customer before any assignment or transfer of the agreement in connection with a change of control.

I've prepared a preliminary risk assessment for each of the 18 customer contracts, considering factors such as:
- Remaining contract term and renewal date
- Historical renewal rate and expansion history
- Current customer health score from the CS team's dashboard
- The customer's historical approach to consent requests in other vendor relationships
- Whether the customer has an active competitive evaluation underway
- The customer's internal procurement policies for consent approvals

The combined annual contract value of these 18 agreements is $8.4M. I'll have a more detailed financial breakdown in the highlighted list you've requested.

Key customer contracts requiring consent (top 5 by ACV):
1. GlobalShip Industries — $890K ACV, renewed January 2025, 3-year term, green health
2. DB Schenker — $420K ACV, expansion in Q1, 2-year term, green health
3. Maersk Digital — $380K ACV, stable, 2-year remaining, green health
4. Ceva Logistics — $310K ACV, stable, 18 months remaining, yellow health
5. TransGlobal Logistics — $180K ACV, recently evaluated competitors, red health

LEASE AGREEMENTS

3 office leases contain change-of-control assignment restrictions:

1. 14th Floor — Headquarters (Primary lease)
   - Landlord: Meridian Real Estate Holdings (no relation to Meridian Corp)
   - Lease area: 22,000 sq ft
   - Term: through December 2029
   - Monthly rent: $110,000 ($60/sq ft annual)
   - CoC provision: Requires landlord consent for assignment. Includes a recapture right allowing the landlord to terminate the lease and reclaim the space in lieu of consenting to assignment. Landlord has 30 days to exercise recapture right after receiving notice.

2. 13th Floor — Engineering Expansion (New lease)
   - Landlord: Meridian Real Estate Holdings
   - Lease area: 8,000 sq ft
   - Term: 18 months from March 1, 2025
   - Monthly rent: $48,000 ($72/sq ft annual, premium rate for short-term)
   - CoC provision: Requires landlord consent for assignment. No recapture right. Shorter term reduces landlord risk.

3. Warehouse Facility — Data Center Equipment
   - Landlord: Pacific Industrial Partners
   - Lease area: 3,200 sq ft
   - Term: through June 2026
   - Monthly rent: $8,800 ($33/sq ft annual)
   - CoC provision: Standard consent requirement. Landlord may not unreasonably withhold consent.

SUMMARY TABLE

| Category | Total Reviewed | CoC Provision | Notification Only | Consent Required |
|----------|---------------|---------------|-------------------|------------------|
| Employment | 416 | 14 | — | — |
| Vendor | 168 | 42 | 42 | 0 |
| Customer | 218 | 18 | 0 | 18 |
| Lease | 5 | 3 | 0 | 3 |
| **Total** | **377** | **77** | **42** | **21** |

Contracts requiring counterparty consent: 21 (18 customer + 3 lease). Contracts requiring notification only: 42 vendor.

I delivered this draft 2 days ahead of the February 28 deadline you originally set. Let me know if any revisions are needed before finalization.

Best,
Nathan Foley
Senior Corporate Counsel
Nextera Solutions

--- Reply ---

Specifically, I want the following for each contract:

DOCUMENT 3 OF 4
TYPE: Internal Announcement
DATE: February 20, 2025
FROM: Vanessa Kline (VP People)
TO: All Employees
SUBJECT: February Hiring Update + New Office Space

Hello Nextera Team!

I'm excited to share our February people update with some great news about our continued growth and a few upcoming milestones that I hope everyone will participate in.

NEW TEAMMATES

We welcomed 14 new teammates in February! Our headcount is now 416 and growing. We've also secured additional office space on the 13th floor to accommodate our engineering team's growth.

Here's the breakdown of our February hires by department and role:

Engineering (8 new hires):
- 4 Backend Engineers — joining the core platform team, working on the data pipeline and recommendation engine infrastructure
- 2 ML/AI Engineers — joining the machine learning team, focused on model training and optimization for rec engine v4 planning
- 1 Platform Engineer — joining the infrastructure team, focused on Kubernetes operations and cloud cost optimization
- 1 QA Engineer — joining the quality assurance team, focused on automated testing for the API layer

Sales (3 new hires):
- 2 Account Executives — covering the Northeast and Southeast territories
- 1 Sales Development Representative — supporting the enterprise pipeline development team

Customer Success (2 new hires):
- 1 Customer Success Manager — managing mid-market accounts in the logistics vertical
- 1 Technical Account Manager — supporting our largest enterprise customers with implementation and integration projects

Legal (1 new hire):
- 1 Paralegal — supporting the expanded contract review and compliance workload in Rachel Dominguez's legal department

A warm welcome to every one of our new colleagues! If you haven't had a chance to introduce yourself yet, please take a moment to say hello — whether that's stopping by their desk, sending a Slack message, or joining one of the new hire lunch sessions that we organize every other Friday. Our culture of welcoming new teammates is something I hear about consistently in onboarding feedback, and I'd like to keep that reputation strong.

OFFICE EXPANSION — 13TH FLOOR

As many of you have noticed, our 14th floor headquarters has been getting a bit cozy, especially in the engineering wing where we've been doubling up on desks in some of the open-plan areas. I'm happy to announce that we've secured additional space on the 13th floor of our building. Here are the details:

- Location: 13th floor, same building as our 14th floor headquarters
- Space: 8,000 square feet
- Availability: March 1, 2025
- Purpose: Engineering team expansion workspace
- Capacity: Approximately 60 desks, 2 large meeting rooms (12-person each), 4 phone booths, and a small kitchen area with coffee/snack service
- Lease term: 18 months

The 13th floor will primarily house the platform engineering and ML/AI teams, with Marcus Webb's engineering leadership overseeing the space allocation. We chose to keep the engineering teams together rather than splitting across departments to maintain the collaboration dynamics that Marcus's team has built.

Facilities will begin the move-in setup starting next week, including furniture installation, IT infrastructure (networking, monitors, peripherals), and kitchen equipment. We expect the space to be fully operational by mid-March, with a formal "opening day" celebration planned for March 17 (St. Patrick's Day theme — why not?).

A few logistical notes about the 13th floor:
- Building access badges will work for the 13th floor starting March 1. No action needed on your part.
- The 13th floor elevator lobby will have the same visitor check-in process as the 14th floor.
- WiFi network name will be "Nextera-13" and will automatically connect if you're on the Nextera network profile.
- Parking and building amenities (gym, cafe, bike storage) remain unchanged.

The 18-month lease term is shorter than our usual 36-month terms, giving us flexibility as we evaluate our long-term space needs. Our 14th floor headquarters lease runs through 2029, so that remains our primary home base for the foreseeable future.

SPRING RECRUITING

Spring recruiting is in full swing. We're targeting 20+ hires in Q2 across engineering, sales, and customer success.

Current open positions: 32

If you know talented people who would be a great fit at Nextera, please use the employee referral program through Greenhouse. Referral bonuses remain at $5,000 for engineering roles and $3,000 for all other positions. Bonuses are paid 50% at hire date and 50% after the referred employee's 90-day mark.

Key positions we're actively hiring for:

Engineering:
- Senior Software Engineer, Platform (2 openings) — backend systems, distributed computing
- Machine Learning Engineer (2 openings) — model development, feature engineering
- Staff Engineer, Distributed Systems (1 opening) — architecture and technical leadership
- Engineering Manager, Data Pipeline (1 opening) — team leadership, pipeline optimization
- Security Engineer (1 opening) — application security, vulnerability management

Sales:
- Account Executive, Enterprise (3 openings) — $500K+ ACV target accounts
- Solutions Architect (2 openings) — technical pre-sales support

Customer Success:
- Customer Success Manager, Strategic Accounts (2 openings) — enterprise relationship management

Product:
- Product Manager, Integrations (1 opening) — partner ecosystem and API strategy

Full descriptions are posted on our careers page (nextera.io/careers) and on the internal job board in Greenhouse. Hiring managers for each role are listed in Greenhouse — feel free to reach out directly if you want to learn more about a specific team.

EMPLOYEE ENGAGEMENT SURVEY

Our annual employee engagement survey launches March 3. Your feedback matters — please take the 15 minutes to complete it.

Survey details:
- Launch date: Monday, March 3, 2025
- Close date: Monday, March 17, 2025 (two-week window)
- Platform: Culture Amp
- Estimated completion time: 15 minutes
- Anonymity: All responses are anonymous and reported in aggregate only. Results are shared at the team level only when a team has 5+ respondents to protect individual privacy.

Last year's engagement score was 78 out of 100, which placed us in the 72nd percentile among Culture Amp's technology company benchmark. Our goal this year is to maintain or improve that score while addressing the top feedback themes from last year's survey.

Last year's top three improvement areas were:
1. Career development opportunities — employees wanted clearer pathways for advancement and more structured mentorship programs
2. Cross-team collaboration — teams felt siloed and wanted more opportunities to work with colleagues from other departments
3. Meeting load — employees reported spending too much time in meetings and not enough in focused work

Here's what we've done in response to that feedback over the past 12 months:
- Launched the internal mobility program in September 2024 — 7 employees have transferred between departments since launch
- Created the cross-functional project initiative in November 2024 — 3 cross-team projects currently underway (Axion integration, rec engine v3 optimization, and the customer data platform project)
- Implemented "No Meeting Wednesdays" starting January 2025 — early feedback has been positive, with 89% of employees reporting they use the day for focused work
- Added 2 additional professional development days per year (now 5 total) — uptake has been strong, with 42% of employees already using at least one PD day in January

I'm genuinely curious to see if these changes have moved the needle. Please participate — the higher our response rate, the more meaningful the data becomes. Last year we achieved an 85% response rate, and I'd love to beat that this year.

UPCOMING HR DATES

Please add these to your calendars:
- February 28: Q1 performance review conversations due — managers, please ensure you've completed these with each direct report
- March 1: Updated severance policy effective (all employees were notified in January)
- March 3-17: Employee engagement survey open (Culture Amp)
- March 5: Retention Bonus Program final information session (eligible employees only, calendar invite sent separately)
- March 7: Deadline for Q2 goal setting in Lattice
- March 14: Benefits open enrollment reminder — dental plan changes taking effect in April
- March 28: Company anniversary celebration — Nextera turns 9! The events team is planning something special.

FINAL NOTES

A few additional updates that didn't warrant their own announcement:
- The kitchen on 14 is getting a new espresso machine next week. The current one has served us well for 3 years, but it's time for an upgrade.
- Bike commuter count for February: 34 employees (up from 28 in January, thanks partly to the dry weather).
- The wellness committee is organizing a March step challenge. Sign up in #wellness on Slack.
- Tax season reminder: W-2s were distributed in January. If you haven't received yours, contact payroll@nextera.io.

As always, my door is open — literally and figuratively. Please reach out to me or any member of the People team if you have questions about any of the above topics, or anything else on your mind.

Best,
Vanessa Kline
VP People
Nextera Solutions

P.S. — A reminder that our 9th company anniversary is coming up on March 28! The events team is planning something special. Details coming soon — stay tuned. :)

SUBJECT: RE: Timeline Discussion — Project Lighthouse
CLASSIFICATION: CONFIDENTIAL — Project Lighthouse

--- Original Message ---
From: David Aldric
To: Gerald Fisk
Date: February 19, 2025, 3:47 PM PST
Subject: Timeline Discussion — Project Lighthouse

Gerald —

Good to speak last Thursday. I believe we can have LOI terms agreed by end of March if your team can turn the financial diligence.

A few things on our end to keep you updated. We are running ahead of plan on Q1 — revenue is tracking 7% above forecast and our NPS score just hit 64, the highest in company history. The recommendation engine v3 is a genuine differentiator in the market and customer adoption is accelerating. I mention this because it has a direct bearing on the valuation conversation — the business is demonstrably stronger today than when we began these discussions in January.

On the operational side, our data room is approximately 60% populated. Rachel Dominguez's team has been assembling documents across all 14 categories. We are targeting a fully loaded data room by mid-March, aligned with your board timeline.

Goldman Sachs has been brought up to speed on the transaction parameters. They are preparing the financial materials your team will need for diligence, including a detailed revenue model, customer cohort analysis, and the IP valuation for the recommendation engine. Wachtell Lipton is handling the legal work on our side.

I'd like to understand your integration plans for our engineering team before we get deeper into the process. Marcus Webb has built an extraordinary team — 186 engineers as of this week — and their continuity is personally important to me.

Let me know your thoughts on timing and integration.

Best,
David

--- Reply ---
From: Gerald Fisk
To: David Aldric
Date: February 21, 2025, 10:22 AM EST
Subject: RE: Timeline Discussion — Project Lighthouse

David —

Agreed on timing. Our board meets March 14. Assuming no surprises in the data room, I am prepared to recommend authorization of a formal offer in the $900M range.

I appreciate the Q1 update. The revenue trajectory reinforces our thesis. My team has been tracking Nextera's public metrics — the Gartner placement, the G2 reviews, the customer case studies — and the picture is consistent with what you're describing. The recommendation engine is indeed what caught our attention initially, and the v3 improvements have only strengthened our conviction.

On integration plans: let me be very direct, because I know this matters to you.

Engineering is the crown jewel. Every engineer gets an offer letter. We plan to keep the SF office as a Meridian Center of Excellence for supply chain AI.

Here's how we're thinking about it in more detail:

1. SF Office: We intend to maintain your San Francisco location as a standalone Meridian development center. The working name internally is "Meridian Center of Excellence for Supply Chain AI." We see this as the natural home for the continued development of the recommendation engine and the broader supply chain optimization platform. We would expect to maintain the headcount at current levels or above.

2. Engineering Leadership: We want Marcus Webb to run the SF center. We understand he has a change-of-control provision in his employment agreement, and we're prepared to offer him an enhanced package on top of that. We have a good track record with engineering acquisitions — when we acquired LogicPath in 2022, we retained 94% of their engineering team through the 18-month integration period.

3. Product Continuity: Hannah Choi's product team would continue to drive the Nextera product roadmap within the Meridian portfolio. The Axion Labs integration work you're doing is exactly the kind of partnership that Meridian would support and potentially accelerate through our existing data relationships.

4. Brand: For the first 12-18 months, we would maintain the Nextera brand for the supply chain optimization product. The gradual transition to Meridian branding would be managed carefully to minimize customer disruption.

5. Support Functions: Sales and customer success would be integrated into Meridian's existing go-to-market organization. This is the area where we see the most overlap and where some consolidation would occur over time. Amanda Briggs's customer success team has done excellent work — we've heard great things from shared customers.

6. G&A: Finance, HR, legal, and administrative functions would consolidate into Meridian's corporate structure. This is standard in acquisitions of this size and typically takes 6-9 months.

I recognize that items 5 and 6 involve potential headcount impacts for some employees. Our approach has consistently been to make competitive offers to individuals we want to retain and to provide generous transition packages for those who don't continue. In the LogicPath acquisition, every employee received either an offer or a separation package equal to 6 months' salary.

My diligence team is ready to begin as soon as the data room is available. Our financial advisor (Lazard) has already reviewed the public information and is prepared to move quickly once they have access.

Looking forward to next steps.

Gerald

--- Reply ---
From: David Aldric
To: Gerald Fisk
Date: February 23, 2025, 8:15 AM PST
Subject: RE: RE: Timeline Discussion — Project Lighthouse

Gerald —

Thank you for the detailed integration framework. The approach to the SF center and engineering retention is exactly what I needed to hear.

My board is fully aligned at 4-0. Goldman is preparing the financial materials you'll need. Wachtell is handling our side. What are your integration plans for our engineering team?

Apologies — I realize I just repeated the question you already answered. Disregard that line. I drafted this at 6 AM before reading your response fully.

To the substance: your plan for the SF center is compelling. The "Center of Excellence" framing will resonate with the engineering team and gives Marcus a clear mandate. The LogicPath retention number (94%) is noteworthy.

I do want to flag one item for your awareness. We recently restructured our non-executive severance policy, effective March 1, from 2x to 1x base salary. This was a planned corporate governance improvement — not related to any transaction — but it does reduce the company's aggregate severance exposure by approximately $9M. I mention this because it will show up in your financial diligence and I didn't want it to be a surprise without context.

The 4-0 board vote I referenced: Sarah Jiang resigned from the board in January. We are down to four directors. The Nominating Committee has a search underway but it's not a priority given current circumstances. All four remaining directors are fully supportive of pursuing Project Lighthouse.

On timing: I believe we should target LOI execution by March 31, with the definitive agreement in Q2. Data room will be ready for your team by March 14, aligned with your board meeting. Goldman is prepared to issue a fairness opinion once we have a formal offer on the table.

SUBJECT: Late February All-Hands — Q1 Progress
LOCATION: Main Auditorium, 14th Floor + Zoom for Remote
ATTENDEES: 355 in-person, 61 remote (416 total)
DURATION: 55 minutes (35 min presentation + 20 min Q&A)

[TRANSCRIPT BEGINS]

DAVID ALDRIC: Good afternoon everyone, and thank you for being here — whether that's in the auditorium or joining us remotely. I see 355 badges scanned in and 61 on Zoom, which means we have essentially full attendance. I appreciate that, especially on a Friday.

Let me start with the headline: Q1 is shaping up to be our best quarter in company history. Revenue up, customers happy, product execution flawless. This is what winning looks like.

I'm going to run through the key metrics and then turn it over to Marcus, Hannah, and Kevin for department updates. Then we'll do our usual Q&A. I've set aside 20 minutes for questions because I know there are topics on people's minds and I want to make sure we have time for them.

[slide change]

REVENUE AND BOOKINGS

Let me start with the numbers. Q1 bookings are tracking at $14.1M as of yesterday. Our Q1 quota is $36.8M, which puts us at 38% attainment at day 48 of the quarter. For those of you who've been here a few years, you know that Q1 is always back-loaded — we typically book 55-60% of the quarter's revenue in March. So at 38% on day 48, we are right on pace.

Kevin's sales team has the strongest pipeline we've ever had. Pipeline coverage for the remaining target is over 3x. I'm not going to jinx it, but I will say: we're in a very good position.

Expansion revenue is at $3.8M quarter-to-date against an $8.2M annual target. That's being driven by some significant upsells — the LogiFlow expansion, DB Schenker, and several mid-market accounts adding capacity.

On churn: we lost Pacific Freight this month. That's $145K ACV. It's painful any time we lose a customer, and Amanda's team did a thorough analysis of what happened there. Price was the primary factor — the competitor came in at a significantly lower price point. Q1 total churn is $290K, well below our $600K annual target cap. Our overall retention metrics remain strong.

[slide change]

PRODUCT UPDATE — MARCUS WEBB, VP ENGINEERING

MARCUS WEBB: Thanks, David. I'll try to be brief because I know you all want to get to Q&A.

Three things from engineering this quarter.

First, rec engine v3. Adoption continues to accelerate. As of this morning, 112 customers have activated rec engine v3. That's 51% of our customer base, up from 78 at the end of January. The feedback has been exceptional — it was the number one positive driver in our NPS survey, cited 38 times in customer comments. Platform stability has been rock-solid at 99.99% uptime for February.

Second, the Kubernetes migration. Lisa Chen's infrastructure team completed the disaster recovery Kubernetes migration ahead of schedule. All three AWS regions are now running K8s 1.29. The total migration took 26 days with zero customer impact. I want to call out Lisa and her team specifically — this was a complex migration involving live traffic rerouting across three regions and they executed it flawlessly.

Third, sprint velocity. Sprint 4 just wrapped and we completed 38 stories and 890 points with zero carryover. That's a 12% increase in velocity quarter-over-quarter and it's the most productive quarter in our history. Our open pull request count is down to 18 from 23 in January, which means we're not just writing more code — we're shipping more code.

I'm incredibly proud of this team. When I look at what 186 engineers are accomplishing, it gives me enormous confidence in our ability to execute on the roadmap.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Marcus. Hannah?

[slide change]

PRODUCT ROADMAP — HANNAH CHOI, VP PRODUCT

HANNAH CHOI: Thank you. I'll be quick. Two items.

First, we have the Axion Labs integration demo scheduled for this Friday, February 28. This is the dry run — three engineers from Ben Arujo's team will be running through the full integration in our staging environment. The internal demo for the broader team is March 3. If you want to attend the internal demo, there's a calendar invite going out this afternoon.

The Axion integration is one of the most exciting partnerships we've done. For those who haven't been following closely, Axion Labs provides real-time freight market data — pricing, capacity, transit times — for 200+ shipping lanes globally. Integrating their data into our platform gives our customers a unified view of their supply chain with market intelligence built in. The beta is targeting June, with general availability in September.

Second, the Q2 roadmap prioritization is complete. I shared the detailed document on Confluence yesterday, but the highlights are: (1) Axion integration GA, (2) rec engine v4 planning, (3) advanced analytics dashboard, and (4) mobile app for field operations. The rec engine v4 planning is the biggest investment — we're looking at incorporating real-time market signals from the Axion data feed into the recommendation model, which would be a genuine first in the industry.

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Hannah. Kevin?

[slide change]

SALES UPDATE — KEVIN OROSCO, VP SALES

KEVIN OROSCO: Afternoon, everyone. I'll keep this short.

Q1 bookings on track for our best quarter ever. The pipeline is the strongest I've seen in my three years here. We have 15 enterprise deals in late-stage negotiations totaling over $8M in potential ACV. The sales cycle is getting faster — average deal cycle time is 38 days this quarter, down from 42 days historically.

The market is moving in our direction. Supply chain optimization is not a nice-to-have anymore — it's a board-level priority for most logistics and manufacturing companies. Every RFP we see now has AI-driven optimization as a requirement, and that's where we win.

I also want to recognize the three new account executives who joined this month. Welcome to the team — you picked a great time to start.

[slide change]

DAVID ALDRIC: Thank you, Kevin.

CLOSING REMARKS

Let me close with something that I think is important for everyone to hear directly from me.

We are building for the next decade. Every decision I make is about ensuring Nextera's independence and long-term success. I know there's been speculation — let me be direct: we are not for sale.

I understand that in a market like this — where consolidation is happening across the enterprise software landscape — people naturally wonder about what's next for a company like ours. I've seen the Blind posts. I've heard the hallway conversations. And I want to address them head-on.

This company was founded nine years ago — our anniversary is March 28, and I'm told the events team has something special planned — with a vision of transforming how supply chains operate through intelligent automation. That vision has never been clearer or more achievable than it is right now. Our technology is the best in the market. Our customers are happier than they've ever been. Our financial performance is the strongest it's ever been. Why would I sell that?

The answer is: I wouldn't. And I'm not going to.

What I am going to do is keep investing in this business. We're hiring 20+ people in Q2. We just signed a lease for the 13th floor. We're building the Axion partnership. We're planning rec engine v4. These are not the actions of a company that's preparing to be acquired. These are the actions of a company that's building for the next decade.

So please: focus on the work. Focus on shipping great product. Focus on making customers successful. That's what got us here, and that's what will carry us forward.

Now let's do Q&A. I see some hands.

[Q&A SESSION — 20 minutes, 7 questions]

QUESTION 1 (remote, from Emily Park, Marketing):
Q: What's our plan for the industry conference in April? Are we doing a keynote this year?
A: Yes, we've been invited to deliver a keynote at SupplyChainExpo on April 15. Hannah and I will co-present on the Axion integration and the future of AI-driven supply chain optimization. It's a great stage for us.

QUESTION 2 (in-person, from Derek Nowak, Customer Success):
Q: Can you talk about the NPS results? Are we doing anything specific to address the detractor feedback?
A: Great question. NPS hit 64, up from 58. The primary improvement driver is rec engine v3 — our engineering team deserves enormous credit. On the detractor side, Amanda's team identified three accounts with pricing concerns and two with implementation speed concerns. We're doing a deep-dive on the red accounts on Monday. The pricing concerns are isolated to a few specific accounts and don't represent a systemic issue.

QUESTION 3 (in-person, from Jake Morrison, Engineering):
Q: Are there plans to expand the ML team beyond the two new hires? We're getting a lot of inbound interest in the rec engine and the current team is stretched.
A: Marcus?
MARCUS WEBB: We have two ML positions open now and we're looking at adding two more in Q2. The ML team is a priority — the rec engine work is driving measurable customer value and we want to invest ahead of demand. If you know great ML engineers, please refer them.

QUESTION 4 (in-person, from Samira Al-Rashid, Product):
Q: What's the timeline for the mobile app? We've been talking about it for two quarters.
A: Hannah?
HANNAH CHOI: It's on the Q2 roadmap as item number 4. We're targeting a design sprint in April with a working prototype by end of Q2. The initial scope is field operations — warehouse floor visibility and alert management. It won't be a full-featured mobile client for the platform, at least not in v1.

QUESTION 5 (remote, from Brian Teller, Sales):
Q: The retention bonus program mentions qualifying events including change of control. Should we read anything into that?
A: No. These are standard provisions that any well-run company includes. We added IPO as a qualifying event too — does that mean we're going public next week? Of course not.

The retention bonus program was designed to ensure that our key employees are rewarded for their loyalty and their contributions to the company's long-term success. It's a retention tool — that's literally in the name. The "qualifying events" language is standard legal drafting that covers the range of potential corporate events that could occur at any private company. We included change of control, IPO, and asset sales because those are the standard categories. I wouldn't read anything into the specific categories any more than I'd read into the fact that our fire insurance policy covers earthquakes — it doesn't mean we're expecting an earthquake.

Vanessa Kline's team can answer any specific questions you have about your individual agreement. The final enrollment deadline is March 15 and there's an information session on March 5.

QUESTION 6 (in-person, from Lisa Chen, Engineering):
Q: What's the status of the No Meeting Wednesdays experiment? Is it becoming permanent?
A: Vanessa?
VANESSA KLINE (from audience): We're collecting data through the engagement survey that launches March 3. Early feedback is positive — 89% of employees say they use Wednesdays for focused work. We'll make a permanent decision after the survey results are in, but I'd be surprised if we rolled it back given the response.

QUESTION 7 (in-person, from Tomas Lindgren, Customer Success):
Q: Can we get more detail on the Axion integration at the internal demo on March 3? Specifically, I have customers asking about data sovereignty — where does the Axion data live?
A: Hannah?
HANNAH CHOI: Absolutely. The March 3 demo will cover the architecture in detail. Short answer: Axion data is processed in our existing AWS infrastructure — same regions, same encryption, same compliance certifications. We're not sending customer data to Axion's systems. We're pulling market data from Axion into our platform. So from a data sovereignty perspective, it's a data ingestion model, not a data sharing model. Your customers' data stays exactly where it is.

DAVID ALDRIC: Great questions, everyone. That's all the time we have today. Let's finish Q1 strong. Thank you.

[TRANSCRIPT ENDS]

Post-meeting note: Employee sentiment poll conducted at conclusion of all-hands. Results: 58% "very confident" in company direction, 31% "somewhat confident," 8% "neutral," 3% "not confident." The "very confident" percentage is down from 61% at the previous all-hands in early February.

Total meeting duration: 55 minutes (35 min presentation, 20 min Q&A). 7 questions asked. All-hands recording available on Confluence by end of business Monday.

Title: Q3 Close-Out Forecast and Q4 Planning

Attendees: Marcus DeWitt, David Aldric (CEO), CFO Office, Tom Okafor
