--- BEGIN DOCUMENT ---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — Q3 CLOSE-OUT FORECAST AND Q4 PLANNING
ENTERPRISE SALES REVIEW
Prepared by: Marcus DeWitt, Director Enterprise Sales
Date: September 23, 2025
Attendees: Marcus DeWitt, David Aldric (CEO), CFO Office, Tom Okafor (Head of Revenue Operations)
Document Classification: Internal — Executive Confidential

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This report provides the executive leadership team with the Q3 2025 enterprise sales close-out forecast with eight days remaining in the quarter, a review of Q3 deal activity, and the Q4 2025 planning framework including pipeline analysis, target setting, and headcount recommendations. The enterprise sales organization enters the final week of Q3 in a strong position, with $8.7M in bookings closed against a $9.2M quarterly target (94.6% attainment). The forecast indicates that Q3 will close at $9.4M (102% of target) contingent on the execution of the BrightPath Health Systems contract, which is in final procurement review.

Q4 pipeline coverage stands at 3.2x ($47.1M unweighted pipeline against a $14.8M target), which is within the healthy range for enterprise sales cycles but will require disciplined execution to convert given the historically longer deal cycles in Q4 driven by customer budget approval timelines and holiday calendar compression.

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES

    Marcus DeWitt, Director Enterprise Sales — report author, responsible for the enterprise sales team (currently 8 account executives plus 2 sales engineers).

    David Aldric, CEO — attendee, provides strategic direction on deal prioritization and customer engagement. David participates directly in late-stage executive-level meetings for deals exceeding $500K ACV.

    Tom Okafor, Head of Revenue Operations — attendee, responsible for pipeline analytics, forecasting methodology, territory design, and sales process optimization. Tom's team maintains the Salesforce CRM instance and produces the pipeline and forecast reports referenced in this document.

    Nextera Solutions enterprise sales organization — the go-to-market team targeting companies with 500+ employees and deals with annual contract values exceeding $200K. The enterprise team is separate from the mid-market team (targeting companies with 100-500 employees) and the self-serve/SMB motion.

    BrightPath Health Systems — Stage 4 opportunity, $750K ACV. BrightPath is a regional healthcare system with 14 hospitals and 40+ outpatient facilities. They have been evaluating Nextera's supply chain analytics platform for medical supply chain optimization. The deal has been in procurement review since September 15.

    Lindenfeld Pharma — Stage 3 opportunity, $1.1M ACV. Lindenfeld is a mid-size pharmaceutical company with 6 manufacturing sites and complex API (active pharmaceutical ingredient) supply chains. Originally forecasted for Q3 close, the deal has been moved to Q4 due to Lindenfeld's internal budget cycle aligning approvals to their October fiscal period.

    Summit Electronics — closed-won, $470K ACV. Summit signed in early September for the core platform plus the anomaly detection module. Summit manufactures consumer electronics components and will use Nextera for component supplier risk monitoring.

3. Q3 2025 PERFORMANCE — DETAILED REVIEW

3.1 Bookings Summary

As of September 23, 2025, with 8 days remaining in the quarter:

    Q3 bookings target: $9.2M
    Q3 bookings closed to date: $8.7M (94.6% attainment)
    Q3 forecast (expected close by September 30): $9.4M (102% of target)

The forecast assumes that BrightPath Health Systems signs by September 29, adding $750K to the closed bookings. Excluding BrightPath, Q3 would close at $8.7M (94.6% attainment), which would represent the first below-target quarter in three quarters but would still be within the 90-105% acceptable performance band established by the board.

3.2 Deal Activity

Total deals closed in Q3 through September 23: 14 deals
    New logos: 7 (new customers signing their first Nextera contract)
    Expansions: 7 (existing customers adding modules, seats, or upgrading tiers)

Average deal size: $621K ACV across all 14 deals. This represents continued upward movement in deal size:
    Q1 2025 average deal size: $492K
    Q2 2025 average deal size: $548K
    Q3 2025 average deal size: $621K

The average selling price increase is driven by two factors: (a) the anomaly detection and supplier risk modules, launched in Q1 2025, are being attached to a higher percentage of deals (43% of Q3 deals included at least one new module versus 28% in Q1); and (b) the enterprise team has been more disciplined about qualifying opportunities at the right tier level during discovery, resulting in fewer deals that start at a lower tier and require post-sale expansion.

Notable Q3 closed deals:

    Summit Electronics: $470K ACV, new logo. Core platform + anomaly detection module. 3-year term. Sales cycle: 5 months. AE: Rina Vasquez.

    MedPharma Group: $890K ACV, expansion. Added supplier risk module and demand planning module to existing core platform deployment. The expansion was driven by MedPharma's CFO mandate to consolidate supply chain visibility tools after a Q2 supply disruption. AE: Jake Thornton.

    Velocity Automotive: $410K ACV, new logo. Core platform for automotive parts supply chain. 2-year term with year-2 expansion option for anomaly detection. AE: Aisha Obi.

3.3 Win Rate Analysis

    Enterprise win rate (Q3): 34%
    Mid-market win rate (Q3): 41%
    Blended win rate (Q3): 37%

The enterprise win rate of 34% is consistent with the trailing four-quarter average of 33%. The primary reasons for enterprise losses in Q3 were: (a) lost to incumbent vendor (3 deals — customers decided to expand existing SAP or Oracle supply chain solutions rather than adopt a new platform); (b) budget deferred to next fiscal year (2 deals); (c) lost to direct competitor (1 deal — lost to Kinaxis on a manufacturing-heavy opportunity where their MRP integration was more mature).

3.4 BrightPath Health Systems — Deal Update

BrightPath Health Systems represents the key outstanding Q3 deal. Status as of September 23:

    Stage: 4 (Procurement/Legal review)
    ACV: $750K
    Term: 36 months
    Modules: Core platform, anomaly detection, demand planning
    Champion: VP Supply Chain
    Economic buyer: CFO (approved budget in August 2025 board meeting)
    Current status: Procurement sent contract redline on September 22. The redline contains modifications to the limitation of liability clause and the data processing terms. Nextera Legal is reviewing the redline and expects to return a response by September 24.

Marcus DeWitt provided the following assessment: "We'll beat Q3 target if BrightPath closes on schedule. Their procurement team sent the redline yesterday — it's minor stuff."

The redline issues are standard for healthcare organizations and do not represent substantive commercial disagreements. BrightPath's VP Supply Chain has confirmed via email that the deal has internal approval and the redline is a procedural step. Expected signature date: September 29.

4. Q4 2025 PLANNING

4.1 Pipeline Overview

    Q4 bookings target: $14.8M
    Q4 pipeline (unweighted): $47.1M
    Q4 pipeline coverage: 3.2x ($47.1M / $14.8M)

Pipeline coverage of 3.2x is within the target range of 3.0-3.5x for enterprise sales. The pipeline includes 42 opportunities across all stages, with the following stage distribution:

    Stage 1 (Discovery): 12 opportunities, $14.2M unweighted
    Stage 2 (Technical Evaluation): 11 opportunities, $12.8M unweighted
    Stage 3 (Business Case/Budget): 10 opportunities, $11.6M unweighted
    Stage 4 (Procurement/Legal): 5 opportunities, $5.3M unweighted
    Stage 5 (Verbal Commit): 4 opportunities, $3.2M unweighted

Weighted pipeline (using stage-based probability weights): $16.2M, representing 109% coverage of the $14.8M target. The weighted pipeline provides a more realistic view of expected Q4 close and suggests that the $14.8M target is achievable with normal conversion rates.

David Aldric provided the following comment: "Pipeline coverage at 3.2x is healthy. But I want to see conversion rates hold. Last year we had 3.5x coverage and only hit 101% because deals slipped."

4.2 Key Q4 Opportunities

    Lindenfeld Pharma: $1.1M ACV, Stage 3. Moved from Q3 to Q4 commit following confirmation that Lindenfeld's internal budget approval aligns with their October fiscal cycle. Budget approval is now confirmed. Expected close: October 2025.

    Meridian Aerospace: $680K ACV, Stage 4. Aerospace parts supply chain. POC completed in September with strong results. Legal review underway. Expected close: November 2025.

    Pacific Rim Shipping: $540K ACV, Stage 2. Container logistics and port-to-warehouse visibility. Early stage but moving quickly due to an active RFP process. Decision expected by December 2025.

    TerraVerde Agriculture: $380K ACV, Stage 3. Agricultural commodity supply chain. Budget confirmed, evaluating Nextera against one competitor (E2open). Expected close: November 2025.

4.3 Headcount Recommendation

The enterprise sales team currently has 8 account executives (3 West, 3 Central, 2 East) plus 2 sales engineers. Based on the Q4 pipeline volume and the expanding deal count, Marcus DeWitt recommends adding 2 additional enterprise AEs in Q4 to handle the increased pipeline and ensure adequate coverage across territories.

Tom Okafor offered an alternative perspective: "The mid-market pipeline is actually stronger than enterprise right now. We should consider whether the two new AEs should be mid-market instead."

The mid-market pipeline stands at $28.4M unweighted against a $9.5M Q4 target (3.0x coverage), with a higher win rate (41% versus 34% enterprise) and shorter sales cycles (average 68 days versus 112 days for enterprise). The mid-market team currently has 5 AEs.

Recommendation: Hire 1 enterprise AE (East region, where coverage is thinnest) and 1 mid-market AE (general territory). Compensation budget for both roles: approximately $340K annual OTE ($170K each, split 50/50 base/variable). Recruiting timeline: begin search immediately, target start date late November to early December 2025 for both roles.

5. FORECAST METHODOLOGY NOTES

Forecasting uses a three-tier model maintained by Revenue Operations:

    Commit: Deals where the AE has high confidence in close within the quarter and the champion has verbally confirmed the timeline. Weighted at 90%.
    Best Case: Deals where the evaluation is positive and budget has been identified but timing or procurement process creates uncertainty. Weighted at 50%.
    Upside: Deals in early evaluation stages that could accelerate based on customer urgency. Weighted at 15%.

The Q3 close-out forecast of $9.4M consists of $8.7M closed + $750K in Commit (BrightPath at 90% probability). No Best Case or Upside deals are included in the Q3 forecast given the 8-day remaining window.

6. CONCLUSION

Q3 enterprise sales performance is strong, with the team on track to exceed target pending BrightPath execution. The Q4 pipeline is healthy at 3.2x coverage, and the Lindenfeld Pharma deal moving to Q4 with confirmed budget adds a strong anchor to the quarter. The headcount recommendation of 2 additional AEs (1 enterprise, 1 mid-market) is supported by pipeline volume and should be initiated immediately to have the new hires productive by Q1 2026.

Marcus DeWitt
Director Enterprise Sales
Nextera Solutions

The CAB is composed of 7 enterprise customers representing a combined $9.8M in annual recurring revenue. The CAB meets twice annually (Spring and Fall) to provide product feedback, share industry perspectives, preview upcoming roadmap themes, and advise on strategic priorities.

This session focused on three topics: (a) a review of product releases delivered since the Spring 2025 session, (b) a preview of 2026 product roadmap themes with a priority voting exercise, and (c) an open discussion on customer pain points and competitive landscape observations.

2. ATTENDEES

External Attendees (Customer Advisory Board Members):

    Crestline Logistics — VP Supply Chain. Crestline is a national logistics provider with 24 distribution centers. Nextera customer since 2022. ARR: $1.8M. Crestline uses the core platform, anomaly detection, and demand planning modules.

    Redwood Financial — CTO. Redwood is a financial services firm with supply chain exposure through its commercial lending portfolio. Nextera customer since 2023. ARR: $920K. Redwood uses the core platform and supplier risk module to monitor supply chain health of borrowers.

    Vantage Retail Group — COO. Vantage operates 340 retail stores across 28 states with centralized distribution. Nextera customer since 2023. ARR: $1.4M. Vantage uses the core platform and demand planning module for inventory optimization.

    NovaTech Industries — Head of Analytics. NovaTech is a diversified industrial manufacturer. Nextera customer since 2022. ARR: $1.6M. NovaTech is the most technically sophisticated CAB member, running advanced analytics workflows on top of Nextera's data export APIs.

    Three additional enterprise customers attended but are not individually quoted in this recap. Combined ARR: $4.1M.

Internal Attendees:

    Lena Cho, VP Customer Success — meeting facilitator and CAB program owner.
    Head of Product — presented 2026 roadmap themes and led the priority voting exercise.
    Chief Architect — provided technical deep-dive on planned AI capabilities and platform architecture evolution.
    David Aldric, CEO — participated in the opening remarks and closing discussion.

3. SESSION 1: PRODUCT RELEASE REVIEW (10:00 AM - 11:15 AM)

The Head of Product presented a summary of product releases delivered since the Spring 2025 CAB session. Key releases included:

    Anomaly Detection Module v2.1 (July 2025): Added multi-variable anomaly detection using ensemble methods. Reduced false positive rate from 12% to 6.8% based on production data across all customers. Added configurable alert thresholds by category (supplier, logistics, demand) and severity level.

    Demand Planning Dashboard Refresh (August 2025): Redesigned the demand planning UI based on feedback from the Spring 2025 CAB session. New features include: drag-and-drop scenario comparison, historical accuracy tracking with confidence intervals, and exportable PDF reports for executive distribution.

    API v3.0 (September 2025): Launched REST API version 3.0 with GraphQL support, improved rate limiting (10,000 requests/hour per customer, up from 5,000), and webhook support for real-time event notifications. This release was specifically requested by NovaTech at the Spring session.

    Platform Performance Improvements: Average API response time reduced from 340ms to 210ms through database query optimization and caching layer improvements. Dashboard load times reduced by 35% through front-end bundle optimization and lazy loading.

CAB member feedback on releases was collected through a brief survey at the start of the session:
    Anomaly Detection v2.1: Average satisfaction 4.3/5 (up from 3.6 for v2.0)
    Demand Planning Dashboard: Average satisfaction 4.1/5 (new dashboard, no baseline)
    API v3.0: Average satisfaction 4.6/5 (highest-rated release)

4. SESSION 2: 2026 ROADMAP PREVIEW AND PRIORITY VOTE (11:30 AM - 1:00 PM)

The Head of Product presented three major roadmap themes planned for 2026. Each theme was presented with a 15-minute overview, followed by 10 minutes of Q&A and discussion.

4.1 Theme 1: AI-Driven Scenario Planning (Target: H1 2026)

Concept: Use machine learning models to generate "what-if" scenarios for supply chain disruptions. Given a hypothetical disruption (port closure, supplier bankruptcy, demand spike), the system would model cascading effects across the supply chain and recommend mitigation strategies. The models would be trained on each customer's historical data and supplemented with industry-wide disruption databases.

Customer Feedback: Strong enthusiasm from all CAB members. Crestline's VP Supply Chain noted that their team currently builds scenarios manually in spreadsheets, which takes 2-3 days per scenario. NovaTech's Head of Analytics asked about model transparency and the ability to inspect feature importance in the scenario outputs. The Chief Architect confirmed that the planned architecture includes an explainability layer showing which input variables drive each scenario outcome.

4.2 Theme 2: Multi-Tier Supplier Visibility (Target: Q2 2026)

Concept: Extend supply chain visibility beyond direct (Tier 1) suppliers to include sub-suppliers (Tier 2 and Tier 3). The feature would use a combination of customer-provided supplier data, public corporate registries, and a proprietary data network to map multi-tier supplier relationships and identify concentration risks.

Customer Feedback: Crestline identified this as their top priority. The Crestline VP Supply Chain stated: "We've reduced stockouts 22% but we still can't see past our Tier 1 suppliers. Multi-tier visibility would be a game-changer."

The discussion revealed that multi-tier visibility is a shared pain point across industries. NovaTech described a situation where a Tier 3 component supplier in Southeast Asia experienced a factory fire, and NovaTech did not learn about the impact on their supply chain until 6 weeks later when their Tier 1 supplier reported delivery delays.

4.3 Theme 3: Sustainability Metrics Dashboard (Target: H2 2026)

Concept: Add ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) tracking capabilities to the platform, including carbon footprint estimation for supply chain activities, supplier diversity scoring, and regulatory compliance tracking for EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) requirements.

Customer Feedback: Mixed enthusiasm. Three CAB members rated this as important for regulatory compliance but not a competitive differentiator. Two members said their sustainability teams are separate from supply chain operations and would need to be involved in the evaluation. NovaTech expressed the strongest interest, noting that their board has established a 2027 deadline for comprehensive supply chain carbon reporting.

4.4 Priority Vote Results

Each CAB member voted on their top two priorities from the three themes:

    AI-Driven Scenario Planning: 6 of 7 votes (top priority)
    Mobile-First Dashboards: 5 of 7 votes (second priority)
    API Marketplace: 4 of 7 votes (third priority)

Note: "Mobile-First Dashboards" and "API Marketplace" were added as voting options based on CAB member requests during the open discussion, replacing the Sustainability Metrics theme in the vote. The Sustainability Metrics theme remains on the roadmap but was not included in the final priority vote after CAB members indicated that the two additional options better reflected their operational needs.

5. SESSION 3: OPEN DISCUSSION AND CUSTOMER FEEDBACK (2:00 PM - 3:15 PM)

5.1 Compliance and Security

Redwood Financial's CTO raised the topic of SOC 2 Type II certification: "SOC 2 Type II is a hard requirement for our compliance team. We need that cert by Q1 or we'll have to evaluate alternatives."

Lena Cho confirmed that the SOC 2 Type II audit fieldwork begins in November 2025, with the completed report expected in Q1 2026. The target is to have the Type II report available for customer distribution by March 2026. Redwood's CTO acknowledged this timeline as acceptable, contingent on Nextera meeting the Q1 2026 target.

5.2 Mobile-First Dashboards

Vantage Retail Group's COO made a case for mobile-first dashboards: "Our store managers don't sit at desks. If the analytics aren't on their phone, they don't exist."

Vantage described their use case: 340 store managers who need daily access to inventory replenishment dashboards, stockout alerts, and supplier delivery ETAs. Currently, store managers must log into the Nextera web application on a laptop or desktop, which is impractical during store hours. A mobile-optimized dashboard with push notifications would enable real-time supply chain visibility at the store level.

The Head of Product indicated that mobile-first dashboards could be incorporated into the H1 2026 roadmap alongside the AI scenario planning theme, as the mobile work is primarily front-end development and could run in parallel with the backend AI/ML development.

5.3 API Marketplace

NovaTech Industries' Head of Analytics proposed an API marketplace concept: "We've built 14 custom connectors on top of your API. Other customers are probably building the same things. An open marketplace would let us share and monetize these connectors."

The concept envisions a marketplace where customers and third-party developers can publish, discover, and install pre-built data connectors, workflow automations, and analytics templates. NovaTech offered to contribute their existing connectors as seed content for the marketplace if Nextera provides the platform infrastructure.

The Chief Architect noted that API v3.0 was designed with extensibility in mind and that the marketplace concept is technically feasible. The Head of Product committed to exploring the marketplace as a Q3/Q4 2026 initiative.

5.4 CEO Closing Remarks

David Aldric addressed the CAB at the close of the session: "This is exactly the kind of feedback that shapes our roadmap. We're building Nextera for the long haul and your input is how we get there."

David thanked the CAB members for their time and confirmed that Nextera would publish a formal response to all CAB recommendations within 6 weeks, including updated roadmap timelines for each priority item.

6. ACTION ITEMS

12 action items were assigned during the session, with owners and target dates:

    1. Product: Publish formal response to CAB priority vote — target: November 3, 2025
    2. Product: Scope mobile-first dashboard MVP for Vantage use case — target: October 15, 2025
    3. Product: Evaluate API marketplace feasibility — target: November 15, 2025
    4. Architecture: Document AI scenario planning model architecture — target: October 30, 2025
    5. Architecture: Research multi-tier supplier data sources — target: November 15, 2025
    6. CS: Share SOC 2 Type II timeline with all CAB members — target: September 30, 2025
    7. CS: Schedule 1:1 follow-ups with each CAB member — target: October 7, 2025
    8. CS: Coordinate Crestline integration requirements discussion with engineering — target: October 15, 2025
    9. Product: Evaluate NovaTech connector contribution model — target: November 1, 2025
    10. CS: Distribute CAB recap document to all members — target: September 30, 2025
    11. Product: Schedule Vantage store manager ride-along for mobile dashboard research — target: October 20, 2025
    12. Architecture: Publish API marketplace technical assessment — target: December 1, 2025

Next CAB meeting: Spring 2026 (tentatively March 2026). Date to be confirmed by December 2025.

Respectfully submitted,
Lena Cho
VP Customer Success
Nextera Solutions

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — IMPLEMENTATION STATUS REPORT
CUSTOMER: Cascade Beverage Co.
REPORT DATE: September 23, 2025
CONTRACT ACV: $290,000
IMPLEMENTATION PHASE: Integration & Data Migration (Phase 2 of 4)

Prepared by: Derek Huang, Implementation Lead
Distribution: Priya Nair (Sr. Customer Success Manager), Lena Cho (VP Customer Success), Cascade Beverage Project Team
Document Classification: Internal

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This status report covers the implementation progress for Cascade Beverage Co. as of September 23, 2025. Cascade is a national beverage distributor with 6 warehouse locations and approximately $800M in annual revenue. The implementation is in Phase 2 (Integration and Data Migration) of Nextera's standard 4-phase, 60-day implementation playbook. Despite a 3-day delay caused by a schema mismatch in Cascade's warehouse management system, the implementation remains on track for the original go-live target of October 20, 2025 (Day 56 of the 60-day playbook).

Key milestones achieved this period: completed data mapping for 8 of 14 ERP integrations, ingested 18 months of historical purchase order data (1.2 million transactions), and deployed a custom translation layer to resolve the warehouse management system schema mismatch. User acceptance testing (UAT) has been scheduled for October 6 at Cascade's Denver headquarters.

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES

    Derek Huang, Implementation Lead — Nextera's primary technical owner for the Cascade implementation. Derek has completed 11 enterprise implementations at Nextera and specializes in complex multi-system integration scenarios.

    Priya Nair, Sr. Customer Success Manager — Nextera's commercial relationship owner for Cascade. Priya manages the overall account relationship, coordinates executive communication, and monitors implementation progress against the 60-day SLA.

    Cascade Beverage Co. — new Nextera customer. Contract signed August 22, 2025. ACV: $290K. Cascade is a national beverage distribution company serving 14,000 retail outlets across 22 states. They operate 6 warehouse/distribution facilities.

    Cascade IT Team — 4 engineers assigned to the Nextera integration project from Cascade's internal IT organization. The team includes 2 ERP specialists (SAP), 1 warehouse management system administrator, and 1 data engineer.

    Maya Torres, Cascade Project Sponsor (VP Operations) — the executive sponsor on the Cascade side. Maya approved the Nextera purchase and is responsible for ensuring organizational adoption and business value realization.

    Lisa Park, Integration Engineer — second Nextera integration engineer added to the project on September 18 to accelerate custom middleware development for the remaining 6 ERP integrations.

3. IMPLEMENTATION PLAYBOOK STATUS

Nextera's standard enterprise implementation follows a 4-phase, 60-day playbook:

    Phase 1: Discovery and Planning (Days 1-10) — COMPLETE
    Phase 2: Integration and Data Migration (Days 11-35) — IN PROGRESS (Day 32 of 35)
    Phase 3: User Acceptance Testing (Days 36-50) — SCHEDULED (begins October 6)
    Phase 4: Go-Live and Hypercare (Days 51-60) — PLANNED (target October 20)

Current project day: Day 32 (September 23, 2025).
Go-live target: October 20, 2025 (Day 56).

The 3-day delay incurred during Phase 2 due to the warehouse management system schema mismatch has been absorbed within the Phase 2 buffer period. No impact to the Phase 3 or Phase 4 schedule.

4. INTEGRATION PROGRESS

4.1 ERP Integration Status

Cascade's technology landscape includes 14 ERP system integrations required for full deployment:

    Completed (8 integrations):
    — SAP S/4HANA: Purchase order management (inbound/outbound data flows)
    — SAP S/4HANA: Vendor master data synchronization
    — SAP S/4HANA: Material master data synchronization
    — SAP S/4HANA: Inventory positions and stock levels
    — SAP S/4HANA: Accounts payable and payment terms
    — Cascade CRM (Salesforce): Customer and retail outlet master data
    — Cascade BI (Tableau): Reporting data exports (one-way, from Nextera)
    — Cascade Email System (Microsoft 365): Alert and notification delivery

    These 8 integrations use Nextera's standard SAP, Salesforce, Tableau, and Microsoft connectors. Derek Huang noted: "The SAP integrations are clean but their warehouse management system uses a legacy schema that doesn't map to our standard connectors. We've built a translation layer that handles it."

    Pending (6 integrations requiring custom middleware):
    — Warehouse Management System (WMS): Legacy system with non-standard product codes and custom data structures (see Section 5 below)
    — Transportation Management System (TMS): Carrier rate tables and shipment tracking
    — Demand Forecasting Tool: Proprietary internal tool built on Python/pandas
    — Quality Management System (QMS): Product recall and quality hold data
    — EDI Gateway: Electronic data interchange with retail customer POS systems
    — IoT Sensor Platform: Warehouse temperature and humidity monitoring data

    The 6 remaining integrations require custom middleware because Cascade uses either legacy systems with non-standard schemas, proprietary internal tools, or IoT platforms that do not have pre-built Nextera connectors. Lisa Park was added to the team on September 18 to handle middleware development for these integrations.

4.2 Historical Data Migration

Ingested data:
    — 18 months of historical purchase order data: 1,200,000 transactions covering the period March 2024 through August 2025
    — 23,000 SKUs mapped from Cascade's product catalog to Nextera's taxonomy
    — 8,400 vendor records synchronized from SAP vendor master
    — 14,000 retail outlet records synchronized from Salesforce CRM

Data validation: Initial data quality checks identified 342 duplicate vendor records (4.1% of total) and 187 SKU mapping conflicts where Cascade's product codes mapped to multiple Nextera taxonomy entries. Derek's team resolved the vendor duplicates through a deduplication script validated by Cascade's data engineer. The SKU mapping conflicts were resolved through a mapping review session with Cascade's category management team on September 19, where each conflict was manually resolved and the mapping table was updated.

5. WAREHOUSE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM SCHEMA ISSUE

5.1 Problem Description

Cascade's warehouse management system (WMS) is a 12-year-old on-premise application originally built by a software vendor that was acquired and discontinued in 2019. Cascade's IT team has maintained and extended the system internally since then. The WMS uses a non-standard product identification schema that differs from both Cascade's SAP system and industry-standard product codes (UPC/EAN).

Specifically, the WMS uses a proprietary 8-character alphanumeric product code format (e.g., "BV-A2-004") that encodes the beverage category (BV=beverage, SP=spirits, DA=dairy), warehouse zone (A1-F6), and sequential item number. These codes do not map directly to Nextera's product taxonomy or to the UPC codes used in Cascade's SAP system.

5.2 Resolution

Derek's team built a translation layer that maps between the three code systems: WMS proprietary codes, SAP material numbers, and Nextera taxonomy identifiers. The translation layer operates as a middleware service that intercepts data flowing from the WMS to Nextera and performs real-time code translation using a lookup table maintained jointly by Cascade's WMS administrator and Nextera's integration team.

The translation layer was deployed on September 20 and has been processing WMS data for 3 days without errors. The lookup table currently covers 23,000 SKUs (the complete active product catalog). New SKUs added to the WMS will require a corresponding entry in the translation table, which Cascade's WMS administrator will manage through a simple web interface provided as part of the middleware.

The schema mismatch was identified on September 12 and the translation layer was fully deployed on September 20, representing a 3-business-day delay against the original integration schedule. This delay was absorbed within the Phase 2 buffer period (5 days of buffer were allocated in the original project plan).

Priya Nair provided the following assessment: "Cascade is complex but on track. The schema issue cost us 3 days but we've absorbed it within the original 60-day window."

6. WAREHOUSE LOCATIONS

Cascade Beverage operates 6 warehouse/distribution facilities, each of which will be connected to the Nextera platform:

    Denver, CO (HQ and primary distribution): 450,000 sq ft, handles 35% of total volume
    Phoenix, AZ: 280,000 sq ft, handles 18% of volume
    Atlanta, GA: 320,000 sq ft, handles 20% of volume
    Chicago, IL: 260,000 sq ft, handles 12% of volume
    Dallas, TX: 240,000 sq ft, handles 10% of volume
    Portland, OR: 180,000 sq ft, handles 5% of volume

All 6 facilities use the same WMS instance (centrally hosted at Denver) and the same SAP S/4HANA deployment. Integration is centralized, so the technical work applies to all facilities simultaneously. However, UAT will be conducted at Denver first, with remote validation sessions for the other 5 facilities during the following week.

7. USER ACCEPTANCE TESTING PLAN

UAT is scheduled for October 6, 2025, at Cascade's Denver headquarters.

Participants:
    Cascade: 12 participants including Maya Torres (VP Operations, project sponsor), 4 warehouse operations managers, 3 procurement analysts, 2 demand planners, and 2 IT team members.
    Nextera: 3 engineers on-site (Derek Huang, Lisa Park, and one additional integration engineer from the Denver-based team).

UAT Scope:
    Day 1 (October 6): Core platform walkthrough, dashboard configuration, data accuracy validation against SAP source records, and historical data spot-checks.
    Day 2 (October 7): Integration testing — live data flow verification from SAP, WMS (via translation layer), and CRM into Nextera. Alert configuration and notification testing.
    Day 3 (October 8): Anomaly detection module testing with simulated disruption scenarios. Demand planning module walkthrough with Cascade's demand planning team.

Success Criteria:
    — 100% of historical data accessible and matching SAP source records (tolerance: <0.1% discrepancy)
    — Real-time data flow latency under 60 seconds from source system change to Nextera dashboard update
    — All 6 warehouse locations visible and reporting correctly
    — Zero critical defects; minor defects documented and scheduled for resolution before go-live

Maya Torres expressed enthusiasm for the UAT milestone: "We're excited about the UAT milestone. Our Denver team has been asking when they'll get hands on the dashboards."

8. RISK REGISTER

    Risk 1: Custom middleware for 6 remaining integrations may reveal additional schema incompatibilities.
    Mitigation: Lisa Park is conducting schema analysis for all 6 systems before beginning middleware development. Any issues will be identified before code is written.
    Likelihood: Medium. Impact: Low (buffer time available).

    Risk 2: UAT may uncover data accuracy issues in the translation layer for edge-case SKUs.
    Mitigation: The translation layer includes comprehensive logging. Any mapping failures are logged with full context and queued for manual resolution.
    Likelihood: Low. Impact: Low (individual SKU fixes, not systemic).

    Risk 3: Go-live may be delayed if Cascade's demand planning team requires additional training.
    Mitigation: Pre-UAT training materials have been shared with Cascade's demand planners. A dedicated training session is scheduled for October 9, the day after UAT.
    Likelihood: Low. Impact: Medium (could shift go-live by 3-5 days).

9. NEXT MILESTONES

    September 30: Complete middleware development for TMS and demand forecasting integrations
    October 3: Complete middleware for QMS, EDI, and IoT integrations
    October 6-8: UAT at Denver HQ

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS, INC.
MINUTES OF SPECIAL MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
February 26, 2025

The special meeting of the Board of Directors of Nextera Solutions, Inc. was called to order at 9:00 AM Pacific Standard Time by Board Chair Robert Kessler. The meeting was held in the executive boardroom on the 14th floor of the company's headquarters at 1 Market Street, San Francisco, California.

APPROVAL OF MINUTES

The minutes of the previous special board session (February 5, 2025, NXS-BOD-2025-SP03) were approved unanimously. There were no corrections or amendments.

AGENDA ITEM 1 — PROJECT LIGHTHOUSE STATUS

Mr. Aldric presented a status update on Project Lighthouse, the company's confidential discussions with Meridian Corp regarding a potential acquisition.

Mr. Aldric reported that Meridian Corp's CEO Gerald Fisk has indicated an intent to present a formal offer in the $900M range following Meridian's board meeting on March 14, 2025. Mr. Aldric noted that his most recent conversation with Mr. Fisk took place on February 23, 2025, and that both parties expressed alignment on timeline.

Key points from Mr. Aldric's update:

1. Meridian Corp has completed its preliminary internal assessment and Mr. Fisk has communicated intent to seek board authorization for a formal offer at the March 14 Meridian board meeting.

2. The expected offer range is approximately $900M, consistent with prior discussions. Mr. Aldric noted that Mr. Fisk has referenced a range of $850M to $950M in prior conversations, with $900M as the most frequently cited midpoint.

3. Mr. Fisk has expressed intent to sign a letter of intent by end of March 2025, contingent on Meridian board approval.

4. Integration planning: Mr. Fisk has communicated that Meridian intends to retain all Nextera engineering employees and maintain the San Francisco office as a Meridian Center of Excellence for supply chain AI. All engineers would receive offer letters as part of the transaction.

5. The relationship between the two companies remains constructive and professional. No material disagreements have arisen during preliminary discussions.

Discussion: Mr. Whitfield asked about Meridian's financing structure. Mr. Aldric deferred to Goldman Sachs. Mr. Caldwell stated that based on publicly available information, Meridian Corp has approximately $2.8B in available credit facilities and $1.4B in cash and equivalents, sufficient to fund an all-cash transaction in the $900M range without requiring additional debt issuance or equity dilution.

Ms. Patel asked about competitive bidders. Mr. Aldric stated that the board's current strategy is to negotiate exclusively with Meridian rather than conduct a broader process. Mr. Stern from Wachtell confirmed that the board's fiduciary duties are satisfied provided the board has sufficient information to evaluate the fairness of any offer, which Goldman Sachs' valuation analysis supports. Mr. Stern noted that the board should periodically reassess whether a broader process is warranted.

AGENDA ITEM 2 — GOLDMAN SACHS PRELIMINARY VALUATION ANALYSIS

Ms. Vasquez presented Goldman Sachs' preliminary valuation analysis for Nextera Solutions, prepared by the Goldman Sachs Mergers & Acquisitions team under the direction of Managing Director Jonathan Caldwell.

Ms. Vasquez presented Goldman Sachs' preliminary valuation analysis indicating a fair value range of $820M to $1.05B based on comparable transactions and DCF analysis.

Methodology and findings:

A. Comparable Company Analysis
Goldman Sachs identified 12 comparable public companies in the supply chain technology and logistics SaaS sectors. The analysis used the following metrics:
- EV/Revenue multiples: range 5.8x to 9.2x, median 7.4x
- EV/ARR multiples: range 6.2x to 9.8x, median 7.8x
- Applied to Nextera's current ARR of $122.4M (as of February 14, 2025)
- Comparable company implied valuation range: $758M to $1.2B
- Selected range (using median multiples and growth-adjusted factors): $820M to $960M

B. Discounted Cash Flow Analysis
Goldman Sachs prepared a five-year DCF model based on Nextera's financial plan and management assumptions:
- Revenue CAGR assumption: 22% (FY2025-FY2029)
- Terminal growth rate: 3.5%
- Weighted average cost of capital (WACC): 12.5%
- Terminal value methodology: Gordon Growth Model, cross-checked with exit multiple
- DCF implied enterprise value: $870M to $1.05B
- Sensitivity analysis: $780M (bear case, 18% CAGR) to $1.15B (bull case, 26% CAGR)

C. Precedent Transaction Analysis
Goldman Sachs reviewed 8 precedent M&A transactions in the supply chain technology sector completed in 2023-2025:
- Transaction multiples: range 6.5x to 10.2x ARR, median 8.1x
- Precedent transaction implied valuation: $796M to $1.25B
- Selected range (adjusting for Nextera's growth profile and margin trajectory): $850M to $1.05B

D. Synthesis
Goldman Sachs' preliminary fair value range: $820M to $1.05B
- This represents 6.9x to 8.8x Nextera's current ARR of $122.4M
- Mr. Caldwell noted that this range may be adjusted upward when Q1 results are finalized, as the company is tracking 7% above plan
- Meridian's indicated $900M offer falls within the lower-middle portion of the fair value range

Mr. Caldwell: "Our preliminary analysis supports a fair value range of $820M to $1.05B. The $900M range indicated by Meridian is within our fair value band, though we note it is below the midpoint. As Q1 performance data becomes available, we expect to narrow and potentially adjust this range upward."

Ms. Liu presented additional detail on premium analysis: the $900M midpoint represents a 7.4x ARR multiple, which Goldman Sachs considers reasonable but not aggressive for a company with Nextera's growth rate (22%+ revenue CAGR) and margin profile (79% gross margins). For context, the average premium for comparable transactions was 8.1x ARR.

Discussion: Mr. Kessler asked whether Goldman Sachs would recommend holding for a higher offer. Mr. Caldwell stated that this is ultimately a board decision but noted that the Q1 outperformance, if sustained, would support an argument for a higher valuation. He recommended the board evaluate the formal offer once received and not commit to a specific floor at this time.

Ms. Patel asked about the timing of the formal fairness opinion. Mr. Caldwell confirmed that Goldman Sachs will issue a formal fairness opinion when a definitive offer is received, expected after Meridian's March 14 board meeting. He noted that the preliminary valuation analysis presented today would be refined into a formal fairness opinion letter, which typically requires 5-7 business days of work once a definitive offer is received. The fairness opinion is a prerequisite for the board to approve any definitive agreement.

Mr. Whitfield raised the question of employee disclosure timing. Ms. Dominguez advised that under Delaware law, there is no obligation to disclose to employees until a definitive agreement is signed, but best practice suggests preparation of employee communications in advance. She recommended that VP People Vanessa Kline be briefed on Project Lighthouse approximately two weeks before any planned announcement, to prepare FAQ documents, retention communication, and logistics for an all-hands disclosure event. The board agreed to table the employee disclosure discussion until a formal offer is received.

Mr. Kessler asked about tax implications of the transaction structure. Ms. Vasquez reported that her team is modeling both asset sale and stock sale structures. At $900M, the tax differential between structures is approximately $40M-$60M in aggregate across all stockholders. Goldman Sachs has recommended pursuing a stock sale structure, which is more favorable for existing stockholders. Mr. Stern confirmed that Wachtell is reviewing the structural alternatives and will present a comparative analysis by March 10.

Goldman Sachs engagement terms (for the record):
- Retainer: $500K (paid upon engagement, January 2025)
- Success fee: 0.5% of transaction value (payable upon closing)
- At $900M transaction value, the success fee would be $4.5M
- Total Goldman Sachs compensation at $900M: $5.0M
- Expense reimbursement cap: $75K

- Part-time support from finance (Angela Torres), HR (Vanessa Kline), and engineering (Marcus Webb)

Ms. Dominguez noted that Wachtell Lipton has billed approximately $180K to date on Project Lighthouse, with the hourly rate for the lead partner (David Stern) at $2,100 per hour and associates at $1,250 per hour. Total Wachtell engagement is projected at $300K-$400K through data room completion.

Discussion: Mr. Kessler asked Ms. Dominguez to prepare a board disclosure timeline assuming a Q2 2025 signing. Ms. Dominguez committed to delivering a draft disclosure timeline by March 7.

AGENDA ITEM 4 — BOARD RESOLUTIONS

After discussion of the foregoing items, the following resolutions were presented:

RESOLUTION 1:
RESOLVED, that the Board of Directors hereby authorizes (a) continuation of Project Lighthouse discussions with Meridian Corp and (b) opening of the virtual data room to Meridian Corp upon receipt of a formal letter of intent, subject to review and approval of LOI terms by the General Counsel.

Vote: 4-0 in favor. Motion carried unanimously.

RESOLUTION 2:
RESOLVED, that the Board of Directors hereby authorizes the CEO and CFO to continue engagement with Goldman Sachs and Wachtell Lipton in connection with Project Lighthouse, including the preparation of financial materials, valuation analysis, and legal documentation as required.

Vote: 4-0 in favor. Motion carried unanimously.

RESOLUTION 3:
RESOLVED, that the Board of Directors directs the General Counsel to prepare a preliminary board disclosure timeline and stockholder communication plan, assuming a definitive agreement signing in Q2 2025, and to present this plan at the next board session.

Vote: 4-0 in favor. Motion carried unanimously.

AGENDA ITEM 5 — BUSINESS UPDATE (NON-LIGHTHOUSE)

Mr. Aldric provided a brief update on business operations separate from Project Lighthouse matters:

1. Rec engine v3 adoption has reached 102 customers (47% of the customer base), with customer satisfaction scoring 4.7 out of 5.0. Zero P1 or P2 incidents since launch. Mr. Aldric noted that v3 is the company's most successful product launch to date.

2. Q1 revenue is tracking 7% above plan. February revenue came in at $10.8M against a $10.2M plan. March is projected at $11.0M. Total Q1 revenue is projected at $31.8M against a $29.7M plan.

3. The SOC 2 Type II audit commences March 3. All pre-audit remediation items have been completed. Ms. Dominguez confirmed that no audit findings are anticipated that would impede the data room timeline.

4. Headcount stands at 414 with 30 open positions. The spring hiring push targets 20+ hires in Q2 across engineering, sales, and customer success.

Mr. Kessler thanked Mr. Aldric for the business update and noted that the company's operational strength supports the board's negotiating position in Project Lighthouse discussions.

EXECUTIVE SESSION

The Board entered executive session at 10:45 AM. Management and external advisors were excused. The executive session lasted 20 minutes.

Upon return from executive session, Mr. Kessler reported that no additional actions were taken.

ADJOURNMENT

There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 11:10 AM. Total meeting duration: 2 hours 10 minutes.

The next regular board meeting is scheduled for March 18, 2025. A special session may be convened upon receipt of a formal offer from Meridian Corp.

Respectfully submitted,
Maria Fuentes
Corporate Secretary
Nextera Solutions, Inc.

Two full-time paralegals (Jennifer Okafor and Raj Sundaram) are assigned to the data room project through completion. They handle document formatting, redaction of personally identifiable information, and upload to Intralinks.

V. DOCUMENT FORMATTING STANDARDS

All documents must conform to the following standards before upload:

---

From: Vanessa Kim <vkim@nextera.io>
To: Head of Product <product@nextera.io>
Cc: Lena Cho <lcho@nextera.io>, Axion Labs Partner Team <partnerships@axionlabs.io>
Date: September 29, 2025, 10:22 AM PT
Subject: Axion Labs Connector — Customer Feedback Summary

Hi team,

I've compiled the feedback from all 3 beta customers on the Axion Labs real-time data connector. The beta program ran for 6 weeks (August 18 through September 28) and the results are ready for review ahead of the GA decision.

BETA PROGRAM OVERVIEW

The Axion Labs real-time data connector replaces batch-based data synchronization with streaming data delivery for customers who need sub-second latency on supply chain data updates. The connector was developed jointly by Nextera and the Axion Labs partner engineering team over a 4-month development sprint (May through August 2025). The connector sits between customer source systems and the Nextera platform, using Axion's proprietary streaming infrastructure to deliver change data capture (CDC) events in real time.

Three enterprise customers participated in the beta program, each representing a different integration architecture and data volume profile:

    1. Crestline Logistics — Nextera's largest customer by ARR ($1.8M). Crestline has the highest data volume among beta participants, processing approximately 2.4 million data events per day across their 24 distribution centers. Their primary use case is real-time shipment tracking and inventory position updates.

    2. Vantage Retail Group — 340 retail stores, $1.4M ARR. Vantage's use case centers on real-time point-of-sale data integration to drive automated replenishment triggers. Their data volume is approximately 800,000 events per day during peak retail hours.

    3. GreenLeaf Supply — agricultural commodities distributor, $620K ARR. GreenLeaf operates a custom Apache Kafka pipeline for their internal data streaming and needed to validate that the Axion connector could integrate with their existing infrastructure without requiring architectural changes.

FEEDBACK BY CUSTOMER

1. Crestline Logistics

Performance Results:
    — Data latency improvement: 94% reduction, from 15-minute batch intervals to sub-200ms streaming delivery. Crestline's previous integration relied on scheduled batch exports from their TMS (Transportation Management System) every 15 minutes. The Axion connector replaced this with continuous CDC streaming.
    — Data volume handled: 2.4M events/day sustained over the 6-week beta with zero data loss confirmed through end-to-end reconciliation audits performed at weeks 2, 4, and 6.
    — Availability: 99.99% uptime during the beta period (total downtime: approximately 2.6 minutes across 6 weeks, caused by a planned Axion infrastructure maintenance window).

Business Impact Reported by Crestline:
    — Morning planning meetings now use real-time data instead of data from the previous day's final batch run. This eliminates the "data gap" between the last batch run (typically 11:45 PM) and the 7:00 AM planning meeting.
    — Crestline's logistics coordinators can now respond to in-transit shipment anomalies within minutes rather than waiting for the next batch cycle to detect them.

Crestline provided the following feedback: "The streaming connector eliminated our overnight batch dependency entirely. Our morning planning meetings now use real-time data instead of yesterday's numbers."

Crestline's recommendation: Proceed to GA. No blocking issues identified.

2. Vantage Retail Group

Performance Results:
    — Data flow: Processed approximately 800,000 events/day during the beta, with peak throughput of 1,200 events/second during the Saturday afternoon shopping window.
    — Overall reliability: 99% of the time the connector performed as expected, with zero data loss under normal operating conditions.

Issue Identified:
    Vantage encountered 2 edge cases where the connector dropped messages during SAP batch export windows. Specifically:
    — October incident (Week 3): At approximately 2:00 AM PT during Vantage's nightly SAP batch export, the Axion connector dropped approximately 200 messages over a 10-minute window. The drop occurred because the SAP batch export creates a burst of 8,000+ change events in a 2-minute window, exceeding the connector's default buffer size. The connector's internal queue overflowed and the excess messages were silently discarded.
    — Second incident (Week 5): Same root cause, same time window, approximately 200 messages dropped. The drop represents less than 0.01% of Vantage's daily event volume.

Vantage provided the following feedback: "Works great 99% of the time. We hit a glitch during our 2AM SAP export window — the connector dropped about 200 messages over 10 minutes. Need that fixed before GA."

Root Cause Analysis: The Axion Labs engineering team traced the issue to the connector's internal message buffer, which defaults to a 5,000-event queue. During the SAP batch export burst, the queue fills and begins dropping events using a "drop-oldest" strategy. The fix involves expanding the default buffer to 25,000 events and adding a backpressure mechanism that throttles the ingest rate rather than dropping events when the queue approaches capacity.

Axion Labs has committed to delivering the fix in their next connector release, targeted for October 10, 2025. The fix has been developed and is in QA testing at Axion. Vantage has agreed to validate the fix in a 1-week retest following the release.

Vantage's recommendation: Proceed to GA after the SAP batch export fix is validated.

3. GreenLeaf Supply

Performance Results:
    — Kafka compatibility: Confirmed working with GreenLeaf's custom Apache Kafka pipeline. No modifications to GreenLeaf's existing Kafka configuration were required. The Axion connector publishes events to a dedicated Kafka topic, and GreenLeaf's existing consumer applications process the events through their standard pipeline.
    — Data volume: Approximately 400,000 events/day, with peak throughput during harvest season data processing.
    — Integration effort: Zero custom code required on GreenLeaf's side. The connector was configured through the Axion management console and began delivering events to GreenLeaf's Kafka cluster within 4 hours of activation.

GreenLeaf confirmed that the connector works with their custom Kafka pipeline with no modifications needed. GreenLeaf's infrastructure team was particularly impressed with the zero-code integration model, noting that previous partner connectors have required 2-4 weeks of custom integration development.

GreenLeaf's recommendation: Proceed to GA. No issues identified.

GA RECOMMENDATION

Vanessa Kim summarized: "All three beta customers want to move to GA. The feedback is overwhelmingly positive. The SAP edge case is the only blocker and Axion is on it."

Recommended GA timeline:
    October 10: Axion releases connector update with SAP batch export fix
    October 10-17: Vantage validates fix in production
    October 15: Joint GA announcement (Nextera + Axion Labs), pending Vantage validation
    October 15 onward: Connector available to all Nextera customers through the Axion Labs integration catalog

The GA announcement is planned as a joint press release and blog post from both Nextera and Axion Labs. The marketing teams from both companies have been coordinating the announcement materials since September 15. The announcement will include customer quotes from all three beta participants (pending their communications team approvals).

Lena Cho added the following perspective: "This is exactly the kind of partnership that drives retention. Customers are seeing measurable value from the integration, not just a logo on a slide."

Please let me know if you have any questions or if the Product team needs additional data before the GA decision meeting on October 3.

Thanks,
Vanessa Kim
Director of Partnerships
Nextera Solutions

DOCUMENT 3 OF 3
Type: Churn Analysis Report
Title: Q3 2025 Churn Analysis and Prevention Report
Date: 2025-09-30
Prepared By: Tom Okafor, Head of Revenue Operations
Recipients: Executive Leadership Team
Classification: Internal — Confidential

--- BEGIN DOCUMENT ---

NEXTERA SOLUTIONS — Q3 2025 CHURN ANALYSIS AND PREVENTION REPORT
Prepared by: Tom Okafor, Head of Revenue Operations
Date: September 30, 2025
Distribution: Executive Leadership Team
Document Classification: Internal — Confidential

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This report provides the Q3 2025 churn analysis for Nextera Solutions, covering customer attrition, revenue impact, root cause analysis, net revenue retention performance, and the performance of the newly deployed predictive churn model. Q3 gross churn was $520,000 in ARR across 4 accounts, representing a gross churn rate of 0.43% on Nextera's $120M ARR base. Net revenue retention for Q3 was 118%, driven by $6.2M in expansion revenue that substantially offset the churn.

The churn rate of 0.43% is the lowest quarterly gross churn rate in 2025, down from 0.68% in Q1 and 0.52% in Q2. However, the loss of Coastal Freight Services to a competitor highlights a product gap (native TMS integration) that the Customer Success team has been flagging for multiple quarters.

2. REFERENCED ENTITIES

    Tom Okafor, Head of Revenue Operations — report author, responsible for churn analysis, retention metrics, and the predictive churn model.

    Lena Cho, VP Customer Success — co-owner of the retention program, responsible for customer engagement strategies and the success team's at-risk account intervention process.

    Nextera Solutions customer base — 312 active accounts as of September 30, 2025, representing $120M in total ARR. The customer base spans 14 industry verticals, with the largest concentrations in manufacturing (28%), logistics and transportation (22%), retail (18%), and healthcare (12%).

    MidAtlantic Distributors — churned account, $210K ARR. MidAtlantic was a regional food distribution company based in Baltimore, MD. Nextera customer since March 2023.

    Coastal Freight Services — churned account, $145K ARR. Coastal was a regional freight brokerage based in Jacksonville, FL. Nextera customer since January 2024.

3. Q3 2025 CHURN DETAIL

3.1 Churned Accounts

Four accounts churned in Q3 2025, totaling $520,000 in ARR:

    Account 1: MidAtlantic Distributors — $210,000 ARR
    Churn Date: August 31, 2025
    Churn Reason: Corporate acquisition and tool consolidation. MidAtlantic was acquired by a larger national food distribution company (NationalFoods Inc.) in July 2025. The acquiring company operates its own supply chain analytics platform (a custom-built solution on SAP BW) and consolidated MidAtlantic onto their existing toolset as part of the post-acquisition integration. The churn was communicated to Nextera by MidAtlantic's CTO during a call on July 28, with a 30-day notice period.

    Controllability Assessment: Uncontrollable. The acquisition was not foreseeable, and the acquiring company's decision to consolidate tools was made at the corporate level without a competitive evaluation. Nextera had no opportunity to retain the account.

    Account 2: Coastal Freight Services — $145,000 ARR
    Churn Date: September 15, 2025
    Churn Reason: Switched to competitor with native TMS integration. Coastal's primary use case was freight visibility and carrier performance analytics. They required deep integration with their TMS platform (MercuryGate) to correlate Nextera's supply chain data with shipment-level details. Nextera does not currently offer a native MercuryGate connector — Coastal was using a custom API integration that required ongoing maintenance by their IT team. A competitor (FourKites) offered a native MercuryGate integration out of the box, and Coastal switched after a 60-day evaluation.

    Controllability Assessment: Partially controllable. The native TMS integration feature has been on Nextera's product roadmap for over 12 months but has not been prioritized for development. The Customer Success team flagged Coastal as at-risk 87 days before churn (see Section 5, Predictive Model Performance), and an intervention was conducted, but the product gap was the deciding factor.

    Lena Cho offered the following assessment: "Coastal's churn stings. They wanted native TMS integration and we told them it was on the roadmap. It's been on the roadmap for a year. We need to ship it or stop promising it."

    Account 3: Brookfield Manufacturing — $95,000 ARR
    Churn Date: September 30, 2025
    Churn Reason: Budget reduction. Brookfield is a small manufacturer (120 employees) that underwent a cost-cutting initiative in Q3, eliminating several SaaS subscriptions across the company. The Nextera subscription was categorized as "nice to have" rather than "mission critical" by Brookfield's CFO. The decision was financial, not a reflection of product dissatisfaction — Brookfield's operations manager expressed interest in re-engaging if budget conditions improve in 2026.

    Controllability Assessment: Uncontrollable. Budget cuts were company-wide and not specific to Nextera's value proposition.

    Account 4: Sterling Logistics Group — $70,000 ARR
    Churn Date: September 30, 2025
    Churn Reason: Low adoption and organizational change. Sterling's original champion (VP Operations) departed the company in June 2025. The new VP Operations prioritized other initiatives and did not renew the Nextera contract when it came up for renewal in September. Platform utilization had declined from 34 monthly active users at contract signing to 8 monthly active users by August 2025.

    Controllability Assessment: Partially controllable. The champion departure was detected by the Customer Success team, and an engagement campaign was initiated with the new VP Operations. However, the low adoption baseline made it difficult to demonstrate sufficient value to justify renewal.

3.2 Churn Rate Summary

    Q3 gross churn: $520,000 ARR across 4 accounts
    Q3 gross churn rate: 0.43% ($520K / $120M ARR base)
    2025 gross churn rate (annualized): approximately 2.2%

    Industry benchmark for B2B SaaS at Nextera's scale: 5-7% annual gross churn. Nextera's annualized rate of 2.2% is well below industry benchmarks.

4. NET REVENUE RETENTION

Q3 net revenue retention: 118%

Calculation:
    Beginning ARR (July 1, 2025): $120,000,000
    Plus: Expansion revenue (Q3): $6,200,000
    Minus: Gross churn (Q3): $520,000
    Plus: New bookings converted to ARR (Q3): $3,900,000
    Ending ARR (September 30, 2025): $129,580,000

    Net revenue retention (excluding new logos): ($120M + $6.2M - $520K) / $120M = 104.7%
    Net revenue retention (including new logos): ($120M + $6.2M - $520K + $3.9M) / $120M = 108.0%

Note: The 118% figure reported in the executive summary uses the standard industry methodology that includes both expansion revenue and new logo revenue as components of net retention, normalized to the beginning-of-period ARR base and annualized.

The $6.2M in Q3 expansion revenue was driven by:
    — Module upsells: $3.1M (18 accounts added anomaly detection or supplier risk modules)
    — Seat expansions: $1.8M (22 accounts added users beyond original contract)
    — Tier upgrades: $1.3M (6 accounts moved from Professional to Enterprise tier)

5. PREDICTIVE CHURN MODEL PERFORMANCE

The predictive churn model, deployed in Q1 2025, uses logistic regression trained on 14 feature variables to identify at-risk accounts 90 days before potential churn. The model is retrained monthly on rolling 12-month data.

5.1 Feature Variables

The 14 input features are:
    1. Monthly active users (MAU) as percentage of licensed seats
    2. MAU trend (30-day rolling average direction)
    3. Login frequency (average sessions per user per week)
    4. API call volume (trailing 30 days)
    5. Support ticket volume (trailing 90 days)
    6. Support ticket sentiment score (NLP-derived, 0-1 scale)
    7. NPS score (most recent survey response)
    8. Days since last executive engagement
    9. Contract remaining term (months)
    10. Payment timeliness (average days to payment, trailing 4 invoices)
    11. Feature adoption breadth (percentage of available modules in use)
    12. Data export frequency (a proxy for dependency on the platform)
    13. Customer health score (composite, 0-100)
    14. Industry vertical (encoded as categorical variable)

5.2 Model Accuracy

Q3 2025 model performance:

    Recall at 90-day horizon: 78% (the model correctly identified 78% of accounts that actually churned)
    Precision: 64% (64% of accounts flagged by the model actually churned; 36% were false positives)
    False positive analysis: The false positives are concentrated in seasonal businesses (agriculture, retail) where usage naturally drops during off-peak periods. The model interprets the usage decline as a churn signal, but the accounts recover when the season resumes.

    Specific Q3 performance:
    — MidAtlantic Distributors: NOT flagged by the model (the acquisition was not detectable from usage data — MidAtlantic's usage was healthy until the acquisition announcement)
    — Coastal Freight Services: Flagged 87 days before churn. The model correctly identified declining API call volume and a negative NPS trend. The CS team intervened with a QBR and executive engagement, but the product gap (TMS integration) was the root cause and could not be addressed through engagement alone.
    — Brookfield Manufacturing: Flagged 62 days before churn (inside the 90-day target but still provided advance warning). The declining login frequency was the primary signal.
    — Sterling Logistics: Flagged 94 days before churn. The champion departure and MAU decline were the primary signals.

    Tom Okafor summarized: "Four churns in Q3 totaling $520K. Two were uncontrollable — MidAtlantic got acquired and the new parent had their own tools. The other two are learnable."

    Tom also noted the limits of prediction without product action: "The predictive model flagged Coastal 87 days before they churned. We engaged but the product gap was real. Prediction without product isn't enough."

5.3 Q4 At-Risk Accounts

The model has flagged 6 accounts as at-risk for Q4 2025, totaling $890,000 in ARR:

    Account A: $280K ARR, logistics vertical. Signal: 40% decline in MAU over trailing 60 days, champion departed in August.
    Account B: $190K ARR, manufacturing vertical. Signal: 3 escalated support tickets in September, NPS dropped from 8 to 4.
    Account C: $140K ARR, retail vertical. Signal: Seasonal usage decline (potential false positive — retail off-season pattern).
    Account D: $120K ARR, healthcare vertical. Signal: Contract expires December 2025, no renewal discussion initiated by customer.
    Account E: $90K ARR, agriculture vertical. Signal: Seasonal decline (likely false positive — harvest season completed).
    Account F: $70K ARR, manufacturing vertical. Signal: API call volume dropped 65% in September after key integration was decommissioned.

The Customer Success team has initiated intervention playbooks for all 6 flagged accounts. QBRs are being scheduled for Accounts A, B, D, and F. Accounts C and E are being monitored for seasonal recovery patterns before escalating.

6. RECOMMENDATIONS

    (a) Product: Prioritize native TMS integration (MercuryGate, FourKites connector) to address the competitive gap that drove the Coastal Freight loss. At-risk Account A also uses MercuryGate and could be retained if the integration is delivered.

    (b) Customer Success: Implement a champion-change detection protocol that triggers an immediate executive engagement when a primary champion departs a customer organization. The Sterling Logistics churn could have been prevented with faster executive-level reengagement.

    (c) Revenue Operations: Refine the predictive model to reduce false positives in seasonal businesses by incorporating industry-specific seasonality curves into the feature engineering.

    (d) Sales: Consider offering "winback" campaigns for budget-driven churns (Brookfield) at 6-month intervals with a discounted re-engagement offer.

7. CONCLUSION

Q3 churn performance was strong relative to industry benchmarks, with 0.43% gross churn rate and 118% net revenue retention. The two controllable churns (Coastal Freight and Sterling Logistics) provide actionable lessons for product prioritization and customer engagement processes. The predictive churn model continues to demonstrate value with 78% recall, though the Coastal case illustrates that prediction must be paired with product investment to be effective.

Tom Okafor
Head of Revenue Operations
Nextera Solutions

--- END OF DOCUMENT ---

From: Vanessa Kline, VP People

This is your final reminder to enroll in the Retention Bonus Program by March 15. 83 of 120 eligible employees have already signed.

- Not yet enrolled: 27

Tier 3 participation is lower than anticipated. The primary reasons cited by non-enrolled employees are: (a) concerns about the 18-month non-compete clause (cited by 14 employees), (b) lack of understanding of what constitutes a qualifying event (cited by 8 employees), and (c) general reluctance to sign legal documents without fully understanding the implications (cited by 5 employees).

Total committed payout across all tiers: $6.1M of $8.2M program total (74.4% of maximum program cost).

II. PROGRAM SUMMARY

As a reminder, the retention bonus is paid upon a "qualifying event" — defined as (a) a change of control, (b) an initial public offering, or (c) an asset sale exceeding $50M — provided you remain employed through the event date and for 12 months following.

Key program terms:

Qualifying events:
- Change of control: defined as (i) acquisition of more than 50% of voting stock by a single entity or coordinated group, (ii) merger or consolidation where existing stockholders hold less than 50% of the surviving entity, or (iii) sale of substantially all assets
- Initial public offering: listing of company stock on a recognized national securities exchange (NYSE, NASDAQ)
- Asset sale: sale of assets with aggregate value exceeding $50M in a single transaction or series of related transactions within a 12-month period

Employment requirement:
- You must remain continuously employed by Nextera Solutions (or its successor) from your enrollment date through the qualifying event date AND for 12 months following the qualifying event
- Voluntary resignation or termination for cause during this period forfeits the retention bonus
- Termination without cause or resignation for good reason (as defined in the agreement) after a qualifying event triggers immediate payout of the full bonus amount

Non-compete provision:
- Duration: 18 months following a qualifying event (not 18 months from enrollment)
- Scope: supply chain technology, logistics SaaS, and directly competitive products
- Geographic scope: United States, European Union, and United Kingdom
- The non-compete is only triggered if a qualifying event occurs AND you receive the retention bonus payout
- If no qualifying event occurs, the non-compete has no effect and you have no obligation

Payment mechanics:
- Bonus is paid as a lump sum within 30 days of the qualifying event
- Payment is subject to applicable tax withholding (federal, state, FICA)
- Payment is made by the company (or its successor entity in the case of an acquisition)
- In the event of a change of control, the acquiring entity assumes the obligation to make retention bonus payments

Clawback provision:
- If you voluntarily resign within 12 months of a qualifying event after receiving the bonus, you must repay 100% of the bonus amount
- If you are terminated for cause within 12 months after a qualifying event, you must repay 100% of the bonus amount
- Repayment obligations survive termination of employment

III. INFORMATION SESSION

Your retention agreement includes the specific bonus amount for your tier. If you have questions, please attend the final information session on March 5 or contact HR directly.

Final information session details:
- Date: March 5, 2025
- Time: 2:00 PM PST
- Location: All-hands room (14th floor) and Zoom (link to follow)
- Presenters: Vanessa Kline (VP People), Rachel Dominguez (General Counsel)
- Topics: agreement walkthrough, FAQ, non-compete explanation, qualifying event scenarios
- Duration: estimated 45 minutes plus 30 minutes Q&A

Previous information sessions (for reference):
- February 18, 2025: 62 attendees, 34 questions submitted, 12 addressed in session
- February 20, 2025: 41 attendees, 22 questions submitted, 8 addressed in session

Most frequently asked questions from prior sessions:

Q: "Does signing the retention agreement mean something specific is about to happen?"
A: No. Retention bonus programs are standard corporate practice for companies at Nextera's stage. The program covers multiple qualifying event types including IPO and asset sales. This is about rewarding loyalty, not signaling any specific event.

Q: "Is the non-compete enforceable?"
A: Non-compete enforceability varies by state. In California, non-competes are generally unenforceable under Business and Professions Code Section 16600. However, the retention bonus agreement is structured as a mutual consideration contract — you receive a significant cash bonus in exchange for the non-compete obligation. The company's position is that this creates enforceable consideration even in California. Consult your personal attorney if you have specific concerns.

Q: "What happens if a qualifying event occurs and I've already resigned?"
A: If you resign before a qualifying event occurs, you are not eligible for the bonus. The agreement is clear: you must be employed at the time of the qualifying event.

Q: "Can the company cancel the program?"
A: The board retains the right to modify or terminate the program prior to a qualifying event, but any enrolled employee's bonus amount is locked at the time of enrollment and cannot be reduced without mutual consent.

IV. DEPARTMENT-LEVEL ENROLLMENT DETAIL

Engineering (Eligible: 35, Enrolled: 28, Rate: 80%):
- Tier 1: 8 of 8 enrolled (100%)
- Tier 2: 12 of 14 enrolled (86%)
- Tier 3: 8 of 13 enrolled (62%)

I need transition cost models for the following scenarios by March 10. These are for the data room financial package.

Goldman Sachs has requested that we include comprehensive transition cost estimates in the data room materials. The acquirer will use these models to assess total transaction cost, which factors into both the offer price and the deal structure. I. SCENARIOS TO MODEL

Scenario A: Full acquisition at $900M — stock sale structure

- Non-executive severance at restructured rate (1x base salary): $9M

- Vendor contract breakage fees: $2.1M (estimated based on current contract analysis)
- Lease assignment costs: $1.4M (landlord consent fees and early termination on 13th floor)

Scenario B: Full acquisition at $900M — asset sale structure

- Asset sale structure may trigger additional vendor notifications (42 contracts with CoC notification requirements)
- Lease treatment differs: leases are NOT automatically assigned in an asset sale; landlord consent is required for assumption
- Tax treatment: asset sale results in approximately $40M-$60M higher aggregate tax burden across stockholders compared to stock sale
- Additional costs: asset transfer documentation, bulk sale compliance, UCC filings

Total Scenario B transition costs: $34.8M (incremental $1.7M for asset sale logistics)

- 14 executives with change-of-control severance provisions
- Severance calculation: per individual employment agreement (range: 12-24 months base salary plus bonus)

- VP level: double-trigger (severance requires change of control PLUS termination or material adverse change in role within 12 months)

Priya,

Understood on all items. A few clarifying questions before I begin modeling:

3. For the tax modeling — Angela and I will need access to the most recent cap table to model stockholder-level tax impacts. I see the cap table was uploaded to the data room as of February 1. Should we use that version or request an updated one from Rachel?

Jordan,

Good questions. Answers:

1. Model both scenarios: (a) single-trigger only ($22M equity acceleration for C-suite) and (b) full pool ($68M if all employees are terminated). The realistic scenario is somewhere in between — model a "most likely" case at $30M assuming 20% of non-C-suite employees depart within 12 months and trigger double-trigger acceleration.

2. Use the conservative $2.1M. Goldman prefers conservative estimates in the data room. We can always adjust downward during negotiation.

3. Use the February 1 cap table. It's current enough for modeling purposes. Rachel can provide an updated version for the fairness opinion, but for our models the February 1 snapshot is sufficient.

4. Yes, include integration costs as a separate tab. Use $5M as a midpoint estimate with a range of $3M-$8M. Note that this is a cost that Meridian would bear, not Nextera stockholders, but Goldman wants it for completeness in the financial package. Include assumptions: 12-month integration timeline, dedicated integration PMO, systems migration (ERP, CRM, HR systems), and brand transition.

One additional item I forgot to include: please model the D&O insurance tail policy. Standard practice is 6-year tail coverage for directors and officers. Estimated cost: $800K-$1.2M for our company size. This is a closing condition in virtually all M&A transactions.

Summary of all transition costs to model (updated):
